scenarios.title: Child Bites and Stings
immediate_steps: Wash the wound with soap and water
Apply a cold compress to reduce swelling
Monitor for signs of infection
do_not: Break the skin open
Use harsh soap
scenarios.additional_info: Seek medical attention if symptoms worsen or do not improve within 24 hours

scenarios.title: Heat Stroke at Home
immediate_steps: Call emergency services immediately
Remove the child from the heat source
Cool the child down with cool water or a cold compress
do_not: Give the child anything to drink
Use ice to lower body temperature
scenarios.additional_info: Seek medical attention if symptoms last longer than 30 minutes

scenarios.title: Drowning at a Pool
immediate_steps: Call emergency services immediately
Start CPR if trained to do so
Begin rescue breaths
do_not: Try to lift the child out of the water without proper training
Use a manual defibrillator on an unresponsive person
scenarios.additional_info: Seek medical attention immediately if symptoms persist

scenarios.title: Poisoning from Insecticides
immediate_steps: Call emergency services immediately
Remove any contaminated clothing or items
Provide the child with a glass of water if they are conscious
do_not: Give the child anything to drink except water
Try to induce vomiting unless instructed by medical professionals
scenarios.additional_info: Seek medical attention within 30 minutes of exposure

scenarios.title: Mild Head Injury in Child
symptoms: swelling that goes down after cold compress
immediate_steps: Apply a cold compress for 20 minutes
Watch your child closely for a time
Check if there are any changes in the child's condition
do_not: apply heat or ice
try to move the child
scenarios.additional_info: If symptoms worsen, call doctor immediately

scenarios.title: Moderate Head Injury with Loss of Consciousness
immediate_steps: Call 911 and get to the hospital immediately
Administer oxygen if available
Keep the child calm and still

scenarios.title: Severe Head Injury with Increased Intracranial Pressure
immediate_steps: Call 911 and get to the hospital immediately
Administer oxygen if available
Start CPR if child is not breathing

scenarios.title: Child Abuse Head Injury
symptoms: bruises or bleeding on the head

Get to a safe location and call for help
Do not attempt to care for the child
when_to_seek_help: bruises or bleeding on the head

scenarios.title: Child with Severe Dehydration
immediate_steps: Administer oral rehydration solution (ORS) according to package instructions
Offer cool water in small amounts to increase fluid intake
Monitor vital signs closely
do_not: try to force fluids down the child's throat
scenarios.additional_info: Seek medical attention immediately if symptoms worsen or do not improve with treatment

scenarios.title: Child with Difficulty Breathing
immediate_steps: Clear the airway by tilting the child's head back and lifting their chin
Position the child on their side to help keep their airway open
Call 911 or your local emergency number immediately
when_to_seek_help: cyanosis or blue discoloration of the skin
do_not: use a tourniquet or attempt to manually ventilate the child

scenarios.title: Child with Large Volume of Blood in Stools
symptoms: large volume of blood in stools
immediate_steps: Immediately clean and dress the wound with a sterile dressing or bandage
Apply firm pressure to the wound to control bleeding
Call 911 or your local emergency number immediately
when_to_seek_help: severe bleeding that will not stop
do_not: try to clean the wound with soap and water
scenarios.additional_info: Seek medical attention immediately if symptoms worsen or do not improve

scenarios.title: Adult with Heat Exhaustion

Provide cool water to drink in small amounts
Monitor vital signs closely
when_to_seek_help: heat exhaustion symptoms that worsen or do not improve
do_not: try to force the person to drink more fluids
scenarios.additional_info: Seek medical attention if symptoms worsen or do not improve

scenarios.title: Child with Fever and Headache

apply topical antibiotic ointment
cover with a non-stick dressing

clear the airway by tilting head back

do_not: use mouth to mouth resuscitation

scenarios.title: Drowning
immediate_steps: start CPR
call 911 immediately
use an automated external defibrillator (AED) if available

provide information about the substance ingested to emergency responders
administer first aid if trained
when_to_seek_help: symptoms persist or worsen over time

scenarios.title: Seizure

stop any activity that may have caused the seizure

when_to_seek_help: symptoms worsen or do not improve within 15 minutes of treatment

scenarios.title: Allergic Reaction (Anaphylaxis)
symptoms: Swelling of the face, lips, tongue, or throat
immediate_steps: Administer epinephrine using an EpiPen if available
Call 911 or your local emergency number
Lay the person down and elevate their legs
Administer oxygen if possible
Continue to monitor vital signs until medical help arrives
when_to_seek_help: If you are experiencing symptoms yourself

scenarios.title: Head Injury (Concussion)
immediate_steps: Remove any loose objects from the victim's pocket or surroundings
Keep them calm and quiet
Apply cold compresses to the forehead and neck if necessary
Monitor vital signs for 30 minutes
Do not give medication unless advised by a doctor

scenarios.title: Heat Stroke
immediate_steps: Move the person to a cooler location and remove excess clothing
Remove any constrictive items from around their neck
Use cool tap water to cool the forehead, armpits, and groin area

Monitor vital signs and seek medical help
when_to_seek_help: If symptoms worsen or do not improve with cooling measures
If body temperature does not drop within 1 hour of treatment

scenarios.title: Poisoning by Inhalation

Rescue the person from the danger of the gas, fumes, or smoke

Take several deep breaths of fresh air, and then hold your breath as you go in
when_to_seek_help: Difficulty breathing or shortness of breath

Clear the person's airway if they vomit

symptoms: Difficulty breathing or shortness of breath
immediate_steps: Call for emergency help
Rescue the person from the danger of the gas, fumes, or smoke
Take several deep breaths of fresh air, and then hold your breath as you go in

immediate_steps: Cut the tip of the hook off just behind the barb with wire cutters.

do_not: Close the wound with tape

scenarios.title: Minor Laceration
immediate_steps: Apply liquid bandage over the wound.

scenarios.title: Moderate Bleeding from Laceration

do_not: Do not apply tourniquet without proper training.
Do not use a tight bandage that cuts off circulation.
scenarios.additional_info: Apply firm pressure to the wound with a clean cloth, and elevate the injured limb above heart level.

scenarios.title: Severe Laceration
immediate_steps: Call 911 or your local emergency number.

scenarios.title: Broken Finger Splinting

do_not: Apply direct pressure on the injury

scenarios.title: Ankle Sprain Treatment
immediate_steps: Apply ice packs to the affected area for 15-20 minutes, three times a day.

scenarios.title: Burn Care for a Minor Burn
immediate_steps: Cool the burn with cool tap water for 10-15 minutes.

do_not: Use harsh soap or apply ice to the burn

scenarios.title: Head Injury First Aid
immediate_steps: Stay calm and reassure the person.
Clear the area of any hazards or obstacles.
Check for breathing and pulse, then call for medical help.
do_not: Move the person unless they are in immediate danger.
Apply direct pressure on the injury

scenarios.title: Choking First Aid for Adults
immediate_steps: Stand behind the person and use the heel of your hand to perform a back slap.
Give five quick chest thrusts until the object is dislodged, then give 30 chest compressions if needed.
Call for medical help immediately.
do_not: Try to remove any visible object from the person's mouth
Perform artificial respiration

scenarios.title: Applying Liquid Bandage for Minor Laceration

do_not: Use liquid bandage around the eyes, in the ear or nose
scenarios.additional_info: Keep activity to a minimum and do not scrub the site

scenarios.title: Caring for a Severe Laceration
immediate_steps: Apply direct pressure to the wound with a clean cloth or gauze for 10 minutes.
Elevate the injured area above heart level.
Call emergency services and seek immediate medical attention.
scenarios.additional_info: Do not attempt to clean or dress the wound yourself

scenarios.title: First Aid for a Snake Bite
immediate_steps: Remove any constrictive items from the affected area.
Keep the bite wound below heart level.
Do not attempt to suck out the venom or use a tourniquet.
do_not: Use ice or ice water
scenarios.additional_info: Seek immediate medical attention and call emergency services

scenarios.title: Minor Cut on the Hand
immediate_steps: Apply gentle pressure with a bandage for 5 minutes to stop bleeding.
Clean the cut with soap and water, then apply an antiseptic solution or wipe.
Cover the cut with a sterile gauze pad.
do_not: force the wound closed
apply harsh soap
scenarios.additional_info: Monitor for signs of infection

scenarios.title: Burn on the Arm
immediate_steps: Run cool tap water over the burn for 10-15 minutes to reduce temperature and ease pain.
Remove any clothing or jewelry near the burned area, and apply a non-stick dressing.
Take an over-the-counter pain reliever such as acetaminophen.
do_not: use harsh soap or ointment
apply ice
scenarios.additional_info: Monitor for signs of infection

scenarios.title: Broken Toe
immediate_steps: Stop activity and elevate the foot above heart level to reduce swelling.
Apply an elastic bandage or splint to immobilize the toe.
Use ice packs wrapped in a cloth to reduce pain.
do_not: try to move the toe
apply harsh soap
scenarios.additional_info: Monitor for signs of infection

scenarios.title: Choking on an Object
immediate_steps: Stand behind the person and use a firm grip on the object to help dislodge it.
Clear the airway of any remaining debris, if needed.
Back slaps, if necessary, between abdominal thrusts until relief is achieved.
do_not: use forceful blows to chest or throat
scenarios.additional_info: Call emergency services immediately

scenarios.title: Infant Choking
symptoms: Difficulty breathing -- ribs and chest pull inward
Loss of consciousness (unresponsiveness) if blockage is not cleared
immediate_steps: Turn the infant face-up. Use your thigh or lap for support. Support the head.
Place 2 fingers on the middle of the breastbone just below the nipples.
Give up to 5 quick thrusts down, compressing the chest one third to one half the depth of the chest.
do_not: Grasp and pull out the object if the infant is alert (conscious)
Do back blows and chest thrusts if the infant stops breathing for other reasons
scenarios.additional_info: If the child becomes unresponsive, stops breathing, or turns blue, shout for help. Give infant CPR.

scenarios.title: Head Injury with Concussion
immediate_steps: Stop activity and rest.
Remove helmet or headgear if applicable.
Apply ice pack to the affected area.
when_to_seek_help: Symptoms worsen or do not improve with rest.
do_not: Continue to participate in activities
Use pain medication without medical supervision
scenarios.additional_info: Monitor for signs of worsening concussion, such as increased dizziness, vomiting, or confusion.

scenarios.title: Burns on the Hands
immediate_steps: Run cool tap water over the burn for 10-15 minutes.
Apply a topical antibiotic ointment and cover with a non-stick dressing.
Elevate the affected hand above heart level.
when_to_seek_help: Infection signs appear, such as increased redness, swelling, or pus
do_not: Use harsh soap, ointment, or apply a tourniquet.
Break any blisters that form without medical supervision
scenarios.additional_info: Monitor for signs of infection and seek medical attention if symptoms worsen or do not improve.

scenarios.title: Choking in Children
symptoms: Noisy breathing or high-pitched sounds while inhaling
immediate_steps: Ask if person is choking, perform abdominal thrusts or back blows
Continue until object is dislodged or person loses consciousness

immediate_steps: Stop the burning process by smothering with a non-flammable material

do_not: Break blisters or scabbing
Use ice or ice water
scenarios.additional_info: Seek medical attention immediately if the burn covers a large area or is deep.

scenarios.title: Torn ACL
symptoms: Swelling and bruising around the knee

scenarios.title: Bleeding Control with Tourniquet
immediate_steps: Apply a tourniquet to the affected limb if bleeding is severe and cannot be controlled with pressure alone.
Call for emergency assistance and get to a hospital as soon as possible.
Keep the person calm and still until medical help arrives.
when_to_seek_help: bleeding that doesn't stop after 10-15 minutes of pressure

scenarios.additional_info: Tourniquets should only be used by trained professionals in emergency situations.

scenarios.title: Choking on a Foreign Object
immediate_steps: Back slaps on the person's back between their shoulder blades to dislodge the object.

Continue chest compressions if the person becomes unresponsive.
do_not: Use your fingers to try and remove the object from the person's mouth
scenarios.additional_info: Choking can be a sign of anaphylaxis or asthma attack. Call 911 immediately.

scenarios.title: Burns from Heat or Flame

when_to_seek_help: Burns that cover more than 1/3 of the body surface, blisters, charring
do_not: Use ice or ice water on burns
scenarios.additional_info: Burns can be serious and lead to infection. Seek medical help if symptoms persist.

scenarios.title: Bite or Sting from Insect
immediate_steps: Wash the wound with soap and water.

do_not: Squeeze the insect's body or try to remove the venom with tweezers

fan the person

Wash your hands thoroughly before assisting the next person.

when_to_seek_help: Vision loss or severe eye pain that doesn't improve after treatment
do_not: Using harsh chemicals or soap
scenarios.additional_info: Seek immediate medical attention

scenarios.title: Cut from Fingertip
immediate_steps: Apply pressure with a clean cloth for 5 minutes
Elevate the injured area above heart level
Clean the wound with soap and water
do_not: Touch the wound with bare hands
scenarios.additional_info: Apply antibiotic ointment after cleaning

scenarios.title: Severe Burn
symptoms: Burning sensation, charring skin, and white or charred tissue
immediate_steps: Cool the burn with cool tap water for 10 minutes
Remove any clothing near the affected area
Apply a topical antibiotic ointment after cooling
when_to_seek_help: Signs of infection, fever, or systemic symptoms like dizziness
do_not: Use ice or ice-cold water
scenarios.additional_info: Seek medical attention for burns covering 10% or more body surface area

scenarios.title: Poisoning from Insect Stings
symptoms: Redness, swelling, or pain at the site
immediate_steps: Remove any constrictive clothing
Clean the affected area with soap and water
Apply a cold compress
when_to_seek_help: Severe allergic reactions, swelling of face, tongue, or throat, or anaphylaxis
do_not: Use heat to relieve itching
scenarios.additional_info: If symptoms worsen, seek medical attention

scenarios.title: Burned Face
immediate_steps: Cool the burn with cool tap water for 10 minutes
Remove any constrictive clothing
Apply a topical antibiotic ointment after cooling
do_not: Use ice or ice-cold water
scenarios.additional_info: Monitor face for signs of infection and seek medical attention if necessary

scenarios.title: Unresponsive Child
immediate_steps: Start CPR if the child is not breathing
Check for signs of circulation
Call 911 or your local emergency number
do_not: move the child unless absolutely necessary
scenarios.additional_info: Get a parent's contact information if possible

scenarios.title: Bleeding from a Deep Laceration
immediate_steps: Apply pressure to the wound with a clean cloth or gauze
Elevate the injured limb above heart level
Call 911 or your local emergency number
do_not: apply tourniquet unless trained in its use
scenarios.additional_info: Use a pressure dressing to control bleeding

scenarios.title: Poisoning from Inhaling Fumes
immediate_steps: Call 911 or your local emergency number
Move the person to fresh air if possible
Remove any contaminated clothing or objects
do_not: use a person's own air if available
scenarios.additional_info: Do not attempt to treat symptoms unless trained in first aid

scenarios.title: Critical Signs of Death
immediate_steps: Call EMS/9-1-1 immediately
Leave the body and scene as found
Do not try to treat the individual yourself
do_not: try to move or transport the individual
scenarios.additional_info: Obtain a first aid kit and AED if available

scenarios.title: Unresponsive Person in Face-Down Position
immediate_steps: Call out loudly for help if you have a mobile phone
Get to a phone as quickly as possible and call EMS/9-1-1
Roll the person from face-down to face-up position
do_not: try to move or transport the individual
scenarios.additional_info: Support the head while rolling the person

scenarios.title: Ill or Injured Person in a Life-Threatening Position
immediate_steps: Do not move the person unless absolutely necessary
Use a mobile phone to call EMS/9-1-1 while staying with the individual
If someone else needs to leave, ask them to come back and tell you what the dispatcher said
do_not: try to move or transport the individual
scenarios.additional_info: Stay with the person and continue to provide care while waiting for help

scenarios.title: Decomposition
immediate_steps: Call EMS/9-1-1 immediately
Leave the body and scene as found
Do not try to treat the individual yourself
do_not: try to move or transport the individual
scenarios.additional_info: Obtain a first aid kit and AED if available

scenarios.title: Unconscious Person with Difficulty Breathing
immediate_steps: Call out for help if you have a mobile phone
Get to a phone as quickly as possible and call EMS/9-1-1
Use the head-tilt/chin-lift technique to open the airway
do_not: try to move or transport the individual
scenarios.additional_info: Check the person's ABCs after opening the airway

scenarios.title: Bleeding Person
immediate_steps: Apply firm and steady pressure to the wound
Elevate the injured limb above heart level if possible
Use a tourniquet or hemostatic agent if available
do_not: try to remove any constrictive items from the affected area
scenarios.additional_info: Call EMS/9-1-1 for further guidance and transportation

scenarios.title: Life-threatening bleeding
immediate_steps: Apply direct pressure to the wound.
Elevate the affected limb above heart level.
Call EMS/9-1-1 immediately.

scenarios.title: Non-breathing child or baby
immediate_steps: Start CPR (5 cycles of 30 compressions and 2 breaths).
Introduce oxygen into the child's system as soon as possible.
Call EMS/9-1-1 immediately.

scenarios.title: Unresponsive adult
immediate_steps: Start CPR (5 cycles of 30 compressions and 2 breaths).
Check the person's airway, breathing, and circulation.
Call EMS/9-1-1 immediately.

scenarios.title: Rolling into Recovery Position for Unresponsiveness
immediate_steps: Check airway, breathing, and circulation (ABCs) before moving the person.
Roll the person onto their side into the recovery position if they are unresponsive or have an altered level of responsiveness.
Support the person's head, neck, and spine while in the recovery position.
scenarios.additional_info: Use caution when rolling a person with a suspected spinal injury.

scenarios.title: Assessing and Providing Care for an Unresponsive Person
immediate_steps: Check the person's airway, breathing, and circulation (ABCs) before providing care.
Use a barrier device to protect your airway if you need to assess or provide care for the person.
Provide reassurance and maintain a comfortable temperature.

scenarios.title: Assessing and Providing Care for a Person with Respiratory Distress
immediate_steps: Position the person on their side to prevent choking.
Clear the airway by tilting the head back and lifting the chin.
Use oxygen if available.

scenarios.title: Rolling into Recovery Position
immediate_steps: Raise the persons arm that is closest to you.
Continue to give appropriate care until the next step is required.
Place the arm farther from you across the persons chest with the palm against the cheek.

scenarios.title: Helping a Person with Minor Bleeding
immediate_steps: Position the person on their side, and slide the bent knee into a position that prevents them from rolling onto their face.
Apply pressure to the wound if it is deep or large.
Elevate the affected limb above heart level.

scenarios.title: Triaging Multiple Injuries
immediate_steps: Assess the persons ABCs (Airway, Breathing, Circulation) to determine severity.
Prioritize care for the most critical injuries first.
Call for emergency assistance if necessary.

scenarios.title: Administering Medication to an Injured Person
immediate_steps: Position the head so that it keeps the airway open.
Check the label to ensure it is the correct medication.
Administer the medication if the person is responsive and has expressed a need for help.

scenarios.title: Providing Care to an Ill Person
immediate_steps: Support and protect the head while rolling the person.
Try to roll the person as one unit (head, back, and legs at the same time).
Roll the person into a position where the body will stay safely on its side.

scenarios.title: Inhaler Overdose
immediate_steps: Remain calm and call for help
Shake the inhaler before dispensing medication
Have the person hold their breath and inhale quickly
do_not: Administer additional medication

scenarios.title: Auto-Injector Misuse
immediate_steps: Remove cover and inspect for expiration date
Read label instructions carefully
Administer medication according to label instructions
do_not: Force the auto-injector's needle into skin

scenarios.title: Inhaler Not Dispensed Correctly
immediate_steps: Remain calm and assess situation
Check the person's medication instructions
Administer medication according to label instructions
do_not: Use additional medication without consulting first aid expert

scenarios.title: Elderly Person Taking Inhaled Medication
immediate_steps: Assess the person's medication instructions and needs
Use a spacer device to deliver medication safely
Monitor the person for signs of distress
do_not: Administer additional medication without consulting first aid expert

scenarios.title: Child Using Auto-Injector
immediate_steps: Assess the child's ability to use auto-injector safely
Administer medication according to label instructions
Monitor the child for signs of distress
do_not: Use additional medication without consulting first aid expert

scenarios.title: Choking on Liquid Medication
immediate_steps: Remain calm and act quickly
Back the person up to a seated position
Administer the liquid medication carefully
do_not: Use objects to try to dislodge the object from their throat

scenarios.title: Overdose on Prescription Medication
immediate_steps: Call emergency services immediately
Administer naloxone if available
Keep the person safe and comfortable
do_not: Administer additional medication without consulting medical professional

scenarios.title: Bleeding from Auto-Injector
immediate_steps: Apply firm pressure to the injection site
Elevate the injured area above heart level
Call emergency services immediately
do_not: Use additional medication without consulting medical professional

scenarios.title: Environmental Exposure (Pesticide, etc.)
immediate_steps: Move the person to fresh air quickly and calmly
Remove contaminated clothing and wash affected area
Call emergency services if symptoms worsen
do_not: Use antidotes without consulting medical professional

scenarios.title: Burns from Inhaler or Auto-Injector
immediate_steps: Wash the burn area with cool water
Apply a topical antibiotic ointment
Monitor for signs of infection
do_not: Use additional medication without consulting medical professional

scenarios.title: Hypoglycemia
immediate_steps: Give the person a quick-acting carbohydrate source (such as glucose tablets or juice)
Monitor vital signs
Check for any underlying medical conditions
do_not: give the person any medication without consulting a doctor
scenarios.additional_info: Continue to monitor for further symptoms

scenarios.title: Respiratory Distress from Injury
immediate_steps: Call EMS/9-1-1 if symptoms worsen or do not improve with rest.
Help the person sit upright and use an oxygen mask if available.
Loosen tight clothing around the neck and chest.
do_not: try to lift the person or move them to a different position
scenarios.additional_info: Monitor vital signs closely

scenarios.title: Burns on Extremities
immediate_steps: Cool the burn with cool water for 10-15 minutes
Remove clothing and jewelry near the burned area
Apply a topical antibiotic ointment
do_not: Use home remedies without medical supervision
scenarios.additional_info: Do not break blisters

scenarios.title: Broken Rib Injury
immediate_steps: Check for airway, breathing, and circulation (ABC)
Support the person's head and back
Apply a makeshift splint
when_to_seek_help: Pain that worsens or difficulty breathing
do_not: Try to move the person without proper training
scenarios.additional_info: Do not attempt to remove the splint

scenarios.title: Bleeding from Wound
immediate_steps: Apply pressure to the wound with a clean cloth or bandage
Elevate the injured area above heart level
Call emergency services
do_not: Try to apply tourniquet without proper training
scenarios.additional_info: Do not apply pressure too tightly

scenarios.title: Driving Illness: Hypothermia
immediate_steps: Keep the person warm and dry
Loosen tight clothing
Drink a non-caffeinated beverage to rehydrate
do_not: Give medication or food
Let them drive further
scenarios.additional_info: Be cautious of frostbite

scenarios.title: Sudden Shock
immediate_steps: Raise the person's head and legs to reduce swelling
Check for airway and breathing obstruction
Call 911 immediately
do_not: Move them unless absolutely necessary
scenarios.additional_info: Use CPR if the person is unresponsive

scenarios.title: Minor Injury: Sprained Ankle
immediate_steps: Apply the RICE principle (Rest, Ice, Compression, Elevation)
Use a splint or sling to immobilize the injury
Monitor for signs of infection
do_not: Try to put weight on the injured ankle
scenarios.additional_info: Encourage rest and physical therapy

scenarios.title: Signs and Symptoms of Shock
symptoms: Skin that is paler than normal
immediate_steps: Call EMS/9-1-1
Provide care by giving the person water or an electrolyte-rich drink
Check the person's ABCs (Airway, Breathing, Circulation) and provide reassurance
do_not: Touch or speak to service animals
scenarios.additional_info: Avoid stereotypes and make no assumptions about what abilities the person has or does not have.

scenarios.title: Severe Infection (Septicemia)
immediate_steps: Isolate the person from others to prevent further infection
Remove any constrictive clothing or accessories
Keep the person's head elevated and provide oxygen if necessary
do_not: Use antibiotics without medical supervision

scenarios.title: Signs and Symptoms of Heart Damage
immediate_steps: Call EMS/9-1-1 immediately
Provide oxygen if necessary
Loosen any constrictive clothing around the neck and chest
do_not: Give aspirin or ibuprofen without medical supervision

scenarios.title: Signs and Symptoms of Anxiety
immediate_steps: Listen to the person without judgment
Provide reassurance and calm them down
Help the person find a quiet, comfortable place
do_not: Try to fight or restrain the person

scenarios.title: Providing First Aid to Someone with Vision Loss Due to Lack of Central Vision
immediate_steps: Ask the person if they are experiencing any dizziness or disorientation.
Check the person's airway, breathing, and circulation (ABCs) as usual.
Use touch to guide the person and maintain their balance.
do_not: touch the person without permission
scenarios.additional_info: Assume the lack of central vision is a temporary condition and can be treated with rest

scenarios.title: Providing First Aid to Someone Who Is Deafblind Due to Total Blindness
immediate_steps: Speak directly to the person, but do not touch them.
Use a clear and firm voice to communicate, and avoid shouting.
Use tactile sign language or written communication methods if necessary.
do_not: touch the person without permission
scenarios.additional_info: Be patient and provide reassurance while using non-visual communication methods

scenarios.title: Providing First Aid to Someone with a Physical Disability Due to a Broken Bone
immediate_steps: Apply the RICE principle (Rest, Ice, Compression, Elevation) to the affected area.
Use a splint or sling to immobilize the broken bone if possible.
Monitor the person's vital signs and watch for signs of shock.
do_not: move the person excessively without proper stabilization
scenarios.additional_info: Prioritize immobilizing the affected area to prevent further injury

scenarios.title: Providing First Aid to Someone with Hearing Loss Due to a Head Injury
immediate_steps: Check the person's airway, breathing, and circulation (ABCs) as usual.
Clear any blockages from the person's mouth, nose, or ears if necessary.
Use a device that produces high-pitched sounds to stimulate the person's auditory nerve.
do_not: try to communicate with the person without proper sound amplification
scenarios.additional_info: Act quickly and follow proper protocols for cardiac arrest

scenarios.title: Providing First Aid to Someone with an Intellectual or Developmental Disability
immediate_steps: Stay calm and patient
Use straightforward language when communicating
Give one piece of information at a time
scenarios.additional_info: Note: The person's disability may not be immediately apparent.

scenarios.title: Providing First Aid to Someone with a Speech or Language Impairment
immediate_steps: Ask yes or no questions if possible
Give the person time to answer and finish speaking
Avoid finishing their sentences
scenarios.additional_info: Use assistive devices such as communication boards if available.

scenarios.title: Bleeding from a Cut on Someone with an Intellectual or Developmental Disability
immediate_steps: Apply gentle pressure to the cut with a clean cloth or bandage
Elevate the injured area above heart level if possible
Use ice packs to reduce bleeding and swelling

scenarios.title: Choking on Someone with a Speech or Language Impairment
immediate_steps: Backslap: stand behind the person and use both hands to slap their back in the middle of the chest
Front slaps: stand in front of the person and perform five quick upward slaps on the chest
Back blows: stand behind the person and give five quick downward thrusts into the abdomen

scenarios.title: Shock in Someone with an Intellectual or Developmental Disability
immediate_steps: Call 911 or your local emergency number if possible
Lay the person down on their back on a firm surface
Loosen tight clothing around the neck and chest
when_to_seek_help: No pulse, slow pulse, pale skin

scenarios.title: Sprains and Strains from Someone with an Intellectual or Developmental Disability
immediate_steps: Apply ice packs to the affected area for 15-20 minutes
Use compression bandages or wraps to support the injured limb
Elevate the injured area above heart level if possible
when_to_seek_help: Severe pain that doesn't improve with rest
Limited mobility that makes breathing difficult

scenarios.title: Complete Choking in Child
immediate_steps: Call 9-1-1 or EMS
Position the child on their back
Support the head and neck with a straight object
Clear the airway by tilting the head and lifting chin
do_not: Try to remove the obstruction yourself
scenarios.additional_info: Continue CPR until medical help arrives

scenarios.title: Partial Choking in Adult
immediate_steps: Encourage the person to cough and dislodge the obstruction
Stand by and monitor the person's condition
Call 9-1-1 or EMS if the person's condition worsens
when_to_seek_help: The person becomes weaker or less able to cough
do_not: Apply pressure to the chest
scenarios.additional_info: Continue to monitor the person's condition until medical help arrives

scenarios.title: Choking from Swallowing a Foreign Object
immediate_steps: Call 9-1-1 or EMS
Support the person's neck and head with a straight object
Clear any remaining foreign objects from the mouth and throat
when_to_seek_help: The person becomes weaker or less able to cough
do_not: Try to remove the obstruction yourself
scenarios.additional_info: Continue to monitor the person's condition until medical help arrives

scenarios.title: Partial Choking in Child
immediate_steps: Encourage child to sit while eating
Make sure object is not a choking hazard
Call 911 if obstruction does not clear
do_not: Interfere with the obstruction
scenarios.additional_info: Supervise children and babies when they are eating

scenarios.title: Complete Choking
symptoms: inability to speak, cough, or breathe
immediate_steps: stand behind the person and wrap one arm diagonally across the throat chest
bend the person forward at the waist until the upper airway is at least parallel to the ground
call deliver up to 5 firm back blows between the shoulder blades
do_not: delay care by calling EMS/9-1-1 yourself

scenarios.title: Child Over 12 Months with Broken Arm
immediate_steps: immobilize the arm with a splint or sling
apply cold compresses to reduce swelling
take the child to see a doctor as soon as possible
do_not: move the arm excessively

scenarios.title: Adult with Severe Burns
immediate_steps: call 911 or your local emergency number
remove any constrictive clothing or jewelry
apply a cool compress to reduce heat and prevent further injury
do_not: use water on severe burns

scenarios.title: Chest Thrusts for Cardiac Arrest in Adults
immediate_steps: Make a fist and place it in the middle of the person's chest, placing your thumb facing inward.
Cover your fist with your other hand and give up to 5 quick, inward and upward thrusts into pulling straight back toward you.
Continue chest thrusts until emergency services arrive or the person shows signs of regaining consciousness.
do_not: Try to give CPR if not trained
scenarios.additional_info: Continue chest thrusts at a rate of 100-120 per minute

scenarios.title: Abdominal Thrusts for Vomiting in Adults
immediate_steps: Stand behind the person and wrap both of your arms around the person's chest, just under the armpits.
Make a fist and place it in the middle of the person's chest, placing your thumb facing inward.
Continue abdominal thrusts until vomiting stops or emergency services arrive.
do_not: Try to give CPR if not trained
scenarios.additional_info: Use 1-2 fingers to apply pressure

scenarios.title: Choking Adult: Larger/ Pregnant
immediate_steps: Dial EMS/9-1-1 and leave the phone off the hook.
If you cannot reach far enough, move to a place where you can be noticed.
Attempt to dislodge the object by performing an abdominal thrust
scenarios.additional_info: Alternate between 5 firm back blows and 5 chest thrusts.

scenarios.title: Choking Toddler
immediate_steps: If the child is short enough, kneel on the floor with one knee raised.
Perform 5 back blows with the child leaning across your raised leg.
Continue until the object comes out, the child begins to breathe or cough.

scenarios.title: Choking Adult: Responsive
immediate_steps: Dial EMS/9-1-1 and leave the phone off the hook.
If there are people nearby, move to a place where you can be noticed.
Attempt to dislodge the object between 5 firm back blows

scenarios.title: Choking Toddler: Responsive
immediate_steps: If you can reach the child, stand behind them and wrap your arms around their waist.
Perform 5 back blows with the child facing upwards on your arm.
Continue until the object comes out.
do_not: Try to remove the object yourself

scenarios.title: Choking Baby (Less Than 12 Months)
immediate_steps: If the object has not been dislodged, turn the baby face-up,
Sit or kneel holding the baby.
Position the baby face down along your forearm, holding his or 6. Place 2 fingers on the middle of the chest just below the nipple

If you are alone, immediately begin care for complete choking.

 Shout for help.

scenarios.title: Object Lodged in Airway
immediate_steps: Clear airway by tilting head back and lifting chin
Check for object lodged in the throat
Perform back blows if necessary
do_not: use scissors to remove the object
scenarios.additional_info: Seek immediate medical attention

scenarios.title: Smoking Cessation and Cardiac Arrest
immediate_steps: Call 911 or local emergency number
Start CPR if trained
Administer epinephrine auto-injector (if trained)
do_not: Try to treat the person yourself, unless trained
scenarios.additional_info: Act quickly and follow proper first aid procedures for cardiac arrest

scenarios.title: Angina or Heart Attack
immediate_steps: Call 911 or local emergency number
Start CPR if trained
Administer epinephrine auto-injector (if trained)
do_not: Try to treat the person yourself, unless trained
scenarios.additional_info: Act quickly and follow proper first aid procedures for angina or heart attack

scenarios.title: High Blood Pressure Detection
immediate_steps: Measure blood pressure regularly
Check for changes in blood pressure patterns
Consult a doctor
when_to_seek_help: chest pain lasting longer than 3-5 minutes
do_not: self-medicate
change medication without consulting a doctor
scenarios.additional_info: Routine testing is recommended for individuals at high risk of developing hypertension.

scenarios.title: Chest Pain during Heart Attack
symptoms: pain or discomfort lasting longer than 3-5 minutes
immediate_steps: Call emergency services immediately
Provide basic life support (CPR) if necessary
Loosen tight clothing around the neck and chest
when_to_seek_help: chest pain that worsens or does not improve with rest
do_not: try to drive yourself to the hospital
use aspirin without consulting a doctor first
scenarios.additional_info: Prompt medical attention is crucial for effective treatment and survival.

scenarios.title: Obesity and Heart Disease
symptoms: increased risk of high blood pressure
immediate_steps: Consult a doctor about weight management plans
Eat a balanced diet and engage in regular exercise
Avoid excessive caffeine intake
when_to_seek_help: weight gain or obesity without a clear cause
do_not: avoid seeking medical help for weight-related issues
try to manage weight on their own without professional guidance
scenarios.additional_info: Maintaining a healthy weight through lifestyle changes can significantly reduce the risk of heart disease.

scenarios.title: Mild Chest Discomfort
immediate_steps: Have the person rest comfortably
Encourage the person to chew and swallow 160 to 325 mg of acetylsalicylic acid (ASA)
Reassure the person
do_not: repeat the ASA dosage
scenarios.additional_info: Monitor symptoms, call EMS/9-1-1 if they worsen or don't improve with rest

scenarios.title: Extreme Fatigue
immediate_steps: Offer to locate the prescribed medication to relieve chest pain
Help the person take the medication
Reassure the person
do_not: let the person delay taking the medication

scenarios.title: Dizziness or Light-Headedness During a Heart Attack
immediate_steps: Call EMS/9-1-1 and get an AED immediately
Reassure the person that anxiety may increase discomfort
Do not let the person delay seeking help
do_not: let the person delay seeking help

scenarios.title: Angina
immediate_steps: Call 9-1-1 or local emergency number
Administer nitroglycerin (if given by doctor)
Provide oxygen if available
do_not: Drive the person to medical facility

scenarios.title: Heart Attack
immediate_steps: Call 9-1-1 or local emergency number
Administer aspirin (if given by doctor)
Provide CPR if necessary
do_not: Drive the person to medical facility
Try to give medication

scenarios.title: Ruptured Aneurysm
immediate_steps: Call EMS/9-1-1 immediately.
Check airway, breathing, and circulation (ABC) status.
Apply cervical collar to stabilize the neck.
do_not: move the person
scenarios.additional_info: Be aware of potential signs or symptoms before medical help arrives.

scenarios.title: Ischemic Stroke (Blood Clot FAST)
immediate_steps: Call EMS/9-1-1 immediately.
Check for signs of a stroke using the FAST acronym (FACE, ARM, TIME).
Perform the ABCs (airway, breathing, circulation)
do_not: attempt to give medication
scenarios.additional_info: Act quickly and accurately according to the FAST acronym.

scenarios.title: Brain Tumour
immediate_steps: Call EMS/9-1-1 immediately.
Apply a firm but gentle cervical collar to stabilize the neck.
Monitor breathing and circulatory status.
do_not: attempt to remove the person from the scene
scenarios.additional_info: Do not attempt to move the person unless they are in danger of injury

apply ice

move child's arm

Allow the chest to fully recoil after each compression.
do_not: Lean on the chest

scenarios.additional_info: Have someone call EMS/9-1-1 and get an AED.

do_not: Rubbing the injured eye

scenarios.title: Severe Burns on Hands
immediate_steps: Cool the burn with cool tap water for 10 minutes

scenarios.additional_info: Seek medical attention immediately if symptoms worsen

scenarios.title: Broken Arm in a Child

scenarios.title: Severe Allergic Reaction in a Child
immediate_steps: Call 911 or your local emergency number immediately
Administer epinephrine using an EpiPen if available
Lie the child on their back with their legs elevated
do_not: try to give epinephrine yourself without proper training

scenarios.title: Burns on the Face
immediate_steps: Run cool tap water over the burns for 10 minutes to reduce temperature and ease pain

Apply a topical antibiotic ointment and cover with a non-stick dressing

scenarios.title: Head Injury in an Elderly Person
immediate_steps: Call 911 or your local emergency number immediately
Turn the person onto their side to prevent choking on vomit
Loosen tight clothing around the neck
do_not: move the person excessively

scenarios.title: Inadequate Chest Compression Depth
immediate_steps: Check the compression depth to ensure it is at least 5 cm (about 2 in.)
Push steadily and evenly, avoiding excessive depths greater than 6 cm
Continue compressions as directed by the CPR protocol
when_to_seek_help: Cardiac arrest without adequate chest compression
do_not: Push too deeply or avoid compressing altogether
scenarios.additional_info: Proper compression depth is crucial for effective CPR

scenarios.title: CPR for a Pregnant Woman
immediate_steps: Start CPR with 30:2 ratio compressions and ventilations
Raise the woman's right hip to 7.5-10 cm using your body weight
Avoid interruptions and minimize energy expenditure
do_not: rocking back and forth during compressions
scenarios.additional_info: Minimize interruptions and focus on effective chest compressions

scenarios.title: Vomiting During CPR
immediate_steps: Turn the person onto their side, facing you
Quickly wipe the person's mouth clean
Reposition the person on their back and continue with CPR
do_not: repositioning hands after every compression
scenarios.additional_info: Minimize interruptions to chest compressions

scenarios.title: Aspiration During CPR
immediate_steps: Pause CPR and assess the person's ABCs
Check for aspiration and provide ventilations only until chest starts to rise
Avoid excessive breathing
do_not: prolonged ventilation
scenarios.additional_info: Avoid lengthy ventilation steps

scenarios.title: Spinal Injury from Fall
immediate_steps: Stay calm and still
Place a towel or blanket under the injured spine
Do not move the person unless they are in immediate danger
do_not: lift heavy objects
try to move the person

scenarios.title: Mouth Injury While Rescuing from Cardiac Arrest
immediate_steps: Tilt the person's head back and breathe into their nose.
Block or close their mouth with your hand to stop air from escaping.
Check for signs of cardiac arrest
do_not: try to open the person's mouth
scenarios.additional_info: Use a head-tilt/chin-lift technique instead.

scenarios.title: Automated External Defibrillation for V-fib
immediate_steps: Turn on the AED and follow its instructions.
Remove any jewelry or clothing that may interfere with the device.
Place the electrodes on the person's chest as directed by the device.
do_not: use manual defibrillation techniques
scenarios.additional_info: Follow the AED's instructions for correct placement and use.

scenarios.title: Automated External Defibrillation for V-tach
immediate_steps: Turn on the AED and follow its instructions.
Remove any jewelry or clothing that may interfere with the device.
Press the button to analyze the person's heart rhythm.
do_not: use manual defibrillation techniques
scenarios.additional_info: Follow the AED's instructions for correct placement and use.

scenarios.title: AED Use on Infant with Pacemaker
immediate_steps: Position AED pads according to diagram
Place one pad anterior and one posterior if space is insufficient
Turn on device and follow prompts

scenarios.title: AED Use on Child (1-8 years)
immediate_steps: Position AED pads according to diagram
Use child AED pads if available, adult otherwise

scenarios.title: Electrical Shock from AED
immediate_steps: Stand clear and say 'I'm clear, you're clear, everybody's clear.'
Ensure that no one is touching the person (as they can be shocked too)
Press the 'shock' button if prompted by the AED
do_not: Touching the person while using the AED

scenarios.title: Burns from Electrical Shock
immediate_steps: Stop CPR and turn off the AED if signs of life are observed
Remove any clothing or jewelry near the burn site
Apply a cooling method (e.g., cool water, not ice)
do_not: Applying heat to the burn
scenarios.additional_info: Seek medical attention immediately

scenarios.title: Muscle Cramps during CPR
immediate_steps: Continue CPR as normal
Check for airway patency and ensure proper ventilation
Adjust compression depth or rate if necessary
do_not: Stopping CPR without medical help
scenarios.additional_info: Monitor the person's condition closely

scenarios.title: AED Failure During CPR
immediate_steps: Stop CPR immediately
Call EMS/9-1-1 and report the issue
Turn off the AED and remove it from service
do_not: Resuming CPR without addressing the issue
scenarios.additional_info: Continue chest compressions until EMS arrives

scenarios.title: Cardiac Arrest with No Oxygenation

do_not: Pausing CPR to check for pulse
scenarios.additional_info: Use AED pads and follow manufacturer's instructions

scenarios.title: AED Battery Expiration
immediate_steps: Turn off the AED and remove it from service

Restock AED pads and ensure proper storage
do_not: Ignoring the issue and continuing CPR
scenarios.additional_info: Notify EMS and inform other first responders

scenarios.additional_info: Seek medical attention if symptoms worsen or don't improve

scenarios.title: Sunburn Prevention and Care
immediate_steps: Apply sunscreen with SPF 30 or higher 15-30 minutes before going outdoors.
Reapply every 2 hours, after being in water, and after sweating.
Cover the person with a blanket if they complain of feeling cold.
do_not: reapply sunscreen more than recommended
scenarios.additional_info: Limit exposure to direct sunlight during peak hours

scenarios.title: Superficial Burns
immediate_steps: Call EMS/9-1-1 if the burn is severe or covers a large area
Apply a topical ointment to help soothe and protect the skin
Cover the burn with a non-stick dressing to prevent further irritation
when_to_seek_help: burns on face, neck, hands, genitals
do_not: use ice or cold water to treat burns

scenarios.title: Thermal Burns
immediate_steps: Call EMS/9-1-1 immediately if the burn is severe or covers a large area
Apply a topical ointment to help soothe and protect the skin
Cover the burn with a non-stick dressing to prevent further irritation
when_to_seek_help: burns on face, neck, hands, genitals
do_not: use ice or cold water to treat burns

scenarios.title: Chemical Burns
immediate_steps: Call EMS/9-1-1 immediately if the burn is severe or covers a large area
Flush the affected area with cool water for 15-20 minutes
Remove contaminated clothing and jewelry
when_to_seek_help: burns on face, neck, hands, genitals
do_not: use ice or cold water to treat burns

scenarios.title: Chemical Burn
symptoms: Pain (may not be present in the most severely burned areas due to nerve damage)
immediate_steps: Wear protective equipment to avoid being burned yourself.
Brush dry chemicals off the person's skin before flushing with water.
Flush the affected area with large amounts of cool running water for at least 15 minutes, or until EMS personnel arrive.
do_not: Remove jewellery and clothing from the burn site without assistance
scenarios.additional_info: Refer to the appropriate Material Safety Data Sheet (MSDS) for additional first aid measures, if it is available.

scenarios.title: Full Thickness Burn
symptoms: Pain (may not be present in the most severely burned areas due to nerve damage)
immediate_steps: Wear protective equipment to avoid being burned yourself.
Remove jewellery and clothing from the burn site, but do not attempt to move anything that is stuck to the skin.
Once it is cool, cover the burn loosely with a dry, sterile dressing, preferably non-stick gauze.
do_not: Remove jewellery and clothing from the burn site without assistance
scenarios.additional_info: Have the person lie down until EMS personnel arrive.

scenarios.title: Wet Chemical Burn
symptoms: Pain (may not be present in the most severely burned areas due to nerve damage)
immediate_steps: Wear protective equipment to avoid being burned yourself.
Flush the affected area with large amounts of cool running water for at least 15 minutes, or until EMS personnel arrive.
Remove clothing that is wet or contaminated by the chemical.
do_not: Move anything that is stuck to the skin without assistance
scenarios.additional_info: Refer to the appropriate Material Safety Data Sheet (MSDS) for additional first aid measures, if it is available.

scenarios.title: Electrical Burns from Lightning Strike
immediate_steps: Call emergency services immediately
Check the person's airway, breathing, and circulation (ABCs)
Apply a burn dressing to prevent further injury
do_not: Pull clothes over burned area
Use absorbent cotton

scenarios.title: Radiation Burns from Sun Exposure
immediate_steps: Apply a cool compress to reduce heat and inflammation
Use topical creams or gels to soothe the skin
Seek shade and rest to avoid further sun exposure
do_not: Use tanning bed or UV light therapy

scenarios.title: Bruise from Trauma
immediate_steps: Apply an ice pack to reduce swelling and pain
Use compression bandages to support the affected area
Elevate the injured limb above heart level
do_not: Scratch or pick at the bruise

scenarios.title: Electrical Burns from Contact with Live Wire
symptoms: Numbness or tingling in hands and feet
immediate_steps: Turn off the electrical source if possible
Apply a burn dressing to prevent further injury
Call emergency services immediately
do_not: Touch burned area with bare hands

scenarios.title: Foreign Object in the Nose
immediate_steps: Remove object if easily visible
Leave object for medical professional to remove
Prevent person from blowing nose
do_not: Attempt to dislodge object yourself
scenarios.additional_info: If the object cannot be removed, do not touch or manipulate it further

scenarios.title: Knocked-Out Tooth
immediate_steps: Call EMS/9-1-1
Apply gentle pressure to stop bleeding
Use a cold compress to reduce swelling
do_not: Attempt to dislodge tooth yourself
scenarios.additional_info: Knocked-out teeth can lead to infection and further complications if left untreated

scenarios.title: Tooth Knocked Out
immediate_steps: Control any bleeding
Carefully pick up the tooth by the crown
Get the person to a dentist as soon as possible
do_not: Pick up the tooth by the root

scenarios.title: Eye Injury from Foreign Object
immediate_steps: Wash the eye with water
Apply a clean cloth or gauze to the affected area
Seek medical help immediately
do_not: Touch the inside of the eyelids

scenarios.title: Eye Injury from Chemical Burns
immediate_steps: Flush the eye with water for 10-15 minutes
Remove any contact lenses
Seek medical help immediately
do_not: Use soap or other cleaning agents

scenarios.title: Eye Injury with Foreign Object
symptoms: Pain and irritation in the eye
immediate_steps: Try to remove the foreign object by having the person blink
Clean away any dirt around the eye and then gently flush with running water
If these steps do not remove the object, seek medical attention
scenarios.additional_info: An object that is not touching the eye itself may be removed with a moist cotton-tipped applicator.

scenarios.title: Eye Injury with Impaled Object
symptoms: Pain and irritation in the eye
immediate_steps: Have the person lie on his or her back and keep as still as possible
Stabilize the object with bulky dressings
Cover both eyes with gauze or another light material
when_to_seek_help: If these steps do not remove the object, seek medical attention
scenarios.additional_info: Provide comfort and reassurance until EMS personnel arrive.

scenarios.title: Flash Burned Eyes
immediate_steps: Cover the eyes with a cool, wet cloth.
Make sure the person gets medical attention.
Call EMS/9-1-1 and get an AED if there is blood or other fluid draining from the ear.
scenarios.additional_info: Seek immediate medical attention

scenarios.title: External Ear Wound
immediate_steps: Apply antibiotic ointment to the affected area.
Cover the ear with a clean dressing or bandage.
Monitor for signs of infection.
scenarios.additional_info: If infection symptoms occur, seek medical attention

scenarios.title: Foreign Object in Ear
immediate_steps: Tilt the head to the affected side, then gently tap the ear to loosen the object.
Attempt to grasp the object and pull it out.
Call EMS/9-1-1 if you can't remove the object.
scenarios.additional_info: If removal is not possible, do not attempt to remove

scenarios.title: Burned Ear
immediate_steps: Apply cool water to the affected area for 10-15 minutes.
Cover the ear with a clean dressing or bandage.
Monitor for signs of infection.
do_not: apply heat
use harsh soap
scenarios.additional_info: Seek medical attention if infection symptoms occur

scenarios.title: Shocked Person
immediate_steps: Lay the person down on their back in a comfortable position.
Loosen tight clothing around the neck and chest.
Call EMS/9-1-1 and start CPR if the person is not breathing.
scenarios.additional_info: Continue CPR until medical help arrives

scenarios.title: Ear Infection
immediate_steps: Apply a warm compress to the affected area.
Give the person over-the-counter pain medication as directed.
Monitor for signs of worsening infection.
scenarios.additional_info: Seek medical attention if symptoms worsen

scenarios.title: Ear Cut
immediate_steps: Apply gentle pressure to the cut with a clean cloth or gauze.
Clean the area with mild soap and water.
Monitor for signs of infection.
do_not: use harsh soap
pick at scabs
scenarios.additional_info: Seek medical attention if infection symptoms occur

scenarios.title: Impaled Object
immediate_steps: Call EMS/9-1-1.
Keep the person still and leave the object in place.
Use bulky dressings to stabilize the object.
do_not: Cut off circulation with bandages
scenarios.additional_info: An impaled object will be visibly protruding from the persons body.

scenarios.title: Chest Compression
immediate_steps: Call EMS/9-1-1.
Start chest compressions at a rate of 100-120 per minute.
Provide rescue breaths.
do_not: Use chest compression devices without proper training
scenarios.additional_info: Chest compressions can help maintain blood flow to the brain and other vital organs.

scenarios.title: Amputation with Partial Reattachment
immediate_steps: Apply direct pressure to control bleeding
Elevate the injured limb above heart level
Call EMS/9-1-1
scenarios.additional_info: Keep the amputated part cool and bagged.

scenarios.title: Bleeding from Cutting
immediate_steps: Apply direct pressure to control bleeding
Elevate the injured limb above heart level
Call EMS/9-1-1
scenarios.additional_info: If bleeding is severe, use a tourniquet if trained to do so.

scenarios.title: Open Wound or Fracture with Partially Detached Limb
immediate_steps: Immobilize the injured limb with a splint or sling
Apply direct pressure to control bleeding
Call EMS/9-1-1
scenarios.additional_info: Keep the amputated part cool and bagged.

scenarios.title: Crush Injury
immediate_steps: Call EMS/9-1-1
Apply a backboard if trapped under an object
Immobilize the affected area
do_not: Move the person without proper training and equipment
scenarios.additional_info: Check for airway obstruction

scenarios.title: Chest Injury (Pneumothorax)
immediate_steps: Call EMS/9-1-1
Apply a pressure dressing to the wound if present
Loosen tight clothing around the chest
do_not: Try to lift or move the person
scenarios.additional_info: Check for airway obstruction

scenarios.title: Chest Injury (Hemothorax)
immediate_steps: Call EMS/9-1-1
Apply a pressure dressing to the wound if present
Loosen tight clothing around the chest
do_not: Try to lift or move the person
scenarios.additional_info: Check for airway obstruction

scenarios.title: Difficulty Breathing After Penetrating Chest Injury
immediate_steps: Have the person rest in a comfortable position.
If the wound is bleeding profusely, apply pressure or gauze dressings may be necessary to stop the bleeding.
Call EMS/9-1-1 and get an AED.
do_not: Apply pressure on non-bleeding wounds
scenarios.additional_info: Avoid applying pressure on bleeding wounds, as this may worsen bleeding.

scenarios.title: Blunt Chest Injury
immediate_steps: Keep the person as still as possible
Give the person something bulky to hold against the chest
Call EMS/9-1-1
when_to_seek_help: bruising at the site of injury
pain, tenderness, or a tight feeling in the abdomen
do_not: move the person
scenarios.additional_info: Flail chest can also involve the sternum.

scenarios.title: Motor Vehicle Collision and Head Injury
scenarios.subcategory: Head Injuries from Motor Vehicle Collisions
immediate_steps: Keep the person calm and still
Remove any constrictive items such as jewelry or tight clothing
Call EMS/9-1-1
do_not: give anything to drink

scenarios.title: Broken Ribs with Difficulty Breathing
immediate_steps: Give the person something bulky to hold against the chest
Keep the person as still as possible
Call EMS/9-1-1
when_to_seek_help: organs possibly protruding from the abdomen
do_not: move the person
scenarios.additional_info: Flail chest can also involve the sternum.

scenarios.title: Abdominal Wound with Life-Threatening Internal Bleeding
symptoms: tenderness or a tight feeling in the abdomen
immediate_steps: Keep the person as still as possible
Call EMS/9-1-1 immediately
Apply firm pressure to the wound
when_to_seek_help: vomiting blood or coffee ground-like material
do_not: give anything to drink

scenarios.title: Organ Protrusion Due to Blasting
immediate_steps: Call EMS/9-1-1 and get an AED
Cover the protruding organs with moist, sterile dressings
Loosely cover the dressings with plastic, if available
do_not: Apply direct pressure or attempt to push organs back into abdomen
scenarios.additional_info: Monitor the person's condition frequently

scenarios.title: Pressure or Heat Injury from Blast
immediate_steps: Stop the burning process with cool water or a cold compress
Remove clothing and jewelry near the burned area
Apply a topical antibiotic ointment to prevent infection
do_not: Use hot water or ice to treat burns
scenarios.additional_info: Seek medical attention if symptoms worsen

scenarios.title: Flying Debris Injury from Blast
immediate_steps: Apply a tourniquet if the wound is above the knee
Cover the wound with a clean dressing to stop bleeding
Monitor for signs of shock and hypovolemic shock
do_not: Remove the shrapnel from the wound
scenarios.additional_info: Seek immediate medical attention if symptoms worsen

scenarios.title: Heat Stroke or Hypertension Due to Blast
immediate_steps: Move the person to a cool, shaded area and remove excess clothing
Loosen tight clothing around the neck and chest
Monitor for signs of shock and cardiac arrest
do_not: Administer cold water or ice packs without medical supervision
scenarios.additional_info: Call 911 immediately if symptoms worsen

scenarios.title: Head Injury from Falling
immediate_steps: Call 911
Clear airway
Stabilize neck and head
do_not: Move person with severe injury
scenarios.additional_info: May cause permanent damage

scenarios.title: Spinal Injury from Motor Vehicle Accident
immediate_steps: Call 911
Stabilize neck and spine
Immobilize affected area
when_to_seek_help: Loss of bladder or bowel control
do_not: Move person with suspected spinal injury
scenarios.additional_info: May cause paralysis or death

scenarios.title: Cervical Spine Injury from Fall
immediate_steps: Call 911
Clear airway
Stabilize neck and spine
when_to_seek_help: Loss of sensation or movement in affected area
do_not: Move person with suspected spinal injury
scenarios.additional_info: May cause quadriplegia

scenarios.title: Concussion from Blow to the Head
immediate_steps: Stop activity
Apply ice to affected area
Monitor for further symptoms
do_not: Take medication without medical advice
Resume strenuous activities
scenarios.additional_info: Concussions can be caused by a single blow to the head or repeated blows.

scenarios.title: Neck Spine Injury from Fall
immediate_steps: Apply ice to affected area
Stabilize spine with towel or cloth
Call emergency services
do_not: Move injured person excessively
Try to straighten spine
scenarios.additional_info: Neck and spinal injuries can be serious, so seek medical attention immediately.

scenarios.title: Electrocution from Lightning Strike
immediate_steps: Call emergency services immediately
Administer CPR if necessary
Avoid conduction through metal objects
do_not: Touch injured person with bare hands
Use electrical appliances on the victim
scenarios.additional_info: Electrocution can be fatal, so seek immediate medical attention.

scenarios.title: Diving Injury from Diving Head-First
immediate_steps: Apply ice to affected area
Monitor for breathing difficulties
Call emergency services
do_not: Conduct further activity
Try to move injured person excessively
scenarios.additional_info: Diving injuries can be serious, so seek medical attention if symptoms persist.

scenarios.title: Heavy External Bleeding from Head or Neck
immediate_steps: Apply firm and steady pressure to the wound
Elevate the injured area above heart level
Call 911 or your local emergency number
do_not: apply tourniquet unless trained to do so
scenarios.additional_info: Seek medical attention immediately if bleeding does not stop

scenarios.title: Drowning from Diving
immediate_steps: Check the person's airway and begin CPR if not breathing
Start rescue breaths if trained to do so
Call 911 or your local emergency number
do_not: try to revive the person unless trained to do so
scenarios.additional_info: Seek medical attention immediately after rescue efforts cease

scenarios.title: Seizure from Head Injury
immediate_steps: Clear the person's airway and begin CPR if not breathing
Start rescue breaths if trained to do so
Call 911 or your local emergency number
do_not: try to revive the person unless trained to do so
scenarios.additional_info: Seek medical attention immediately after seizure ends

If blood or other fluid is in the ear canal or draining from the ear:
Let the ear drain. Do not apply direct pressure. Do not move
Cover the ear loosely with a sterile dressing.

If you can see chest unresponsive and breathing,

scenarios.title: Concussion from Blunt Force
immediate_steps: Open airway and start CPR if not breathing
Call 911 and stay on the line
Keep person still and upright
Do not move unless absolutely necessary
do_not: Move the person more than necessary
Remove the helmet or protective gear without checking for injuries first
scenarios.additional_info: A concussion can result from even a seemingly minor bump, blow, or jolt.

scenarios.title: Head and Neck Injury from Whiplash
immediate_steps: Call 911 and stay on the line
Apply a firm but gentle cervical collar to stabilize the neck
Keep person still and upright
Do not move unless absolutely necessary
when_to_seek_help: Numbness or tingling in arms or legs
do_not: Remove the cervical collar without medical supervision
Drive the person to the hospital yourself
scenarios.additional_info: Whiplash can cause serious injuries, including fractures and soft tissue damage.

scenarios.title: Concussion from Explosion
immediate_steps: Open airway and start CPR if not breathing
Call 911 and stay on the line
Keep person still and upright
Do not move unless absolutely necessary
do_not: Move the person more than necessary
Remove the helmet or protective gear without checking for injuries first
scenarios.additional_info: An explosion can cause concussions due to the force and shockwave generated.

scenarios.title: Seizure After Fall
immediate_steps: Call emergency services immediately
Clear the area around the person to prevent further injury
Turn the person onto their side if they are unconscious
do_not: Apply ice or cold compresses
scenarios.additional_info: Monitor the person's airway, breathing, and circulation (ABCs)

scenarios.title: Chest Pain from Cardiac Arrest
immediate_steps: Call emergency services immediately
Start CPR if trained to do so
Use an automated external defibrillator (AED) if available
do_not: Give aspirin or other medications
scenarios.additional_info: Check the person's airway, breathing, and circulation (ABCs)

scenarios.title: Headache from Concussion
immediate_steps: Stay calm and rest
Apply ice packs to the head and neck
Take over-the-counter pain medication like acetaminophen or ibuprofen if prescribed by a doctor
do_not: Try to return to normal activities immediately
scenarios.additional_info: Monitor for signs of worsening symptoms

scenarios.title: Broken Bone from Fall
immediate_steps: Stop activity and rest the injured area
Apply an ice pack to reduce swelling
Use crutches or a splint if necessary
do_not: Move the person excessively
scenarios.additional_info: Monitor for signs of infection

scenarios.title: Repeated Vomiting After Concussion
immediate_steps: Stop the activity immediately
Offer water or clear liquids
Have the person rest and sit down
Do not give medication without consulting a doctor
when_to_seek_help: Loss of responsiveness of any duration
do_not: Continue participating in physical activities
scenarios.additional_info: Seek medical attention if the person shows signs of worsening symptoms

scenarios.title: Vision Changes After Concussion
symptoms: Vision and ocular changes (e.g., double vision, dilated pupils, or unequal pupil size)
immediate_steps: Have the person sit in a quiet, dark room
Remove any eyewear or glasses
Monitor for any worsening symptoms
when_to_seek_help: Loss of responsiveness of any duration
do_not: Continue participating in activities that may exacerbate the condition
scenarios.additional_info: Seek medical attention if vision changes persist

scenarios.title: Seizures After Concussion
immediate_steps: Call 911 or seek immediate medical help
Position the person in a safe position to prevent injury
Do not attempt to restrain the person
when_to_seek_help: Loss of responsiveness of any duration
do_not: Continue participating in activities that may exacerbate the condition
scenarios.additional_info: Seek immediate medical attention if seizures occur

scenarios.title: Difficulty with Speech After Concussion
immediate_steps: Have the person rest and sit down
Offer clear liquids
Monitor for any worsening symptoms
when_to_seek_help: Loss of responsiveness of any duration
do_not: Continue participating in activities that may exacerbate the condition
scenarios.additional_info: Seek medical attention if speech difficulties persist

scenarios.title: Concussion with Confusion
immediate_steps: Place the person on their side to prevent choking
Loosen tight clothing around the neck
Clear the area of any objects that could cause injury
do_not: giving medication without medical supervision
scenarios.additional_info: Monitor vital signs and seek immediate medical attention if symptoms worsen

scenarios.title: Shaken Baby Syndrome (SBS)
immediate_steps: Place the baby face-up in a safe place and let them cry
Call emergency services immediately
Do not attempt to console or handle the baby
do_not: shaking the baby to soothe them
scenarios.additional_info: Seek medical attention immediately if you suspect SBS

scenarios.title: Severe Bleeding in Head or Neck
immediate_steps: Call emergency services immediately
Apply pressure to the wound with a clean cloth or gauze
Stabilize the person's head and neck
do_not: moving the person unless necessary
scenarios.additional_info: Seek medical attention immediately for severe bleeding

scenarios.title: Concussion with Loss of Consciousness
immediate_steps: Place the person on their side to prevent choking
Loosen tight clothing around the neck
Clear the area of any objects that could cause injury
do_not: giving medication without medical supervision
scenarios.additional_info: Seek immediate medical attention for loss of consciousness

scenarios.title: Bruising around the Eyes
immediate_steps: Apply cold compress
Elevate the injured area
Monitor for swelling
do_not: Press or rub the bruise

scenarios.title: Bleeding from Nose and Ears
immediate_steps: Apply pressure to the affected area
Keep the head elevated
Monitor for bleeding
do_not: Insert objects into the nose or ear

scenarios.title: Vomiting and Irritability
immediate_steps: Offer a small amount of water or clear broth
Keep the individual calm and comfortable
Monitor for further symptoms
do_not: Give medication without consulting a doctor

scenarios.title: Unexplained Bruising
immediate_steps: Apply cold compress
Elevate the injured area
Monitor for swelling
do_not: Press or rub the bruise

scenarios.title: Seizures in a Baby
immediate_steps: Clear the airway
Check for breathing and pulse
Call EMS/9-1-1 immediately
do_not: Try to restrain or comfort the baby during a seizure

scenarios.title: Fracture - Open
immediate_steps: Apply a clean, sterile dressing to the wound
Immobilize the affected limb using a splint or sling
Elevate the injured area above heart level
do_not: Remove any jewelry from the affected area until medical help arrives
Apply ice to the wound
scenarios.additional_info: Watch for signs of infection, such as increased redness or swelling.

scenarios.title: Muscle Cramp - Severe
immediate_steps: Stretch the affected muscle to relieve tension
Apply cold compresses or ice packs to reduce swelling
Change positions to help relieve pressure
do_not: Apply heat to the area
Bend or twist the affected joint
scenarios.additional_info: If symptoms persist, seek medical attention.

scenarios.title: Dislocation - Knee
immediate_steps: Apply a splint or sling to immobilize the affected leg
Reduce the dislocation using gentle maneuvers
Elevate the injured area above heart level
do_not: Apply ice to the wound
Bend or twist the affected joint
scenarios.additional_info: Seek medical attention immediately for proper treatment.

scenarios.title: Sprain - Ankle
immediate_steps: Apply ice to the affected area
Elevate the injured area above heart level
Use a compression bandage to reduce swelling
do_not: Remove any jewelry from the affected area until medical help arrives
Bend or twist the affected joint
scenarios.additional_info: Gradually return to activities, avoiding strenuous exercise.

scenarios.title: Child Seatbelt Injury
immediate_steps: Apply cold compress to reduce swelling
Elevate injured area above heart level
Call 9-1-1 immediately
do_not: Try to move the child
scenarios.additional_info: Keep child calm and comfortable

scenarios.title: Falling Elderly Person
symptoms: The person may be anxious and in a lot of pain
immediate_steps: Keep the person comfortable and prevent further injury
Provide good lighting
Call 9-1-1 immediately
do_not: Perform traction or any other manipulation

Move the person away from the poison source

scenarios.title: Giant Hogweed Exposure

Remove contaminated clothing
Apply a topical antibiotic ointment

scenarios.title: Eye Irritation from Wild Parsnip Sap
immediate_steps: Rinse eyes thoroughly with water for at least 15 minutes
Apply a warm compress to the affected eye
Visit an urgent care center or hospital
do_not: Sharing contaminated items
scenarios.additional_info: Wild parsnip sap can cause severe eye irritation, so seek medical attention immediately if symptoms occur

scenarios.title: Giant Hogweed Burn
immediate_steps: Cool the burn with cool water for 10-15 minutes
Apply a topical antibiotic ointment
Cover the burn with a non-stick dressing

scenarios.title: Wild Parsnip Allergic Reaction

Wear loose clothing to reduce irritation
do_not: Sharing contaminated items

scenarios.title: Stimulant Overdose
symptoms: Continuous pain or pressure in the chest or abdomen
immediate_steps: Call EMS/9-1-1 and get an AED if you suspect a drug overdose
Administer CPR if person is unresponsive
Apply firm, gentle support to airway if possible
when_to_seek_help: Changes in breathing or difficulty breathing
do_not: Give the person anything to eat or drink
scenarios.additional_info: Monitor vital signs closely

scenarios.title: Hallucinogen Exposure
symptoms: Changes in behaviour (e.g., aggression or fear)
immediate_steps: Try to keep the person calm and safe
Provide a comfortable environment with minimal stimulation
Call Poison Control Centre for guidance
when_to_seek_help: Changes in behaviour (e.g., aggression or fear)
do_not: Give the person any medication without consulting a medical professional
scenarios.additional_info: Do not attempt to induce vomiting

scenarios.title: Designer Drug Overdose
immediate_steps: Call EMS/9-1-1 immediately if you suspect a designer drug overdose
Administer CPR if person is unresponsive
Provide information about the substance taken to EMS personnel or Poison Control Centre
do_not: Give the person anything to eat or drink
scenarios.additional_info: Be prepared for rapid changes in symptoms

scenarios.title: Alcohol Poisoning
immediate_steps: Administer naloxone according to training instructions
Monitor the person's vital signs and provide continual care until EMS personnel arrive
do_not: Administer naloxone alone without professional medical care
scenarios.additional_info: Use of naloxone is an effective lifesaving treatment

scenarios.title: Wild Animal Bites
immediate_steps: Call your local animal control department if the animal is wild or a stray.
Do not try to capture the animal.
Try to get the person safely away from the animal.
when_to_seek_help: blue-tinged skin or skin that is paler than normal

scenarios.title: Animal Bites (Moderate)
immediate_steps: Control any bleeding.
Wash the wound thoroughly with clean water, ideally by running it under a tap.
Apply antibiotic ointment or cream to the wound if there are no known allergies or sensitivities.
do_not: try to capture the animal

scenarios.title: Animal Bites (Severe)
immediate_steps: Call EMS/9-1-1 for life-threatening bleeding.
Cover the wound with a dressing or bandage.
Carefully monitor the person until medical help arrives.
when_to_seek_help: blue-tinged skin or skin that is paler than normal

scenarios.title: Animal Stings
immediate_steps: Wash the wound thoroughly with clean water, ideally by running it under a tap.

Provide wound care

scenarios.title: Anaphylaxis from Insect Sting

Administer epinephrine using an EpiPen
Provide oxygen if necessary
do_not: Use antihistamines without consulting a doctor first
scenarios.additional_info: Anaphylaxis can be life-threatening if not treated promptly

Keep the affected limb below heart level
Do not move the person

Use ice or heat on the wound

scenarios.title: Snake Bite: Copperhead
immediate_steps: Remove any constrictive clothing or jewelry near the bite area
Keep the affected limb below heart level
Clean the wound with soap and water
do_not: Apply a tourniquet
Use ice on the wound
scenarios.additional_info: Monitor for signs of renal failure

scenarios.title: Snake Bite: Massasauga Rattlesnake
immediate_steps: Call 911 or your local emergency number immediately
Keep the person calm and still
Do not attempt to remove any constrictive clothing or jewelry near the bite area
do_not: Apply a tourniquet
Use ice on the wound

scenarios.title: Snake Bite with Localized Redness

Cover the bite with a clean, dry dressing
do_not: Attempt to capture or handle the snake

Wash the wound with water

scenarios.additional_info: Seek medical attention immediately

scenarios.title: Confused Child
immediate_steps: Check the child's airway, breathing, and circulation (ABCs)
Call for emergency assistance if unresponsive
Provide a pacifier or bottle if child is crying and unable to breathe

scenarios.title: Severe Vomiting in Child
immediate_steps: Call emergency services if child is unconscious or not breathing
Position the child on their side to prevent choking
Keep the child calm and comfortable until help arrives

scenarios.title: Bite from a Child's Pet
immediate_steps: Wash the wound with soap and water
Apply a clean bandage to prevent infection
Monitor for signs of infection, such as redness or increased swelling
do_not: apply antibiotic ointment without consulting a doctor

scenarios.title: Child with Severe Eye Injury
symptoms: Discharge in his or her eyes
immediate_steps: Stop any further injury
Clean the eye with cool water
Apply an antibiotic ointment
do_not: Touch or rub the injured eye
scenarios.additional_info: Seek immediate medical help for severe eye injuries

scenarios.title: Child with Respiratory Distress
immediate_steps: Call 911 or your local emergency number
Place the child on their back in a comfortable position
Administer oxygen if available
do_not: Try to breathe for the child
scenarios.additional_info: Respiratory distress is a medical emergency

scenarios.title: Child with Seizure
symptoms: Tendency to pull, cup, or poke his or her ears
immediate_steps: Clear the child's airway
Position the child on their side in a recovery position
Stop any seizure activity
when_to_seek_help: The seizure lasts longer than 5 minutes
do_not: Try to restrain or move the child during a seizure
scenarios.additional_info: Seizures can be a sign of a serious medical condition
