scenarios.title: Minor Eczema Rash
immediate_steps: Apply a cool compress to reduce itching
Take an oral antihistamine for relief
Use a topical cream or ointment to soothe the skin
do_not: Scratch the affected area
scenarios.additional_info: Seek medical attention if symptoms worsen or do not improve with treatment

scenarios.title: Minor Impetigo Outbreak
symptoms: Clusters of pimples filled with straw-coloured fluid
immediate_steps: Wash the infected area with soap and water
Clean and disinfect any contaminated items or surfaces
Use a topical antibiotic ointment to treat mild cases
do_not: Share personal care items with others who have impetigo
scenarios.additional_info: Seek medical attention if symptoms worsen or do not improve with treatment

scenarios.title: Severe Impetigo Infection
symptoms: Inflamed skin around the mouth and nose
Crusting of the skin with a foul odor
immediate_steps: Seek immediate medical attention
Apply antibiotic ointment to the affected area
Clean and disinfect any contaminated items or surfaces
when_to_seek_help: Systemic symptoms such as fever, chills, or swollen lymph nodes
do_not: Use homemade remedies to treat impetigo
scenarios.additional_info: Do not return to childcare or school until prescribed medication has been taken for at least one full day

scenarios.title: Ringworm Treatment
symptoms: Red, scaling rings on the skin
immediate_steps: Clean the area with mild soap and water twice a day
Apply topical antifungal medication as directed by doctor
Wash hands thoroughly after treatment
do_not: Return to child care setting or school before 48 hours of treatment
scenarios.additional_info: Fungal infection is contagious, avoid close contact with others until treated.

scenarios.title: Scabies Treatment
symptoms: Many tiny blisters, scratch marks, and scaly crusts
immediate_steps: Bathe the child prior to medication application
Apply prescribed lotion all over affected skin
Wash hands thoroughly after treatment
do_not: Return to child care setting or school until treated and symptoms have resolved
scenarios.additional_info: Scabies is contagious, treat entire household at the same time.

scenarios.title: Heat Rash in Children
immediate_steps: Pat the skin dry to avoid rubbing
Dress the child or baby in layers, and remove layers as necessary
Replace wet or sweaty clothing immediately
do_not: irritability
scenarios.additional_info: Not contagious

scenarios.title: Prickly Heat Rash
immediate_steps: Pat the skin dry to avoid rubbing
Dress the child or baby in layers, and remove layers as necessary
Replace wet or sweaty clothing immediately
do_not: rubbing the skin
scenarios.additional_info: Not contagious

scenarios.title: Diaper Rash with Yeast Infection
symptoms: red, scalded appearance that does not fade
immediate_steps: Wash and dry the area well
Expose the area to the air
Change diapers often
when_to_seek_help: rash does not clear up within 48 hours
do_not: use non-prescription ointment without consulting a doctor
scenarios.additional_info: May be contagious

scenarios.title: Scalded Skin
immediate_steps: Cool the burn with cool tap water for 10 minutes
Apply a topical antibiotic ointment and cover with non-stick dressing
Monitor for signs of infection
when_to_seek_help: burn covers more than 10% body surface area
burns are deep or have white tissue
do_not: break blisters

scenarios.title: Diaper Rash without Yeast Infection
immediate_steps: Wash and dry the area well
Expose the area to the air
Change diapers often
do_not: use non-prescription ointment without consulting a doctor

scenarios.title: Head Lice Infestation
immediate_steps: Wash the child's hair with medicated shampoo
Comb out live lice and nits
Disinfect all clothing and bedding
do_not: Share brushes and combs
Allow children to share headgear
scenarios.additional_info: Treatment may need to be repeated in 72 hours

scenarios.title: Scalp Pustules Due to Lice
immediate_steps: Clean and disinfect affected area with hot water
Apply antibiotic ointment
Cover affected area with a bandage
do_not: Share personal items
Allow children to return to school before 72 hours
scenarios.additional_info: May require further treatment from a doctor

Elevate the injured leg above the level of the heart
Use over-the-counter pain medication as directed
do_not: move the child excessively
scenarios.additional_info: Monitor for signs of infection, such as redness and warmth around the wound

scenarios.title: Adult Stroke
symptoms: weakness or numbness in the face
immediate_steps: Call 911 immediately if you observe any of these symptoms
Place the person on their side to prevent choking
Loosen tight clothing around the neck
do_not: try to revive the person yourself
scenarios.additional_info: Do not attempt to drive the person to the hospital, as this can worsen the injury

scenarios.title: Adult Sprain Injury
immediate_steps: Apply ice to the affected area for 15-20 minutes, three times a day
Elevate the injured limb above the level of the heart
Use over-the-counter pain medication as directed
do_not: move around excessively
scenarios.additional_info: Monitor for signs of infection, such as redness and warmth around the wound

scenarios.title: Burn Wound
immediate_steps: Cool the burn with cool tap water for 10-15 minutes
Remove any clothing or jewelry near the burned area
Apply a topical antibiotic ointment
do_not: use ice or ice water on the burn
scenarios.additional_info: Do not break any blisters, as this can lead to infection

scenarios.title: Bite/ Sting Injury
immediate_steps: Wash the wound with soap and water
Apply an antibiotic ointment
Cover the wound with a bandage
do_not: try to suck out any venom or debris from the wound
scenarios.additional_info: Monitor for signs of infection, such as increased redness and swelling

scenarios.title: Tuberculosis (TB) Symptoms
immediate_steps: Seek medical attention immediately if you experience any of these symptoms
Avoid close contact with others to prevent transmission
Take medication as directed by your healthcare provider
do_not: try to treat yourself for TB at home
scenarios.additional_info: Do not hesitate to seek medical attention if you are experiencing any of these symptoms

scenarios.title: Severe Bee Sting
immediate_steps: Administer epinephrine
Call emergency services
Remove stinger
Apply a cold compress
do_not: Rub the affected area with your hands
scenarios.additional_info: If you have a history of allergies, be prepared for an emergency response

scenarios.title: Rattlesnake Bite
immediate_steps: Stay calm
Keep the affected limb below heart level
Remove any constrictive items
Do not attempt to suck out the venom
when_to_seek_help: Symptoms worsen or you experience difficulty breathing
do_not: Use tourniquets or ice packs
scenarios.additional_info: Seek medical attention immediately

scenarios.title: Poison Oak Rash
immediate_steps: Wash the affected area with soap and water
Apply calamine lotion or hydrocortisone cream
Avoid scratching
when_to_seek_help: Symptoms worsen or you experience difficulty breathing
do_not: Use harsh soaps or ointments
scenarios.additional_info: Prevent future exposure by avoiding areas with poison oak

scenarios.title: Bee Sting Allergy
immediate_steps: Administer epinephrine
Call emergency services
Lie down and elevate legs
do_not: Rub the affected area with your hands
scenarios.additional_info: Have an EpiPen or other emergency medication on hand

scenarios.title: Burns from Chemical Exposure
immediate_steps: Remove contaminated clothing and jewelry
Flush eyes with water for 15 minutes
Inhale fresh air
when_to_seek_help: Symptoms worsen or you experience difficulty breathing
do_not: Use water that may be contaminated
scenarios.additional_info: Seek medical attention immediately

scenarios.title: Snake Bites
immediate_steps: Remove any constricting items (jewelry, watches) from the affected area
Keep the affected limb below heart level
Clean and bandage the bite with sterile materials
when_to_seek_help: signs of systemic toxicity (nausea, vomiting, difficulty breathing) or severe pain
do_not: Using ice or heat on the wound without medical supervision
scenarios.additional_info: Signs of envenoming include numbness, tingling, or respiratory distress

scenarios.title: Bleeding from a Cut
immediate_steps: Hold continuous direct pressure on the wound until help arrives.
Elevate the injured person's legs above their heart if possible.
Call 911 or your local emergency services immediately.
when_to_seek_help: Severe bleeding that won't stop after 15-20 minutes of first aid
do_not: Remove an object embedded in the body
scenarios.additional_info: Keep a clean and sterile environment

scenarios.title: Bleeding from a Nosebleed
immediate_steps: Pinch the nostrils shut and apply gentle pressure to the nostril for 5-10 minutes.
Use saline wash can to clear out debris or dirt from the wound without touching it.
Elevate the injured person's head with an extra pillow if possible.
do_not: Breathe through the nose
Try to suck out the blood

scenarios.title: Bleeding from a Puncture Wound
immediate_steps: Apply clean and sterile bandages to the wound.
Hold continuous direct pressure on the wound until help arrives.
Elevate the injured person's legs above their heart if possible.
do_not: Remove an object embedded in the body

scenarios.title: Abdominal Wound
immediate_steps: Apply clean and sterile bandages to the wound.
Hold continuous direct pressure on the wound until help arrives.
Call 911 or your local emergency services immediately.
do_not: Try to remove an object embedded in the body

scenarios.title: Burned Finger by Hot Liquid
immediate_steps: Remove constrictive items like rings, watches, and bracelets
Cover the burn area with a clean, cool, moist bandage
Raise the hand above the level of the heart
do_not: Apply ice
Blow on the burn
scenarios.additional_info: Run cool water over your finger or hand for 10 to 15 minutes after flushing the burn.

scenarios.title: Burned Hand by Steam
immediate_steps: Remove constrictive items like rings, watches, and bracelets
Cover the burn area with a clean, cool, moist bandage
Raise the hand above the level of the heart
do_not: Apply ice
Blow on the burn

scenarios.title: Defibrillator Shock
immediate_steps: Turn on the AED and follow the voice prompts.
Remove all clothing and jewelry covering the chest of the person in need of help.
Peel away the backing from the pads and attach them to the persons bare chest following the illustration on the pads.
do_not: Touching the person while the AED is analyzing
scenarios.additional_info: Continue CPR until emergency medical personnel arrive.

scenarios.title: First-Degree Burn on Face
immediate_steps: Soak the burn in cool water for five minutes or longer
Take acetaminophen or ibuprofen for pain relief
Apply lidocaine (an anesthetic) with aloe vera gel or cream to soothe the skin
do_not: Use ice, as this may make the damage worse

scenarios.title: Chemical Burn to Hands
immediate_steps: Remove contaminated clothing and jewelry
Flush the area with cool water for 15 minutes or longer
Seek emergency medical treatment
when_to_seek_help: If the burn affects a widespread area
scenarios.additional_info: Chemical burns warrant immediate medical attention.

scenarios.title: Second-Degree Burn on Knee
immediate_steps: Soak the wound in cool water for 15 minutes or longer
Apply antibiotic cream to blisters
Cover with a loose bandage
when_to_seek_help: If the burn affects a widespread area

scenarios.title: Scalding Burn on Ankle
immediate_steps: Soak the burn in cool water for five minutes or longer
Take acetaminophen or ibuprofen for pain relief
Apply lidocaine (an anesthetic) with aloe vera gel or cream to soothe the skin
do_not: Use ice, as this may make the damage worse

scenarios.title: Electrical Burn to Forearm
immediate_steps: Remove any constrictive clothing or jewelry
Apply a non-stick dressing and keep the area clean
Seek emergency medical treatment
when_to_seek_help: If the burn affects a widespread area

scenarios.title: Fourth-Degree Burn to Spine
immediate_steps: Call 911 or your local emergency number immediately
Provide as much information as possible about the burn
Stay with the person and provide comfort until medical help arrives
when_to_seek_help: Always seek immediate medical attention for fourth-degree burns

scenarios.title: Fainting in Hot Weather
immediate_steps: Turn the person onto their back and elevate their legs about 12 inches
Loosen tight clothing and remove shoes and socks
Keep the person calm and still until help arrives

scenarios.title: Unconscious Person with Possible Airway Obstruction
immediate_steps: Place the person on their left side and lift their head slightly with one hand
Tilt their head back and use your other hand to tilt their chin up
Use your fingers to carefully open their airway

scenarios.title: Babysitting in Case of Seizure
immediate_steps: Clear the area around the baby and make sure they are on their side
Loosen any tight clothing around their neck
Check for breathing and pulse, then call for help

scenarios.title: Unconscious Person with Spinal Injury
immediate_steps: Do not move the person unless absolutely necessary
Call for emergency medical help and wait for professionals to arrive
Do not attempt to immobilize their neck or spine
do_not: move the person

scenarios.title: Babysitting in Case of Diabetic Coma
immediate_steps: Call for emergency medical help and wait for professionals to arrive
Loosen any tight clothing around their neck
Check for breathing and pulse, then check the person's airway

scenarios.title: Tourniquet Application on Arm
immediate_steps: Tie a tourniquet tightly around the affected limb, above the wound.
Twist the windlass to tighten the bandage until it applies enough pressure to stop the bleeding.
Use tape or cloth to tie the windlass in place and secure the tourniquet.
do_not: remove the tourniquet without medical supervision

scenarios.title: Tourniquet Application on Leg
immediate_steps: Tie a tourniquet tightly around the affected limb, above the wound.
Twist the windlass to tighten the bandage until it applies enough pressure to stop the bleeding.
Use tape or cloth to tie the windlass in place and secure the tourniquet.
do_not: remove the tourniquet without medical supervision

scenarios.title: Tourniquet Application on Upper Calf
immediate_steps: Tie a tourniquet tightly around the affected limb, above the wound.
Twist the windlass to tighten the bandage until it applies enough pressure to stop the bleeding.
Use tape or cloth to tie the windlass in place and secure the tourniquet.
do_not: remove the tourniquet without medical supervision

scenarios.title: Applying Pressure Only
immediate_steps: Apply pressure directly to the wound with a cloth or bandage.
Elevate the injured limb above heart level if possible.
Monitor for signs of worsening bleeding.
do_not: use a tourniquet unless necessary
scenarios.additional_info: Check local guidelines for proper application

scenarios.title: Head or Torso Wounds
immediate_steps: Apply pressure directly to the wound with a cloth or bandage.
Call for emergency medical help immediately.
Keep the person calm and still.
do_not: use a tourniquet unless necessary
scenarios.additional_info: Do not attempt to remove a tourniquet

scenarios.title: Soft Tissue Injury
immediate_steps: Stop activity immediately and rest the affected area.
Apply ice to the affected area in 15-20 minute increments for 15-20 minutes, 3 times a day.
Elevate the injured area above the heart level to reduce swelling.
do_not: move around without assistance
scenarios.additional_info: Seek medical attention if symptoms worsen or do not improve with rest and ice

scenarios.title: Bleeding from a Small Cut
immediate_steps: Apply gentle pressure to the cut with a clean cloth or bandage for 5 minutes.
Elevate the injured area above the heart level to reduce swelling.
Clean and dress the wound with antibiotic ointment and a bandage.
do_not: apply tourniquet or tight bandage
scenarios.additional_info: Monitor for signs of infection, such as increased redness, swelling, or pus

scenarios.title: Severe Muscle Strain
immediate_steps: Stop activity immediately and rest the affected area.
Apply ice to the affected area in 15-20 minute increments for 15-20 minutes, 3 times a day.
Use compression bandages or wraps to support the injured muscle.
do_not: move around without assistance
scenarios.additional_info: Seek medical attention if symptoms worsen or do not improve with rest and ice

scenarios.title: Ankle Sprain
immediate_steps: Stop activity immediately and rest the affected area.
Apply ice to the affected area in 15-20 minute increments for 15-20 minutes, 3 times a day.
Use compression bandages or wraps to support the injured ankle.
do_not: move around without assistance
scenarios.additional_info: Monitor for signs of infection, such as increased redness, swelling, or pus

scenarios.title: Child Cardiac Arrest (Infant)
immediate_steps: Call 911 or local emergency services immediately
Start hands-only CPR with chest compressions
Continue CPR until medical help arrives
do_not: Perform traditional CPR with breaths if you're not trained

scenarios.title: Adult Heart Attack
immediate_steps: Call 911 or local emergency services immediately
Take the person to the hospital immediately if possible
Do not attempt CPR unless trained
do_not: Perform CPR unless you have training

scenarios.title: Child Drowning (No CPR Training)
immediate_steps: Begin CPR for 2 minutes before calling emergency services
Call 911 or local emergency services immediately
Continue CPR until medical help arrives
do_not: Do not attempt to revive the person unless trained in CPR

scenarios.title: First-Degree Burn from Sun Exposure
immediate_steps: Apply sunscreen with SPF 30 or higher
Take pain medication as needed
Stay hydrated
Rest in a shaded area
Monitor for signs of infection
do_not: Rub the affected area with sand or dirt
scenarios.additional_info: Avoid further sun exposure

scenarios.title: Scald Burn from Hot Liquid
immediate_steps: Run cool tap water over the burn for 10-15 minutes
Remove any clothing or jewelry that's in contact with the burn
Apply a topical antibiotic ointment and cover with a non-stick dressing
Monitor for signs of infection
do_not: Break blisters or scratch the affected area
scenarios.additional_info: Never apply ice or ice water to a burn

scenarios.title: Electrical Burn from Contact with Appliances
immediate_steps: Turn off the power source immediately
Call 911 or your local emergency number
Remove any clothing or jewelry that's in contact with the burn
Apply a non-stick dressing to the affected area
when_to_seek_help: Severe burns to the face, hands, or feet
do_not: Touch the electrical appliance or try to remove any metal objects from the body
scenarios.additional_info: Seek immediate medical attention

scenarios.title: Infection-Related First-Degree Burn
immediate_steps: Contact a healthcare professional for guidance
Apply an antibiotic ointment and cover with a non-stick dressing
Monitor for signs of infection
do_not: Use harsh soap or hydrogen peroxide on the affected area
scenarios.additional_info: Seek medical attention if symptoms persist or worsen

scenarios.title: Mild Cut or Scrape
immediate_steps: Wash your hands with antibacterial soap or use clean, disposable gloves.
Rinse the wound with clean water or a water/saline solution to flush away dirt and debris.
Clean the wound with water and a gentle antibacterial soap.
do_not: Apply antiseptic unless necessary
scenarios.additional_info: No need for medical attention

scenarios.title: Severe Burn or Deep Wound
immediate_steps: Call emergency services immediately.
Apply a cool compress to the affected area.
Do not break blisters.
do_not: Break blisters
Use harsh chemicals
scenarios.additional_info: Seek immediate medical attention

scenarios.title: Animal Bite or Scratch
immediate_steps: Wash the wound with soap and water.
Apply an antibiotic ointment.
Seek medical attention if symptoms worsen.
when_to_seek_help: Redness or swelling that won't go away
do_not: Touch or probe the wound
scenarios.additional_info: May require post-exposure prophylaxis

scenarios.title: Mouth Infection
immediate_steps: Use a saltwater rinse.
Take over-the-counter pain medication as directed.
See a doctor if symptoms worsen.
do_not: Try to push the object out of your mouth
scenarios.additional_info: May require prescription medication

scenarios.title: Severe Infection
immediate_steps: Call emergency services immediately.
Apply a warm compress to the affected area.
Do not delay seeking medical attention.
do_not: Use harsh chemicals
scenarios.additional_info: Seek immediate medical attention

scenarios.title: Eye Irritation from Chemical Spill
immediate_steps: Flush with water for 15 minutes
Remove contact lenses if present
Call Poison Control
do_not: Rub eyes
Apply ointment
scenarios.additional_info: Seek medical attention immediately.

scenarios.title: Deep Cut from Sharp Object
immediate_steps: Apply pressure with a clean cloth for 5 minutes
Elevate the injured limb above heart level
Call emergency services
do_not: Remove foreign object
Apply tourniquet
scenarios.additional_info: Monitor for signs of infection.

scenarios.title: Puncture Wound
immediate_steps: Apply pressure to the wound with a clean cloth for 5 minutes
Clean the wound with soap and water
Cover with a bandage
do_not: Touch or handle the wound with your bare hands

scenarios.title: Puncture Wound from Sharp Object
immediate_steps: Apply gentle pressure to the wound with a clean cloth or bandage for 5 minutes.
Clean the wound with soap and water, then apply an antibiotic ointment.
Cover the wound with a sterile dressing or bandage.
do_not: Press down on the wound
Use sharp objects to remove debris
scenarios.additional_info: Seek medical attention if symptoms worsen or don't improve within 24 hours.

scenarios.title: Allergic Reaction (Hives)
symptoms: Swelling of the face, lips, tongue, or throat
immediate_steps: Call 911 or your local emergency number immediately.
Administer epinephrine using an EpiPen if available.
Lie down in a comfortable position with your feet elevated.
do_not: Take antihistamines without medical supervision
Use a tourniquet
scenarios.additional_info: Seek immediate medical attention if symptoms worsen or don't improve within 30 minutes.

scenarios.title: Broken Bone (Adult)
immediate_steps: immobilize with splint or sling
apply cold compress
seek medical attention
do_not: move the limb

scenarios.title: Eye Injury from Chemical Spill
immediate_steps: Flush the affected eye with water for 15-20 minutes
Remove any contact lenses if present
Avoid rubbing or touching the eye
do_not: Try to neutralize the spill
scenarios.additional_info: Seek medical attention immediately if symptoms worsen

scenarios.title: Broken Bone (Wrist Fracture)
immediate_steps: Immobilize the affected arm using a splint or sling
Apply ice to reduce swelling
Elevate the affected arm above heart level
do_not: Try to move the arm or apply weight
scenarios.additional_info: Seek medical attention for proper immobilization and treatment

scenarios.title: Inhalation of Foreign Object
immediate_steps: Remove the object from the airway if possible
Turn the person onto their side to prevent choking
Start CPR if unresponsive
do_not: Administer medication without consulting a doctor first

scenarios.title: Strangulation by Necktie or Rope
immediate_steps: Clear the airway and begin CPR if unresponsive
Call 911 or your local emergency number immediately
Apply pressure to the neck to stop bleeding
do_not: Remove the object from the neck without proper training

scenarios.title: Email Field Required
immediate_steps: Check the email field for errors
Correct the error and try again
If still having issues, contact Mayo Clinic support

scenarios.title: Invalid Email Address
immediate_steps: Check the email address for typos or formatting errors
Correct the error and try again
If still having issues, contact Mayo Clinic support

scenarios.title: Email Subscription Error
immediate_steps: Retry the subscription process
If still having issues, contact Mayo Clinic support
Check for any firewall or antivirus software blocking the email

scenarios.title: Deep Cut
symptoms: Pain, swelling, and bruising at the wound site
immediate_steps: Stop the bleeding by applying firm pressure with a clean cloth or gauze
Elevate the injured limb above heart level
Clean the wound with soap and water
when_to_seek_help: Signs of infection, such as increased redness or swelling
The wound is deep or jagged
do_not: Try to close the wound with a bandage or tape
scenarios.additional_info: Avoid using harsh soap or cleansers on the wound

scenarios.title: Burn from Hot Beverage
immediate_steps: Flush with cool water for 10 minutes
Remove burning clothing
Apply topical antibiotic ointment
when_to_seek_help: Severe burns covering larger areas of the body
do_not: Break blisters or pick at skin
scenarios.additional_info: Monitor burn for signs of infection

scenarios.title: Bite/Wound from Dog
immediate_steps: Clean wound with soap and water
Apply antibiotic ointment
Cover wound with a bandage
when_to_seek_help: Signs of infection such as increased redness, swelling, or pus
do_not: Try to remove splinters or debris from the wound
scenarios.additional_info: Get rabies post-exposure prophylaxis if necessary

scenarios.title: Bites and Stings: Snake Envenoming
immediate_steps: Remove any constrictive clothing or jewelry
Keep the affected limb below heart level
Do not attempt to suck out venom
do_not: attempt to apply a tourniquet
scenarios.additional_info: Call emergency services immediately

scenarios.title: Chest Pain due to Heart Attack
immediate_steps: Call emergency services immediately
Administer aspirin (if advised by a medical professional)
Stay calm and lie down on the floor with your feet elevated
do_not: Drive to the hospital yourself
Take other medications without consulting a doctor

scenarios.title: Burned by Hot Surface
immediate_steps: Cool the burn with cool tap water for 10 minutes
Remove any clothing or jewelry near the burned area
Apply a topical antibiotic ointment
do_not: Using butter, oil, or other greasy substances on the burn
scenarios.additional_info: Monitor for signs of infection

scenarios.title: Eye Irritation
immediate_steps: Flush eyes with water for 10 minutes
Remove contact lenses if wearing
Avoid rubbing the affected eye
do_not: Apply any medication to the eye
scenarios.additional_info: Seek medical attention immediately if vision loss or severe pain occurs

scenarios.title: Burn (Third-Degree)
immediate_steps: Cool the burn with cool water for 10-15 minutes
Remove any clothing or jewelry near the burn area
Apply a topical antibiotic ointment to prevent infection
do_not: Use soap or other cleansers on the burn
scenarios.additional_info: Seek medical attention immediately for severe symptoms or prolonged recovery time

scenarios.title: Burn from Scalded Email
immediate_steps: Flush the burn with cool tap water for 10-15 minutes
Apply a topical antibiotic ointment and cover with a non-stick dressing
Monitor for signs of infection such as increased redness, swelling, or pus
do_not: Use hot water to clean the burn
Apply butter or oil to the affected area
scenarios.additional_info: Never use electrical appliances near open flames or sparks.

scenarios.title: Bleeding Wound from a Cut
immediate_steps: Apply pressure with a bandage or cloth for 10 minutes
Raise the injured limb above heart level if on lower limb, or keep it at shoulder height if on upper limb
Check the wound for any foreign objects and do not press down on them
do_not: try to remove any foreign objects yourself

scenarios.title: Pus or Infection Wound
immediate_steps: Wash hands thoroughly and put on gloves
Clean the wound with bottled water or sterile wipes
Apply a new dressing or plaster
do_not: use antiseptic without proper training

scenarios.title: Deep Cut on the Palm of the Hand
symptoms: severe pain, difficulty moving hand, or loss of feeling in the hand
immediate_steps: Call 999 or go to A&E immediately
Apply a clean dressing to the wound
Immobilize the hand with a splint if possible
when_to_seek_help: severe pain, difficulty moving hand, or loss of feeling in the hand
do_not: drive to A&E yourself

scenarios.title: Severe Cut on the Face
symptoms: severe pain, swelling, or difficulty breathing
immediate_steps: Call 999 or go to A&E immediately
Apply a clean dressing to the wound
Keep the face as still as possible and avoid moving it
when_to_seek_help: severe pain, swelling, or difficulty breathing
do_not: use harsh soap on the cut

scenarios.title: Foreign Object in a Cut
symptoms: difficulty moving affected limb or numbness
immediate_steps: Call 999 or go to A&E immediately
Apply a clean dressing to the wound
Do not try to remove the object yourself
when_to_seek_help: difficulty moving affected limb or numbness
do_not: try to remove the foreign object yourself

scenarios.title: Insect Sting Allergic Reaction
symptoms: swelling of your throat and tongue
difficulty breathing or breathing very fast
immediate_steps: Call 999
Lie down with raised legs if struggling to breathe
Try to remove the sting if still in skin
when_to_seek_help: Symptoms have not improved after 5 minutes
do_not: Stand or walk at any time

scenarios.title: Food Allergic Reaction
symptoms: swelling of your throat and tongue
difficulty breathing or breathing very fast
immediate_steps: Call 999
Use an adrenaline auto-injector (if available)
Lie down with raised legs if struggling to breathe
when_to_seek_help: Symptoms have not improved after 5 minutes
do_not: Stand or walk at any time

scenarios.title: Anaphylactic Reaction
symptoms: swelling of your throat and tongue
difficulty breathing or breathing very fast
immediate_steps: Call 999
Use an adrenaline auto-injector (if available)
Lie down with raised legs if struggling to breathe
when_to_seek_help: Symptoms have not improved after 5 minutes
do_not: Stand or walk at any time

scenarios.title: Broken Hip - Minor Pain
symptoms: pain in the hip or upper leg
swelling and bruising around your hip and upper leg
immediate_steps: Rest the affected area
Apply ice to reduce pain and swelling
Use over-the-counter pain relievers as directed by the manufacturer's instructions
Monitor for numbness or tingling in your hip or leg after an injury
do_not: Drive yourself to see a doctor without proper medical attention
Apply heat to the affected area
scenarios.additional_info: Seek immediate help if you experience severe pain, difficulty moving, or numbness/tingling

scenarios.title: Broken Hip - Severe Pain
symptoms: Severe pain in the hip or upper leg
Inability to stand or put weight on your affected hip and leg
immediate_steps: Call 999 or go to A&E immediately
Remove any constrictive clothing that may be causing discomfort
Try to remain calm and still until medical help arrives
when_to_seek_help: Severe pain after a fall or injury
Inability to walk or put weight on your leg
do_not: Drive yourself to see a doctor without proper medical attention
scenarios.additional_info: Get help right away, as this may be a life-threatening situation

scenarios.title: Broken Hip - Difficulty Moving
symptoms: Difficulty moving your hip and leg
The affected leg is at an odd angle or is shorter than the unaffected leg
immediate_steps: Try to remain calm and still until medical help arrives
Remove any constrictive clothing that may be causing discomfort
Use crutches if available to take weight off your affected leg
when_to_seek_help: Difficulty moving after a fall or injury
The affected leg is at an odd angle or is shorter than the unaffected leg
do_not: Drive yourself to see a doctor without proper medical attention
scenarios.additional_info: Get help right away, as this may be a serious injury

scenarios.title: Transient Ischaemic Attack (TIA) - Recognizing Symptoms
symptoms: numbness or weakness in the face, arms, and legs
immediate_steps: Call 999 immediately if you see any of these signs or symptoms
Do not drive yourself to hospital
Stay calm and try to communicate with your emergency contact
when_to_seek_help: see any of these signs or symptoms
do_not: drive yourself to hospital
scenarios.additional_info: Symptoms may last for a few minutes to a few hours, but fully resolve within 24 hours.

scenarios.title: Blood Clot in the Brain - Treatment
symptoms: weakness or numbness in the face, arms, and legs
immediate_steps: Administer aspirin (if prescribed) by a trained person
Keep the patient calm and try to keep their airway clear
Do not give the patient any medication unless instructed to do so
do_not: administer aspirin if not prescribed
scenarios.additional_info: Seek immediate medical attention for a blood clot in the brain.

scenarios.title: Stroke - Emergency Response
symptoms: sudden weakness or numbness in the face, arms, and legs
immediate_steps: Call 999 immediately if you see any of these signs or symptoms
Do not drive yourself to hospital
Stay calm and try to communicate with your emergency contact
when_to_seek_help: see any of these signs or symptoms
do_not: drive yourself to hospital
scenarios.additional_info: Act F.A.S.T. to recognize stroke symptoms.

scenarios.title: Mini Stroke - Follow-up Care
symptoms: weakness or numbness in the face, arms, and legs
immediate_steps: Attend follow-up appointment with your doctor
Take any prescribed medication as directed
Maintain a healthy lifestyle
scenarios.additional_info: Prevent future mini strokes by maintaining a healthy lifestyle.

scenarios.title: Alcohol Poisoning - Adult
symptoms: slurring words or being unable to speak
immediate_steps: Call 999 if you think someone has alcohol poisoning
Give them water to sip if they're able to swallow
Keep them warm with a jacket or blanket
do_not: Try to make them sick
Put them in a cold shower or bath
scenarios.additional_info: Can cause serious complications, like liver and heart failure

scenarios.title: Alcohol Poisoning - Child
symptoms: slurring words or being unable to speak
immediate_steps: Call 999 if you think someone has alcohol poisoning
Give them water to sip if they're able to swallow
Keep them warm with a jacket or blanket
do_not: Try to make them sick
Put them in a cold shower or bath
scenarios.additional_info: Can cause serious complications, like liver and heart failure

scenarios.title: Alcohol Poisoning - Elderly
symptoms: slurring words or being unable to speak
immediate_steps: Call 999 if you think someone has alcohol poisoning
Give them water to sip if they're able to swallow
Keep them warm with a jacket or blanket

if you have a weakened immune system or are allergic to snake venom

use tourniquets or ice packs on the affected area

if the child is unconscious or not breathing

immediate_steps: call 911 immediately
stay with the person and keep them calm
do not leave the scene unless it is safe to do so
when_to_seek_help: if you experience any of these symptoms
if you are unsure if the injury requires immediate medical attention
do_not: attempt to move the person or provide treatment without proper training
leave the scene or abandon the person

scenarios.title: Collapsing Adult with Unresponsive
immediate_steps: Check Responsiveness (tap shoulder and shout 'Are you OK?')
Start Hands-Only CPR if no response or breathing is absent
Continue Hands-Only CPR until trained responder arrives or person starts breathing normally
do_not: Touch the person unless necessary to perform CPR
scenarios.additional_info: Do not attempt conventional CPR without proper training.

scenarios.title: Severe Burn on Face

Immobilize the affected limb with a splint or sling

scenarios.additional_info: Seek medical attention immediately for snake bites.

scenarios.title: Adult Overdose with Difficulty Breathing
symptoms: Difficulty breathing, rapid heartbeat, and loss of consciousness
immediate_steps: Call 911 or your local emergency number immediately
Administer naloxone (if trained) or oxygen if available
Start CPR if the person is unresponsive
do_not: Administer any medication unless trained to do so
scenarios.additional_info: Seek medical attention immediately for overdoses.

scenarios.title: Bleeding from Cuts and Wounds
immediate_steps: Apply direct pressure on the cut or wound with a clean cloth, tissue, or piece of gauze until bleeding stops.
If blood soaks through the material, dont remove it. Put more cloth or gauze on top of it and continue to apply pressure.
Raise limb above the heart if possible to help slow bleeding.
when_to_seek_help: bleeding won't stop after 10 minutes of firm and steady pressure
do_not: Apply a tourniquet unless the bleeding is severe
Use hydrogen peroxide or iodine, which can damage tissue
scenarios.additional_info: Wash hands again after giving first aid and before cleaning and dressing the wound.

scenarios.title: Severe Bleeding
immediate_steps: Call 911 or your local emergency number if the person is unconscious or in severe distress.
Apply direct pressure on the cut or wound with a clean cloth, tissue, or piece of gauze until bleeding stops.
If the person is unconscious, begin CPR if trained to do so.
when_to_seek_help: bleeding won't stop after 10 minutes of firm and steady pressure
do_not: Apply a tourniquet unless the bleeding is severe
Leave the scene without calling for help
scenarios.additional_info: Use your best judgment and call emergency services if in doubt.

scenarios.title: Bites and Stings from Animals
immediate_steps: Wash the wound with soap and warm water.
Apply antibiotic cream to reduce risk of infection and cover with a sterile bandage.
Change the bandage daily to keep the wound clean and dry.
when_to_seek_help: the wound is deep or jagged
do_not: Use hydrogen peroxide or iodine, which can damage tissue
Leave the bite or sting uncovered
scenarios.additional_info: Be cautious of rabies if bitten by an animal that may be infected.

scenarios.title: Benign Positional Vertigo (Minor)

Help the person avoid sudden changes in body position.
Help the person avoid abrupt head movements, especially looking up.

immediate_steps: Stop the bleeding by applying gentle pressure with a clean cloth or bandage.
Elevate the injured area above heart level if possible.

do_not: move the person unless absolutely necessary

scenarios.title: Stroke (Critical)

immediate_steps: Call 911 immediately.
Loosen tight clothing around the neck and arms.
Turn the person onto their side if they are unconscious.
do_not: try to move the person

scenarios.title: Fever and Seizures (Moderate)
immediate_steps: Move the person to a safe location away from any heat sources.
Remove any clothing or bedding that may be constricting the body.
Loosen tight clothing around the neck and arms.
do_not: give medication without consulting a doctor

scenarios.title: Mild Dizziness After Head Injury
immediate_steps: Have the person sit or lie down
Loosen tight clothing around the neck
Elevate the feet about 12 inches
Check for any signs of concussion
do_not: Try to drive or operate heavy machinery

scenarios.title: Chest Pain and Shortness of Breath
immediate_steps: Call 911 or your local emergency number immediately
Lean the person forward to help breathe
Support the back and head with pillows
do_not: Administer aspirin

scenarios.title: Mild Vomiting After Injury
immediate_steps: Have the person sit or lie down
Loosen tight clothing around the neck
Elevate the feet about 12 inches
do_not: Try to give the person something to eat or drink

scenarios.title: Severe Numbness or Tingling
immediate_steps: Have the person sit or lie down
Loosen tight clothing around the neck
Elevate the feet about 12 inches
do_not: Try to apply heat or cold

scenarios.title: Burns and Burns to Face in Elderly Patients (65+)
symptoms: burning sensation that worsens with age-related medications
painful blistering that may be more prone to infection due to decreased circulation
scarring that may be more noticeable on older skin
immediate_steps: cool burn with lukewarm water, avoiding extreme temperatures
apply topical antibiotic ointment and cover with non-stick dressing
elevate affected area above heart level to reduce swelling
seek medical attention immediately if signs of infection appear
When to seek help: increased redness or swelling that worsens over time
difficulty breathing due to inhalation injury
burning sensation in throat or chest that interferes with swallowing
Do not: use household cleaners or harsh soaps to clean the wound
apply tourniquet or tight bandages, as this can cut off circulation
scenarios.Additional information: Never use water that is too hot or too cold when treating burns in elderly patients

scenarios.title: Severe Burns and Burns to Face
symptoms: painful blistering, leading to charring of skin
immediate_steps: call 911 immediately and remain on the line
cool burn with cool or lukewarm water (not ice or hot water)
apply topical antibiotic ointment and cover face and neck with a non-stick dressing
move person to a shaded area if possible
When to seek help: increased redness or swelling, difficulty breathing, or signs of cardiac arrest
burning sensation in throat or chest that lasts more than 30 seconds
Do not: use household cleaners to clean the wound, apply oil or butter to the burn
scenarios.Additional information: Never use water that is not lukewarm when treating burns, and always prioritize cardiac arrest over other symptoms

scenarios.title: Broken Arm: Immobilizing and Cleaning (Elderly)
symptoms: numbness or tingling in the arm or hand
immediate_steps: Immobilize the arm with a sling or splint, taking care not to dislodge any medication
Clean the wound with mild soap and lukewarm water, avoiding harsh agents
Apply antibiotic ointment to prevent infection and check for any signs of allergic reaction
when_to_seek_help: pain is severe or worsening over time
swelling is excessive or accompanied by fever
do_not: move the arm excessively, as this can dislodge medication or worsen bleeding
use harsh cleaning agents, which can strip the skin of its natural oils and slow healing
scenarios.additional_info: Elderly patients are at risk for complications from broken arms, such as pressure sores, deep vein thrombosis, and respiratory problems. Prompt medical attention is essential.

scenarios.title: Critical Fracture: Immediate Action Required
immediate_steps: Call 911 immediately and provide location
Immobilize the arm with a splint as soon as possible
Clean the wound with sterile water and apply antibiotic ointment to prevent infection
Monitor vital signs closely, including heart rate, blood pressure, and oxygen saturation
do_not: move the arm excessively
use harsh cleaning agents
apply tourniquet or ice to affected area
scenarios.additional_info: A critical fracture requires immediate medical attention to prevent complications and promote optimal healing.

scenarios.title: Scraped Knee in Elderly
immediate_steps: Clean the wound with mild soap and lukewarm water
Apply antibiotic ointment, then cover with a breathable dressing
Elevate the affected leg above heart level
Monitor for signs of infection, such as increased redness or swelling
when_to_seek_help: Redness, swelling that worsens over time, difficulty moving the knee
Increased pain, numbness or tingling in the knee or surrounding area
Signs of infection, such as increased redness or swelling
do_not: Touch or probe the wound with bare hands
Apply harsh soap, hydrogen peroxide, or iodine to the wound

scenarios.title: Severe Laceration in Children
immediate_steps: Call 911 immediately and provide location
Apply firm, non-stretchy bandage to wound
Elevate affected limb above heart level
Monitor vital signs for changes
do_not: Move child or change bandage without professional help
Apply ice or cold compress to wound
scenarios.additional_info: Seek immediate medical attention if child shows signs of infection, organ failure, or cardiac arrest.

scenarios.title: Elderly Sore Throat Due to Over-the-Counter Medication
symptoms: Cough with rusty or hoarse sound
immediate_steps: Encourage hydration and electrolyte-rich beverages
Use a humidifier to add moisture to the air
Administer over-the-counter pain relievers as directed, but monitor for side effects such as dizziness or constipation
do_not: Give aspirin to patients with a history of bleeding disorders or taking anticoagulant medications
scenarios.base_scenario_id: Child Sore Throat Due to Over-the-Counter Medication

scenarios.title: Child Sore Throat Due to Over-the-Counter Medication - Severe
symptoms: Sore throat that worsens with movement or speaking
immediate_steps: Call 911 immediately and begin CPR if child is unresponsive
Administer epinephrine auto-injector (if prescribed) and continue to administer over-the-counter pain relievers as directed
Use a humidifier and ensure child's airway is clear
do_not: Give aspirin to children under 18
scenarios.additional_info: This condition may be a sign of a more serious underlying infection, such as epiglottitis. Seek immediate medical attention if symptoms worsen or do not improve with treatment.
scenarios.base_scenario_id: Child Sore Throat Due to Over-the-Counter Medication

scenarios.title: Minor Scald from Hot Liquid

Elevate the affected area above heart level, but avoid extreme positions that may worsen breathing
when_to_seek_help: Changes in mental status or confusion
do_not: Break blisters or use harsh soap
Apply ice or take a cold bath
Use over-the-counter pain medications without consulting a doctor first

scenarios.title: Severe Burn from Scalding Water
symptoms: severe pain that is difficult to manage with medication
immediate_steps: Call 911 immediately and stay on the line
Apply a cool, wet compress to the burn for 10-15 minutes, then seek immediate medical attention
Do not move the person unless absolutely necessary, as this can cause further injury
when_to_seek_help: Any sign of breathing difficulty or consciousness loss
Severe difficulty moving due to pain
do_not: Break blisters or use harsh soap
Apply ice or apply a topical antibiotic ointment without medical supervision
scenarios.additional_info: Do not attempt to treat the burn at home. Medical professionals will provide further treatment in an emergency setting.

scenarios.title: Concussion in Elderly Patient
immediate_steps: Keep the patient lying down in a quiet room
Elevate the head of the bed 6-8 inches to reduce swelling
Offer a gentle drink of water if conscious, but avoid strenuous activities
when_to_seek_help: Symptoms worsen or last longer than 2 hours
do_not: use aspirin or ibuprofen without consulting doctor
allow the patient to drive or operate heavy machinery

scenarios.title: Severe Concussion in Child
immediate_steps: Call 911 immediately
Keep the child calm and quiet, but do not move them unless they are in a dangerous position
Apply cold compresses to the forehead or wrists, but do not apply ice or heat directly to the skin
Administer oxygen if available
Monitor vital signs closely
when_to_seek_help: Vomiting persists for more than 2 hours
do_not: use aspirin or ibuprofen on children under 18
move the child unless they are in a dangerous position

scenarios.title: Bite and Sting Wound in Elderly (65+)
immediate_steps: Wash the wound with mild soap and lukewarm water
Apply a cold compress to reduce swelling, but avoid icing for more than 15 minutes
Elevate the affected area above heart level, use pillows if needed
when_to_seek_help: Signs of infection (e.g., increased redness, swelling, or pus)
Dizziness or fainting that lasts more than 10 minutes
do_not: Break the skin around the bite or sting if you have osteoporosis or brittle bones
Use harsh soap, hydrogen peroxide, or iodine on the wound
Apply a tourniquet or tight bandage
scenarios.additional_info: Monitor for signs of infection and seek medical attention immediately if necessary. Elderly patients may be more susceptible to complications from bites and stings due to underlying health conditions.

scenarios.title: Critical Bite and Sting Wound
symptoms: Numbness or tingling in the face, arms, or legs
immediate_steps: Call 911 immediately and report bite/sting location and severity
Apply firm pressure to the wound with a clean cloth for 5-10 minutes
Immobilize the affected area with a splint if necessary
when_to_seek_help: Signs of severe infection (pus, fever over 101.5째F)
do_not: Break the skin around the bite or sting
Apply antibiotic ointment to the wound
Drive yourself to the hospital if symptoms worsen
scenarios.additional_info: Monitor vital signs and seek immediate medical attention if symptoms worsen or do not improve with treatment

scenarios.title: Burn from Scalding Water (Elderly)
immediate_steps: Flush the burn with cool tap water for 5-10 minutes
Apply a topical antibiotic ointment and cover with a non-stick dressing
Elevate the affected area above heart level, but avoid bending or lifting
do_not: Break blisters or scalded skin
Use harsh soap or ointments
scenarios.additional_info: Elderly may need additional oxygen and medication; seek medical attention immediately if symptoms worsen

scenarios.title: Critical Burn from Scalding Water
symptoms: Extreme pain, difficulty breathing, and rapid heartbeat
Burning sensation that spreads rapidly and worsens over time
Inability to move the affected arm or leg
immediate_steps: CALL 911 IMMEDIATELY AND FOLLOW INSTRUCTIONS FROM OPERATORS
Administer a burn gel or spray immediately, if available
Remove any clothing or jewelry near the burn area and apply a non-stick dressing
Apply cool tap water for 10-15 minutes, but only after first aid has been administered
when_to_seek_help: Signs of severe infection (increased redness, swelling, pus)
Difficulty breathing or rapid heartbeat that doesn't improve with rest
do_not: Break blisters or scalded skin
Apply any topical creams or ointments without medical supervision
scenarios.additional_info: Seek immediate medical attention if symptoms worsen or don't improve with first aid

scenarios.title: Head Injury from Fall (Elderly)
immediate_steps: Call 911 or your local emergency number if possible and stay on the line
Place the person in a comfortable position, such as on their side with a pillow under their head to support it
Loosen any tight clothing around the neck
when_to_seek_help: Changes in mental status or confusion that worsens over time
do_not: Try to move the person unless they are in immediate danger, as this can cause further injury
Give medication without consulting a doctor first

immersed the burn in water if it covers more than 10% of body surface area

apply antibiotic ointment without consulting a medical professional first
move the child unless absolutely necessary, as this can cause further injury

scenarios.title: Puncture Wound with Risk of Infection in Elderly
immediate_steps: Apply gentle pressure with a clean cloth or bandage, but be careful not to dislodge the object if possible
Call for emergency services and have them send an ambulance if you are alone or unable to get home safely
Have someone assist you in getting home or to the hospital
do_not: remove the object stuck in the body without medical supervision
apply a tourniquet or constricting band around the affected area
scenarios.additional_info: Prevent tetanus by seeking medical care, as vaccination may not be up-to-date
scenarios.base_scenario_id: Puncture Wound with Risk of Infection

scenarios.title: Severe Puncture Wound with Critical Risk of Infection
symptoms: numbness or tingling in the face or extremities
immediate_steps: Call 911 immediately and provide your location
Apply firm pressure with a clean cloth or bandage to control bleeding
Lay the person down on their back, elevate the head 12 inches above the level of their heart, and monitor their airway
when_to_seek_help: severe pain that doesn't improve with pain medication
numbness or tingling in the face or extremities
do_not: remove the object stuck in the body (can push it further in and cause more damage)
apply a tourniquet or tight bandage
scenarios.additional_info: Prevent tetanus by seeking medical care as soon as possible
scenarios.base_scenario_id: Puncture Wound with Risk of Infection

scenarios.title: Severe External Bleeding (Abdominal or Chest Wound) in Older Adults
immediate_steps: Apply gentle pressure with a clean cloth or bandage, avoiding over-pressuring the abdomen
Sit the person up if possible, to help maintain blood flow and prevent dizziness
Cover the injury with a moist cloth or bandage, but avoid wrapping too tightly
when_to_seek_help: severe bleeding that doesn't stop after 15 minutes of pressure
abdominal pain worsens or is accompanied by nausea or vomiting
dizziness or fainting persists or is severe
do_not: lift the person above the level of their wound if possible, as this can dislodge the clot and worsen bleeding
apply tourniquets or constrictive bandages, as these can cut off circulation to vital organs
scenarios.additional_info: Consider taking anticoagulation medications with you in case of an emergency. Apply ice wrapped in a towel to reduce swelling, if necessary
scenarios.base_scenario_id: Severe External Bleeding (Abdominal or Chest Wound)

scenarios.title: Critical External Bleeding (Abdominal or Chest Wound)
immediate_steps: Apply firm pressure with a clean cloth or bandage for at least 5 minutes
Elevate the injured area above heart level to reduce blood flow
Call 911 immediately and provide basic life support until medical help arrives
Lay the person down to reduce the chances of fainting, but do not move them unless absolutely necessary
when_to_seek_help: any sign of severe bleeding, difficulty breathing, or chest pain
severe abdominal pain that doesn't improve with rest
do_not: move the person unless they are on fire or have a spinal injury
scenarios.additional_info: Apply ice wrapped in a towel to reduce swelling only if necessary and under direct medical supervision
scenarios.base_scenario_id: Severe External Bleeding (Abdominal or Chest Wound)

scenarios.title: Gastrointestinal Severe Irritation
immediate_steps: Call 911 immediately
Remove any constrictive clothing
Administer water or oral rehydration solution (ORS) if conscious
Lay patient on their side in recovery position to prevent aspiration
Do not induce vomiting
do_not: Administer any medications without medical supervision
scenarios.additional_info: Monitor vital signs closely, perform CPR if necessary

scenarios.title: Ingestion of Highly Toxic Plant
immediate_steps: Call 911 immediately and administer water orally if conscious
Apply the heel of hand to the back of the neck to help keep airway open while lying down
Do not induce vomiting unless instructed by emergency medical personnel
Lay patient on their side with legs elevated at an angle
when_to_seek_help: Severe abdominal pain or difficulty breathing

scenarios.title: Hand Splinting for Minor Lacerations in the Elderly
immediate_steps: Apply a hand splint to stabilize the injured hand.
Clean and dress the wound with antibacterial soap and water, taking care not to dislodge any medication.
Gently apply antibiotic ointment and cover with a bandage.
do_not: apply a tourniquet
scenarios.additional_info: Monitor for signs of infection, as elderly patients may be more susceptible.

scenarios.title: Hand Splinting for Severe Lacerations
symptoms: severe bleeding that won't stop after 10 minutes
significant swelling, difficulty moving hand or wrist
coldness or pale color of the skin around the wound
immediate_steps: Call 911 immediately and apply a hand splint to stabilize the injured hand.
Clean and dress the wound with antibacterial soap and water, then apply antibiotic ointment and cover with a sterile dressing.
when_to_seek_help: severe bleeding that won't stop after 5 minutes
significant swelling or difficulty moving hand or wrist
do_not: apply a tourniquet, use harsh soap, or clean the wound with hydrogen peroxide
scenarios.additional_info: Monitor for signs of shock and seek immediate medical attention if symptoms worsen.

scenarios.title: Splinting a Broken Finger in the Elderly
symptoms: swelling, numbness or tingling in hands and feet
immediate_steps: Immobilize the injured finger using a hand splint or sling.
Apply ice packs to reduce swelling and pain, but avoid overuse of ice.
Monitor for numbness or tingling in hands and feet, report to doctor.
when_to_seek_help: pain worsens, limited mobility increases, numbness or tingling persists
do_not: move the injured finger without consulting doctor
continue strenuous activities
scenarios.additional_info: Consider consulting an orthopedic specialist for elderly patients.

scenarios.title: Splinting a Severely Broken Finger
symptoms: limited mobility with inability to move the finger
immediate_steps: Immediately immobilize the injured finger using a hand splint or sling and apply ice packs.
Seek immediate medical attention and call emergency services (911) if symptoms worsen or do not improve with treatment.
when_to_seek_help: pain intensifies, swelling increases, or limited mobility worsens
do_not: move the injured finger under any circumstances
apply heat to the affected area
scenarios.additional_info: Transport the patient to an emergency room immediately if numbness or tingling persists.

scenarios.title: Splinting a Sprained Ankle in the Elderly
immediate_steps: Apply an ice pack to reduce swelling and pain, but avoid prolonged application (less than 20 minutes).
Elevate the injured ankle above the level of the heart, with extra support if needed.
Use a bandage or compression wrap to support the ankle, but avoid too tight of a wrap.
when_to_seek_help: pain worsens or limited mobility increases, especially in older adults at risk for falls (e.g., osteoporosis, balance issues)
do_not: move the injured ankle, as this can exacerbate the injury and increase risk of fall.
scenarios.additional_info: Monitor for numbness or tingling in the foot, which may be a sign of nerve compression. Consider consulting a specialist (e.g., orthopedic surgeon) for further evaluation.

scenarios.title: Fishhook Removal from Skin in Elderly
symptoms: numbness or tingling in fingers or toes
immediate_steps: Pull the tip of the hook out in the opposite direction it went in if the barb has not entered the skin. Be cautious not to pull too hard, as this may cause further injury.
Wash the wound thoroughly with mild soap and lukewarm water. Avoid using harsh or abrasive cleansers.
Apply a loose, sterile dressing to protect the wound from dirt and bacteria. Use an elastic bandage if necessary.
when_to_seek_help: If you have diabetes or poor circulation, seek medical attention immediately as infection risk is higher.
do_not: Close the wound with tape
Apply direct pressure to the wound using a tourniquet

scenarios.title: Fishhook Removal from Skin (Severe)
symptoms: swelling that may lead to compartment syndrome
immediate_steps: Call emergency services (911) immediately and provide location.
Do not attempt to remove the hook yourself; let trained professionals handle it.
Apply firm, direct pressure with a clean cloth or gauze to the wound for at least 5 minutes.
do_not: Close the wound with tape
Use home remedies such as butter or cooking oil to remove hook
scenarios.additional_info: Seeking prompt medical care is essential for preventing infection and further tissue damage.

scenarios.title: Fishhook Removal from Skin (Superficially Embedded) - Critical
symptoms: heavy bleeding (excessive bleeding that soaks more than 2-3 gauze pads in 10 minutes)
immediate_steps: CALL 911 IMMEDIATELY AND PROVIDE AS MUCH INFORMATION AS POSSIBLE ABOUT THE INJURY
Put a loop of fish line or string through the bend of the fishhook, if possible, and hold onto the shaft
Use forceps to grasp the hook as close to the skin as possible and slowly pull it out in the direction indicated by the arrow on the 911 operator's guidance
do_not: Close the wound with tape or attempt to remove the hook yourself
Apply pressure to the wound without a clean gauze pad

scenarios.title: Wire Cutting Method for Fishhook Removal in Elderly Patients
immediate_steps: Cut the tip of the hook off just behind the barb with wire cutters, taking care not to push the hook further into the skin.
Remove the rest of the hook by pulling it back through the way it entered slowly and carefully.
Wash the wound thoroughly with soap and water, then apply a topical antibiotic ointment.
when_to_seek_help: If you experience increasing pain, swelling, or redness
If you have difficulty removing the hook yourself
do_not: Close the wound with tape, as this can cause further irritation
Apply tourniquet or restrict blood flow
scenarios.additional_info: Consider seeking medical attention if you are taking anticoagulant medications, as bleeding risk may be increased.
scenarios.base_scenario_id: Wire Cutting Method for Fishhook Removal

scenarios.title: Wire Cutting Method for Fishhook Removal (Severe/Critical)
symptoms: heavy bleeding that doesn't stop with pressure
immediate_steps: Call 911 immediately and explain the situation.
Cut the tip of the hook off just behind the barb with wire cutters. Be prepared to provide your location and a detailed description of the injury.
Remove the rest of the hook by pulling it back through the way it entered while maintaining gentle but firm pressure on the wound to control bleeding. If bleeding doesn't stop, reapply pressure.
Administer 2-3 cups of cool water over the wound for 10-15 minutes or apply a tourniquet if available and trained to do so.
Wash the wound thoroughly with soap and water as soon as possible.
Apply antibiotic ointment to reduce risk of infection.
Monitor vital signs and watch for signs of shock, such as pale skin, coolness, and shortness of breath.
Seek medical attention within 30 minutes of removal of the hook.
when_to_seek_help: Within 30 minutes of removal of the hook
do_not: Close the wound with tape
Apply a tourniquet without proper training
scenarios.base_scenario_id: Wire Cutting Method for Fishhook Removal

scenarios.title: Broken Finger Fracture in Elderly (65+ years)
symptoms: pain that worsens at night or with activity
limited mobility, stiffness, or numbness in hand or finger
immediate_steps: Apply ice to reduce swelling and pain, but avoid prolonged use (less than 20 minutes)
Immobilize the finger with a splint or bandage, taking care not to constrict circulation
Elevate the hand above heart level, but avoid bending or stretching the injured finger
when_to_seek_help: Pain worsening or increasing over time
Swelling or bruising spreading, or numbness/tingling in hand or finger
do_not: Moving or bending the injured finger for more than 2 hours at a time
Ignoring pain and continuing activity, which can lead to further injury
Taking pain medication without consulting doctor first
scenarios.additional_info: Seek medical attention if symptoms worsen or do not improve with treatment. Elderly may be at risk for osteoporosis, so fractures can be more serious.

scenarios.title: Severe Finger Fracture
symptoms: limited mobility due to numbness or tingling
immediate_steps: Apply ice to reduce swelling and pain, but do not stop bleeding
Immobilize the finger with a splint or bandage and seek immediate medical attention
Elevate the hand above heart level and call emergency services (911) immediately for transport to the hospital
do_not: Moving or bending the injured finger under any circumstances
Ignoring pain and continuing activity despite severe symptoms
scenarios.additional_info: Do not attempt to treat this injury on your own. Seek immediate medical attention if symptoms worsen or do not improve with treatment.

scenarios.title: Allergic Reaction to Insect Bite in Elderly Patients
symptoms: hives that may be more severe and potentially life-threatening
itching that can lead to open sores or infection
swelling that can affect breathing, swallowing, or vision
immediate_steps: Remove any constrictive clothing or jewelry carefully, as elderly skin may be thinner and more fragile
Apply calamine lotion or hydrocortisone cream to affected areas gently and avoid breaking the skin
Take an oral antihistamine such as Benadryl with caution, as elderly patients may be more susceptible to sedation
when_to_seek_help: Symptoms worsening or not improving within 2 hours of treatment
Difficulty breathing or swallowing due to swelling in the throat or tongue
do_not: Using ice or heat on the affected area, as elderly skin may be more susceptible to damage
Ignoring symptoms and continuing activity, which can lead to further complications
scenarios.additional_info: Elderly patients may require closer monitoring due to pre-existing medical conditions, such as diabetes, high blood pressure, or heart disease.

scenarios.title: Life-Threatening Allergic Reaction to Insect Bite
symptoms: Severe hives covering extensive areas of the body
Swelling of the face, lips, tongue, or throat
immediate_steps: Call 911 immediately and provide your location
Remove any constrictive clothing or jewelry
Apply a cold compress to the affected area if available
Administer an EpiPen if prescribed by a healthcare provider
Take an oral antihistamine such as Benadryl only if advised by medical personnel
when_to_seek_help: Symptoms worsening or not improving within 5 minutes of treatment
Difficulty breathing, rapid heartbeat, or fainting
do_not: Using ice or heat on the affected area
Ignoring symptoms and continuing activity
Administering any medication without consulting a healthcare provider
scenarios.additional_info: Seek immediate medical attention if symptoms worsen or do not improve with treatment. Call 911 if you are experiencing difficulty breathing, rapid heartbeat, or fainting.

scenarios.title: Burns (Severe) in Elderly
immediate_steps: Call 911 immediately
Remove loose clothing and jewelry
Cool the burn with cool water (avoid ice or cold compresses)
Elevate burned area above heart level
do_not: Breaking blisters or scabs
Using tourniquets or tight bandages
scenarios.additional_info: Act quickly to minimize damage

scenarios.title: Burns (Critical)
symptoms: Severe burns, charring of skin; Difficulty breathing; Fever over 103째F; Increased heart rate; Decreased blood pressure
immediate_steps: Call 911 immediately and stay on the line
Remove clothing and jewelry; Cover with a sterile dressing or cloth; Keep patient calm and still
Cool the burn with cool water, not ice or ice water
when_to_seek_help: Severe burns requiring immediate medical attention
Difficulty breathing; Fever over 103째F; Decreased level of consciousness
do_not: Breaking blisters or scabs; Applying topical creams or ointments without consulting a doctor first
scenarios.additional_info: Act quickly to minimize damage and preserve skin integrity

scenarios.title: Snake Bite (Elderly, 65+)
immediate_steps: Remove constrictive items
Keep the affected limb below heart level (avoid bending or lifting)
Clean and dress the wound with antiseptic wipes only
do_not: Trying to suck out venom or use a tourniquet
Driving yourself to the hospital; consider alternative transportation
scenarios.additional_info: Seek medical attention immediately; consider seeking help from a family member or caregiver

scenarios.title: Snake Bite (Adult) - Critical
symptoms: Severe pain, swelling, bruising; Difficulty breathing; Rapid heartbeat; Numbness or tingling in face, arms, or legs; Confusion or loss of consciousness
immediate_steps: Call 911 immediately; Remove constrictive items around the affected limb; Keep the affected limb below heart level; Do not move the person unless they are on fire
Do not try to suck out venom or use a tourniquet
when_to_seek_help: Snake bite, difficulty breathing, rapid heartbeat, numbness or tingling, confusion or loss of consciousness
do_not: Trying to suck out venom
Using a tourniquet
Applying ice or heat
Giving medication without medical supervision

scenarios.title: Burns (Minor) in Elderly
immediate_steps: Apply cool water for 10-15 minutes, then apply a topical antibiotic ointment and cover with gauze
Remove loose clothing and jewelry to reduce pressure on the burn site
Cover with a non-stick dressing and change daily
when_to_seek_help: Minor burns that are large (over 2 inches), deep, or won't stop bleeding
Burns to face, hands, feet, or genital area
Signs of infection, such as increased redness, swelling, or pus
Burns in people with diabetes or poor circulation
do_not: Breaking blisters or scabs
Using harsh soap, ointments, or cleansers on the burn site
Ignoring pain or not taking prescribed medications
Returning to normal activities too quickly

scenarios.title: Burns in Elderly
symptoms: burn pain, possible fracture or osteoporosis-related complications
redness, swelling, potential for infection in elderly
immediate_steps: Cool the burn with cool tap water for 10-15 minutes
Apply a topical antibiotic ointment and cover with a non-stick dressing, avoid breaking blisters
when_to_seek_help: burns to the face, hands, or feet, difficulty breathing, severe pain
any sign of infection, such as increased redness or swelling
do_not: Apply butter or oil on burns, can exacerbate infection risk

scenarios.title: Broken Humerus with Head Exposure in Elderly
symptoms: Severe pain that worsens at night
Limited mobility due to weakness or numbness
immediate_steps: Apply a firm, immobilizing splint to the affected arm and seek medical attention immediately
Elevate the injured arm above heart level, but avoid bending or straightening it
Control bleeding with pressure and bandages, but do not apply tight bandages
when_to_seek_help: Significant swelling, numbness, tingling, or weakness in the arm or hand
do_not: Assume a reduction of the fracture without medical supervision
Bend or straighten the affected arm while it is immobilized
Drive or operate heavy machinery until advised to do so by a doctor

scenarios.title: Burn on Hands in Elderly
immediate_steps: Cool the burn with cool tap water for 10-15 minutes, avoid extreme temperatures
Apply a topical antibiotic ointment and non-stick dressing, avoid tight bandages
Monitor for signs of infection such as increased redness or swelling, seek help if symptoms worsen
when_to_seek_help: Increased pain or difficulty breathing, especially if shortness of breath is accompanied by a cough or chest pain
do_not: Use harsh soap on the burned area
Apply ice directly to the burn
Tighten clothing around the burned area

scenarios.title: Severe Burn on Hands
symptoms: Severe pain that doesn't improve with treatment
immediate_steps: Call emergency services (911) immediately for guidance on transport to hospital
Apply a topical antibiotic ointment and non-stick dressing, but do not remove clothing or jewelry that is in contact with the burn
when_to_seek_help: Difficulty breathing, severe pain, or numbness/tingling in hands or fingers
Increased swelling or redness, especially if accompanied by fever
do_not: Move person experiencing a severe burn unless absolutely necessary
Apply ice or harsh soap to the burned area
Use tight clothing that may constrict the burn
Discontinue any medication without consulting a doctor first

scenarios.title: Bite from a Bee (Severe)
immediate_steps: Remove the stinger immediately
Wash with soap and water
Apply a cold compress
Call 911 or your local emergency number
do_not: Squeeze the stinger
Try to suck out the venom
Use heat or warm water to relieve pain
scenarios.additional_info: Administer epinephrine auto-injector (e.g. EpiPen) if available and known to be effective.

scenarios.title: Burn from Scalding Water in Elderly
symptoms: Redness, swelling, and warmth around the burned area
Decreased sensation or numbness due to nerve damage
immediate_steps: Cool the burn with cool tap water (avoid ice or extreme temperatures)
Remove clothing from the burned area carefully (avoid exacerbating injury)
when_to_seek_help: Increased heart rate or blood pressure
Numbness, tingling, or weakness in extremities
do_not: Use ice on the affected area (may cause further tissue damage)
Apply harsh chemicals or ointments without consulting a doctor first
scenarios.additional_info: Burns can increase the risk of infection; seek medical attention immediately, as elderly may be more susceptible to complications.

scenarios.title: Headache from Concussion in Elderly
immediate_steps: Rest and avoid strenuous activities
Apply ice packs to the head, but avoid direct pressure on fragile bones
Stay hydrated with water or clear fluids, and consider electrolyte supplements if symptoms persist
when_to_seek_help: Increasing severity of symptoms, such as worsening headache, confusion, or loss of balance
Weakness or numbness in the face, arm, or leg
do_not: Take pain medication without consulting a doctor first, especially blood thinners and sedatives
Drive or perform tasks that require attention and focus
scenarios.additional_info: Concussions can be serious in older adults; seek medical attention if symptoms worsen.

scenarios.title: Severe Headache from Concussion
immediate_steps: Call 911 immediately
Apply firm pressure to the injured area
Get to a hospital or urgent care as soon as possible
when_to_seek_help: Symptoms worsening or worsening rapidly within minutes
Loss of consciousness for more than 5 minutes
do_not: Take pain medication without consulting a doctor first
Drive or operate heavy machinery
scenarios.additional_info: Concussions can be life-threatening; seek immediate medical attention if symptoms worsen.

scenarios.title: Broken Rib (Severe)
symptoms: Chest tightness or severe difficulty breathing
immediate_steps: Apply a cold compress to the affected area IMMEDIATELY
Call 911 and get to the hospital ASAP
Administer oxygen if available
when_to_seek_help: Severe chest pain that worsens over time
do_not: Breathe in deeply or cough vigorously
Move or lift anything heavy
scenarios.additional_info: Monitor for signs of pneumonia; seek immediate medical attention if symptoms worsen. Do not delay seeking help.

scenarios.title: Burns from Hot Water (Elderly)
symptoms: Redness and swelling, pain, or difficulty breathing
Blisters that are white, leathery, or have a foul odor
immediate_steps: Run cool tap water over the affected area for 10-15 minutes.
Remove any contaminated clothing or jewelry carefully to avoid further injury.
when_to_seek_help: Signs of infection such as increased redness, swelling, pus, fever, chills, or difficulty breathing
Severe burns that cover a large area or are deep enough to reach organs
do_not: Break blisters or scratch the burned skin, as this can lead to infection and further complications.
scenarios.additional_info: Elderly individuals may be more susceptible to infections and complications from burns. Seek medical attention immediately if symptoms worsen or do not improve with treatment.

scenarios.title: Severe Burns from Hot Water
symptoms: Large blisters or charring of the skin
immediate_steps: Call 911 immediately and provide your location.
Run cool tap water over the affected area for as long as possible, but do not immerse in a tub of water.
Remove any contaminated clothing or jewelry, and cover the burn with a sterile dressing.
when_to_seek_help: Any signs of infection, such as increased redness, swelling, or pus
do_not: Break blisters or scratch the burned skin
Use ice or any other cooling agents on the burn
scenarios.additional_info: Seek immediate medical attention if the burn is severe or covers a large area

scenarios.title: Broken Bone (Elderly)
immediate_steps: Call emergency services immediately if possible.
Use a splint made of soft materials (e.g., cloth, foam) to stabilize the injured area, if feasible.
when_to_seek_help: Difficulty moving due to weakness or fatigue
do_not: Try to move the person without proper immobilization, as they may exacerbate the injury.
scenarios.additional_info: Seek medical attention for a broken bone in elderly patients, as they are at higher risk of complications and fractures can lead to osteoporosis.

scenarios.title: Critical Fracture
symptoms: Difficulty moving affected limb due to loss of sensation
Coldness or pallor in the affected area
immediate_steps: Apply a splint to the affected area if possible.
Immobilize the injured limb using a sling or wrap, and cover with a blanket or sheet to maintain blood flow.
Call 911 immediately and provide your location.
Keep the injured area elevated above heart level, but do not attempt to move the person without proper assistance.
when_to_seek_help: Any loss of sensation in the affected limb
Severe pain that does not improve with pain medication
do_not: Try to move the person without proper immobilization.
Administer any medications without consulting a medical professional first.
Remove any clothing or bandages from the injured area.
scenarios.additional_info: A critical fracture requires immediate attention from a medical professional, as it can lead to serious complications such as nerve damage, infection, or even death.

scenarios.title: Dislocated Shoulder in Elderly
symptoms: Difficulty moving arm or lifting hands
immediate_steps: Loosen any tight clothing around the neck and shoulders with care
Use a supportive sling or pillow to immobilize the shoulder
Elevate the affected arm above heart level, but avoid bending or twisting
when_to_seek_help: Pain that worsens over time or is severe
Difficulty moving arm or lifting hands for more than 2 hours
Numbness or tingling in the face, arm, or hand
do_not: Try to realign the shoulder unless necessary and advised by a healthcare professional
Use ice or heat on the affected area without consulting a doctor
scenarios.additional_info: Elderly may be more susceptible to complications such as pneumonia or stroke. Seek medical help immediately if symptoms worsen.

scenarios.title: Dislocated Shoulder - Critical
symptoms: Difficulty moving arm or shoulder movement is restricted
immediate_steps: Call emergency services (911) immediately and provide location
Loosen any tight clothing around the neck and shoulders, but DO NOT move shoulder
Immobilize the shoulder with a sling or splint if possible, but prioritize stabilizing neck and spine
when_to_seek_help: Any severe pain or difficulty moving arm
Arm turns blue or pale due to reduced circulation
do_not: Try to realign the shoulder unless medical professionals are present
scenarios.additional_info: Seek immediate medical attention if symptoms worsen or do not improve with rest and immobilization

scenarios.title: Broken Arm in Elderly
immediate_steps: Apply a splint to the affected arm, but avoid using a sling if possible
Elevate the affected arm above heart level, but be cautious of falls
Take pain medication as directed by doctor
when_to_seek_help: Pain that worsens over time or does not respond to medication
Difficulty moving arm, numbness or tingling in hand
Signs of infection, such as increased redness, warmth, or pus

Use a sling if it may impede breathing or worsen pneumonia risk

scenarios.title: Critical Nerve Damage
symptoms: Severe numbness and tingling in the face and extremities

Apply a rigid splint to the affected area to prevent further injury
Immobilize the affected limb with a sling or splint and elevate it above heart level
