Severe pain or weakness that worsens over time
do_not: Try to realign the nerve damage unless a medical professional is present
scenarios.additional_info: Seek immediate medical help if symptoms persist or worsen

scenarios.title: Minor Scrape (Elderly)
immediate_steps: Wash hands thoroughly with mild soap and water
Wash the scrape gently with mild soap and lukewarm water; avoid soaking in warm water
Apply antibiotic ointment if available; consider over-the-counter pain reliever such as acetaminophen or ibuprofen for pain
when_to_seek_help: If bleeding doesn't stop after 10-15 minutes of pressure, seek medical attention
If symptoms worsen or don't improve with treatment
do_not: Apply direct pressure on the wound
Cut the wound open
Use harsh soap, hydrogen peroxide, or iodine on the wound
scenarios.additional_info: Consider taking anticoagulant medications and consult doctor before treating any wound

scenarios.title: Critical Poisonous Insect Sting
symptoms: Swelling of the face, lips, tongue, or throat
immediate_steps: Call 911 immediately. Do not delay.
when_to_seek_help: If you experience any of these symptoms
do_not: Use heat or apply a tourniquet
Try to suck out the venom or use an antidote without medical supervision

scenarios.title: Minor Laceration in Elderly
immediate_steps: Apply gentle pressure to the wound with a clean cloth.
Secure with an elastic bandage, avoiding constrictive tightness.
Monitor for signs of infection and watch for changes in wound color or temperature.
when_to_seek_help: Changes in wound color, swelling, or difficulty moving
do_not: Do not apply antibiotic ointment to the wound if you have a weakened immune system.
Do not use harsh soap or hydrogen peroxide on the wound if sensitive skin is a concern.
scenarios.additional_info: Apply gentle pressure to the wound, and secure with an elastic bandage.

scenarios.title: Moderate Bleeding from Laceration (65+ years)
immediate_steps: Apply firm pressure to the wound with a clean cloth.
Elevate the injured limb above heart level and rest.
Use a compression bandage instead of tourniquet, as elderly may be at risk of decreased circulation.
when_to_seek_help: Excessive bleeding that doesn't stop after 10 minutes of pressure
do_not: Do not apply tourniquet without proper training.
Do not use a tight bandage that cuts off circulation in elderly.
scenarios.additional_info: Apply firm pressure to the wound with a clean cloth, and elevate the injured limb above heart level. Be cautious of potential falls or dizziness.

scenarios.title: Critical Bleeding from Laceration
immediate_steps: Call 911 immediately and provide your location.
Apply firm pressure to the wound with a clean cloth and use a tourniquet if available (only if you have proper training).
Elevate the injured limb above heart level and monitor for signs of shock.
Stay with the patient and keep them calm until medical help arrives.
when_to_seek_help: Severe bleeding that won't stop after 5 minutes of pressure.
Signs of shock (fast heartbeat, pale skin, rapid breathing).
do_not: Do not attempt to drive the patient to the hospital yourself.
Do not use a tight bandage that cuts off circulation.
scenarios.additional_info: Act quickly and prioritize stopping the bleeding. Call for emergency medical help immediately.

scenarios.title: Severe Laceration in Elderly
symptoms: Swelling of the face, throat, or limbs
immediate_steps: Call 911 or your local emergency number immediately.
Apply a clean, sterile dressing to the wound as gently as possible to avoid further injury.
Immobilize the injured limb with a splint if necessary, but do not remove any constrictive clothing or jewelry without proper assistance.
Sit or lie down in a comfortable position and elevate the injured area above heart level.
Seek immediate medical attention, as elderly individuals are at risk for complications such as shock and cardiac arrest.
do_not: Do not attempt to drive the person to the hospital; call for assistance instead.
Do not try to remove any constrictive clothing or jewelry without proper medical assistance.

scenarios.title: Critical Severe Laceration
symptoms: Severe, life-threatening bleeding that won't stop with pressure
Extreme swelling causing difficulty moving the affected limb
Sudden, severe pain that may be accompanied by numbness or tingling
immediate_steps: Call 911 immediately and stay on the line.
Apply a clean, sterile dressing to the wound, but DO NOT attempt to stop bleeding with a tourniquet.
Immobilize the injured limb with a splint if possible, but prioritize stopping the bleeding.
Start CPR if the person is unresponsive and not breathing.
Monitor vital signs closely for shock and cardiac arrest.
when_to_seek_help: Severe bleeding that doesn't stop after 5 minutes of pressure
Swelling that causes difficulty moving the affected limb
do_not: Do NOT attempt to drive the person to the hospital.
Do NOT remove any constrictive clothing or jewelry without proper training and equipment.
scenarios.additional_info: Call 911 immediately and follow instructions from emergency operators.

scenarios.title: Broken Finger Splinting (Elderly)
immediate_steps: Wrap the finger with a bandage or cloth to protect it from further injury, taking care not to constrict blood flow.
Apply an ice pack wrapped in a cloth to reduce swelling and pain for no more than 15 minutes at a time.
Use a splint material (such as a rolled-up newspaper) to support the injured finger, avoiding bending or straightening the finger
when_to_seek_help: If you have diabetes, poor circulation, or are taking medications that affect healing.
do_not: Apply direct pressure on the injury, as this can worsen swelling and numbness.
Bend or straighten the injured finger, as this can cause further damage.
scenarios.additional_info: Finger injuries in older adults are more common due to decreased bone density. Be cautious of osteoporosis when using splints.

scenarios.title: Broken Finger Splinting (Severe)
symptoms: Severe pain that won't subside with medication
Swelling that's increasing in size and causing difficulty moving the finger
Numbness or tingling that's spreading to other fingers or hands
Loss of sensation or reflexes in the injured finger
immediate_steps: Call emergency services immediately and inform them you have a severe finger injury (911).
Apply an ice pack wrapped in a cloth to reduce swelling and pain, but only for 15-20 minutes at a time. Repeat this process as needed.
Use a splint material (such as a rolled-up newspaper) to support the injured finger, and get it to a hospital or urgent care facility as soon as possible.
when_to_seek_help: Immediately if you experience severe symptoms or can't move the finger
Within hours if symptoms worsen or don't improve with treatment
do_not: Apply direct pressure on the injury (this can cut off blood flow)
Try to move or manipulate the injured finger
Use a tourniquet or any other constrictive device around the wrist
scenarios.additional_info: Seek immediate medical attention for severe finger injuries. Delaying treatment can lead to serious complications, including infection and permanent damage.

scenarios.title: Ankle Sprain Treatment in Elderly (65+)
immediate_steps: Apply ice packs to the affected area for 15-20 minutes, three times a day. Be cautious not to fall or lose balance.
Elevate the injured ankle above heart level and use a pillow or cushion for support.
Use compression bandages or tape to stabilize the ankle. Avoid tight stockings that may constrict blood flow.
when_to_seek_help: Pain worsens over time, or difficulty walking
Signs of dehydration (excessive thirst, dark urine, decreased urine output)
do_not: Bend or straighten the ankle, as this can increase pain and risk of falling
Apply direct pressure on the injury, which may worsen bleeding
Ignore numbness or tingling sensations in the foot or toes
scenarios.additional_info: Consult with your doctor before resuming normal activities. Elderly individuals may need additional time to heal.

scenarios.title: Severe Ankle Sprain Treatment
symptoms: Limited mobility with significant weight-bearing difficulty
Pallor or coolness of the skin around the ankle
immediate_steps: Call 911 immediately and provide emergency assistance if possible.
Apply ice packs to the affected area for 15-20 minutes, three times a day, and continue until medical help arrives.
Elevate the injured ankle above heart level and use compression bandages or tape to stabilize the ankle as much as possible.
when_to_seek_help: Difficulty walking or putting weight on the affected ankle
Coldness, numbness, tingling, or weakness in the leg
do_not: Bend or straighten the ankle
Apply direct pressure on the injury
Remove ice packs or stop elevation
scenarios.additional_info: Seek immediate medical attention if you experience any of these symptoms.

scenarios.title: Burn Care for a Minor Burn in Older Adults (65+)
immediate_steps: Cool the burn with cool tap water for 10-15 minutes, avoiding immersion in water to prevent shivering.
Apply a topical antibiotic ointment and cover with a non-stick dressing or bandage, taking care not to break any skin barriers.
Monitor for signs of infection, such as increased redness or swelling, and seek medical attention if unable to manage symptoms at home.
when_to_seek_help: Blisters, especially on the face, ears, hands, feet, or genital area
do_not: Use harsh soap or apply ice to the burn, as these can exacerbate circulation issues common in older adults.
Take non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) without consulting a doctor first.
scenarios.additional_info: Consult with a healthcare provider if you are taking medications that may affect healing, such as blood thinners or immunosuppressants.
scenarios.base_scenario_id: Burn Care for a Minor Burn

scenarios.title: Burn Care for a Severe Burn
symptoms: Blisters that burst and ooze fluid
immediate_steps: Call 911 IMMEDIATELY if the burn covers a large area of your body or if you are experiencing difficulty breathing. If you are in a public place, try to find someone who can call for help.
Cool the burn with cool tap water for 10-15 minutes, then apply a topical antibiotic ointment and cover with a non-stick dressing or bandage.
Administer pain medication as directed by the emergency medical personnel.
do_not: Use harsh soap or apply ice to the burn
Break any blisters that have formed without medical supervision
scenarios.additional_info: Seek immediate medical attention if you are experiencing cardiac arrest, severe shock, or altered mental status.
scenarios.base_scenario_id: Burn Care for a Minor Burn

scenarios.title: Head Injury First Aid for Elderly (65+)
symptoms: Memory loss or difficulty remembering events
immediate_steps: Stay calm and reassure the person, but avoid physical restraint.
Clear the area of any hazards or obstacles to prevent falls.
do_not: Move the person unless they are in immediate danger, as they may be at risk for further injury.
Apply direct pressure on the injury, as elderly patients may have fragile bones.
scenarios.additional_info: Elderly patients may experience changes in mental status due to medication or underlying medical conditions. If symptoms persist or worsen, seek medical attention promptly.

scenarios.title: Critical Head Injury First Aid
immediate_steps: Call 911 immediately. Do not attempt to drive the person to a hospital.
Clear the area of any hazards or obstacles.
Check for breathing and pulse, then begin CPR if the person is unresponsive.
do_not: Move the person unless they are in immediate danger.
Apply direct pressure on the injury
Remove any cervical collar or immobilization device without medical guidance.
scenarios.additional_info: If the person is unresponsive, not breathing, or showing signs of cardiac arrest, start CPR. If unsure about treatment, err on the side of caution and seek immediate medical attention.

scenarios.title: Applying Liquid Bandage for Minor Laceration in Elderly
immediate_steps: Wash the cut and surrounding area with cold water and mild soap.
Dry the site completely with a clean towel or gauze pad, avoiding scrubbing which can dislodge blood clots.
when_to_seek_help: Signs of infection (increased redness, swelling, warmth), difficulty breathing
do_not: Use liquid bandage around the eyes, in the ear or nose as this can cause further irritation.
Apply tourniquet or constrictive bandages unless instructed by a medical professional.
scenarios.additional_info: Monitor for signs of blood clots and numbness or weakness in legs or arms. Consider mobility aids to reduce strain on affected area
scenarios.base_scenario_id: Applying Liquid Bandage for Minor Laceration

scenarios.title: Applying Liquid Bandage for Severe Laceration
symptoms: severe bleeding that won't stop after 10 minutes of pressure
excessive swelling, bruising, or discoloration around the wound site
pain or numbness spreading beyond the wound area
immediate_steps: Call emergency services immediately by dialing 911 and report your symptoms. Stay on the line with the operator.
Apply firm and steady pressure to the cut using a clean cloth or gauze for at least 10 minutes to stop the bleeding.
when_to_seek_help: if you experience any of the above symptoms
do_not: Use liquid bandage around the eyes, in the ear or nose
scenarios.additional_info: Do not remove any constrictive items like jewelry or tight clothing that may be stuck to the wound.
scenarios.base_scenario_id: Applying Liquid Bandage for Minor Laceration

scenarios.title: Caring for a Severe Laceration in the Elderly
symptoms: bleeding that is heavy or difficult to control
immediate_steps: Apply direct pressure to the wound with a clean cloth or gauze for 10 minutes.
Elevate the injured area above heart level, but be cautious of falls.
Call emergency services and seek immediate medical attention. Consider enlisting help due to potential mobility issues.
when_to_seek_help: Bleeding that does not stop after 15-20 minutes
do_not: Apply tourniquets unless instructed by medical professionals
Use harsh soap or hydrogen peroxide to clean the wound
Disregard concerns about bleeding and apply pressure only when medically advised
Take pain medication without consulting a doctor first
scenarios.additional_info: Elderly individuals may be more susceptible to hypovolemic shock due to reduced blood volume. Be cautious of potential falls while elevating the injured area.

scenarios.title: Minor Cut on the Hand in Elderly
immediate_steps: Apply gentle pressure with a bandage for 5 minutes to stop bleeding.
Clean the cut with mild soap and lukewarm water, then apply an antiseptic solution or wipe.
Cover the cut with a sterile gauze pad and elevate the hand above heart level.
when_to_seek_help: if unable to stop bleeding after 10 minutes of pressure
if showing signs of infection (e.g., increased redness, swelling, pain)
if experiencing numbness or tingling in fingers
do_not: force the wound closed with a finger or any object
apply harsh soap or hydrogen peroxide
immobilize the arm with a sling if unable to do so safely
scenarios.additional_info: Be cautious of osteoporosis, consider bone density testing after injury.

scenarios.title: Burn on the Arm (Elderly)
immediate_steps: Run cool tap water over the burn for 10-15 minutes to reduce temperature and ease pain.
Remove any loose clothing or jewelry near the burned area, and apply a breathable dressing.
Take an over-the-counter pain reliever such as acetaminophen, but consult doctor before taking if on blood thinners.
do_not: use harsh soap or ointment
apply ice
try to move or lift the burned area
discontinue medications without consulting doctor first
scenarios.additional_info: Monitor for signs of infection, especially in diabetic patients. Consider wound care by a professional if unsure about wound care at home.

scenarios.title: Severe Burn on the Arm
symptoms: pale or cool skin around the burned area
immediate_steps: Call 911 immediately and provide your location.
Run cool tap water over the burn for 10-15 minutes to reduce temperature and ease pain, but avoid submerging the burned area below the elbow.
Remove any clothing or jewelry near the burned area, and apply a non-stick dressing, but do not apply any topical creams or ointments.
Apply a sterile gauze pad or dressing to cover the burn and secure with medical tape.
when_to_seek_help: Seek immediate medical attention if you experience difficulty breathing, chest pain, severe headache, confusion, dizziness, or loss of consciousness
If you are unsure about the severity of the burn or have concerns about your condition
do_not: use harsh soap or ointment
apply ice
break any blisters that form
scenarios.additional_info: Monitor for signs of infection, such as increased redness, swelling, or pus. Do not delay seeking medical attention if you experience any of these symptoms.

scenarios.title: Broken Toe in Elderly
immediate_steps: Stop activity and elevate the foot above heart level to reduce swelling.
Apply an elastic bandage or splint to immobilize the toe, being careful not to cut the skin.
when_to_seek_help: Immediate medical attention is recommended if you experience difficulty walking, numbness or tingling in your toes, or increasing pain
If you have a history of osteoporosis or have taken bisphosphonate medications
do_not: try to move the toe
apply harsh soap
bend down to pick up objects or adjust furniture
scenarios.additional_info: Monitor for signs of infection and be aware of any changes in your symptoms. Be cautious when walking to avoid tripping or falling.

scenarios.title: Severe Crushed Toe
immediate_steps: Call 911 immediately and inform them of the situation.
Do not move the toe unless absolutely necessary; immobilize it as much as possible.
Apply a cold compress wrapped in a cloth to reduce pain and swelling.
Elevate the foot above heart level to reduce swelling.
Use an elastic bandage or splint to hold the toe in place.
Monitor vital signs and seek immediate medical attention
when_to_seek_help: Seek immediate medical attention; do not delay.
If unable to breathe, start CPR if trained.
Apply a tourniquet only if instructed by emergency services
do_not: try to move the toe
apply harsh soap
disregard severity
attempt to self-treat without professional help
scenarios.additional_info: Seek immediate medical attention; signs of infection or nerve damage may require surgical intervention.

scenarios.title: Head Injury with Concussion (Elderly)
immediate_steps: Stop activity and rest immediately.
Remove helmet or headgear if applicable, but avoid bending or straining.
when_to_seek_help: Symptoms worsen or do not improve with rest within 24-48 hours.
Severe headache, confusion, or difficulty walking
do_not: Continue to participate in activities that may exacerbate the injury, such as driving, cooking, or heavy lifting.
Use pain medication without consulting a doctor first, especially if you are taking other medications.
scenarios.additional_info: Monitor for signs of worsening concussion, such as increased dizziness, vomiting, or confusion. Elderly patients may also experience urinary retention or constipation due to the injury.

scenarios.title: Head Injury with Severe Concussion
symptoms: Severe dizziness causing loss of balance or fainting
Confusion and disorientation with slurred speech
Headache with intense pressure and nausea
immediate_steps: Call 911 immediately if symptoms are severe.
Stop activity and rest in a quiet, dark room.
Remove helmet or headgear if applicable and apply ice pack to the affected area.
when_to_seek_help: Symptoms worsen or do not improve with immediate rest and ice.
do_not: Continue to participate in activities
Use pain medication without medical supervision
scenarios.additional_info: Monitor for signs of worsening concussion, such as increased dizziness, vomiting, or confusion. Seek immediate medical attention if experiencing any of the following: seizures, weakness or numbness in the face, arm, or leg, difficulty speaking or understanding speech.

scenarios.title: Burns on the Hands (Elderly)
immediate_steps: Run cool tap water over the burn for 10-15 minutes.
Apply a topical antibiotic ointment and cover with a non-stick dressing, but avoid breaking any blisters.
when_to_seek_help: Signs of infection appear, such as increased redness, swelling, or pus
do_not: Use harsh soap, ointment, or apply a tourniquet.
Break any blisters that form without medical supervision.
scenarios.additional_info: Monitor for signs of infection and seek medical attention if symptoms worsen or do not improve. Elderly may be at risk for dehydration; ensure adequate hydration after treatment.

scenarios.title: Critical Burns on the Hands
symptoms: Severe redness and swelling that spreads beyond the burn area
Excessive pain that is excruciating and difficult to manage with medication
Difficulty breathing or swallowing due to inhalation of smoke or chemicals
Numbness, tingling, or loss of sensation in hands or fingers
immediate_steps: Call 911 immediately and provide your location.
Run cool tap water over the burn for 10-15 minutes, but only if you are in a safe place to do so. Otherwise, stop the bleeding by applying pressure with a clean cloth or gauze.
when_to_seek_help: Burning continues or worsens within minutes of treatment
Infection signs appear, such as increased redness, swelling, or pus that lasts more than 2 days
do_not: Use harsh soap, ointment, or apply a tourniquet.
Break any blisters that form without medical supervision
scenarios.additional_info: Monitor for signs of shock, such as pale skin, fast heartbeat, and low blood pressure. Administer oxygen if available and provide oral antacids to help neutralize stomach acid. Do not attempt to drive or operate heavy machinery until symptoms improve.

scenarios.title: Cut on Hand ( Elderly )
symptoms: Increased bleeding, pale or cool to the touch skin
immediate_steps: Apply gentle pressure to the cut with a clean cloth for 5-10 minutes.
Clean the cut with mild soap and lukewarm water.
Apply an antibiotic ointment and cover the cut with a bandage, avoiding tight clothing.
when_to_seek_help: Increased bleeding, pale or cool to the touch skin, difficulty moving
do_not: Apply harsh soap or hydrogen peroxide, especially on elderly patients
scenarios.additional_info: Monitor for signs of infection and consider immunizations if applicable.

scenarios.title: Critical Cut on Hand
symptoms: Severe bleeding that doesn't stop after 10 minutes of pressure
Swelling that covers the entire hand or arm
immediate_steps: Call 911 immediately and provide your location.
Apply firm, direct pressure to the cut with a clean cloth for 10-15 minutes.
Clean the cut with mild soap and water, avoid harsh chemicals.
when_to_seek_help: Any of the above symptoms occur
do_not: Move the person unless absolutely necessary.
Apply a tourniquet or hemostatic agent without proper training.
Give medication without medical supervision.
scenarios.additional_info: Seek immediate medical attention for potential compartment syndrome or nerve damage

scenarios.title: Capillary Nail Refill Test - Critical
immediate_steps: Call 911 immediately and explain symptoms
Apply gentle pressure to the nail bed for 30 seconds, then release and reapply every 15 seconds until medical help arrives
Measure time it takes for blood to return to the tissue and report back to emergency responders
when_to_seek_help: Blanch times greater than 1 second or symptoms persist after 5 minutes of pressure application
do_not: Take medication without consulting a doctor, administer oxygen without proper training
Drive or operate heavy machinery if symptoms are severe
scenarios.additional_info: May indicate life-threatening dehydration, hypothermia, or cardiac arrest. Seek immediate medical attention.

scenarios.title: Burns in Seniors (65+)
symptoms: Redness and warmth around the affected area
Swelling, bruising, or pain that worsens with movement
immediate_steps: Cool the burn with cool tap water for 10-15 minutes (be cautious of falls)
Remove any loose clothing or jewelry near the burn to prevent further irritation
Apply a non-stick dressing to cover the burn, changing it every 2 days
when_to_seek_help: Severe burns, blisters, or charring; pain that is severe and unmanageable with medication
Difficulty breathing or shortness of breath; fever over 101.5째F (38.6째C)
do_not: Use ice or ice water on burns in seniors (can cause vascular spasm)
Apply a tourniquet or tight bandage to the affected area
scenarios.additional_info: May be more prone to infections, so monitor for signs of infection and seek help if present

scenarios.title: Laceration - Severe
symptoms: Severe bleeding (life-threatening), rapid swelling, extreme pain, numbness or tingling
Difficulty stopping bleeding, pale skin, fast heartbeat
immediate_steps: Call 911 immediately. If you are in a public place, alert others and try to find help.
when_to_seek_help: Any severe laceration that cannot be controlled with pressure, bleeding that won't stop after 15 minutes of pressure, difficulty breathing, or loss of consciousness
do_not: Use harsh soap, hydrogen peroxide, or other cleansers on open wounds. Do not attempt to clean the wound yourself.
scenarios.additional_info: May cause severe infection, organ damage, or even death if not treated immediately and properly

scenarios.title: Splinter Removal in Elderly
immediate_steps: Wash your hands with soap and water.
Use tweezers to gently grasp the splinter (avoid forcing)
Carefully pull it out at the same angle it went in, taking breaks if necessary.
when_to_seek_help: Infection or signs of worsening pain
do_not: Rubbing the affected area aggressively
scenarios.additional_info: Avoid using harsh soap or hydrogen peroxide, as these can dry out the skin.

scenarios.title: Splinter Removal (Critical)
symptoms: Swelling that covers more than 50% of the skin
immediate_steps: Call 911 immediately
Apply a cold compress to reduce swelling
Immobilize affected limb with a splint or sling
Administer pain medication as directed by doctor
Wash hands thoroughly with soap and water
when_to_seek_help: Severe swelling that threatens to cut off circulation
Signs of infection such as increased redness, warmth, or pus
do_not: Rubbing the affected area
Using a magnifying glass or lamp to try to remove splinter
Tightening clothing around affected limb
scenarios.additional_info: Do not attempt to remove splinter yourself, as this can push it further into skin and cause more damage.

scenarios.title: Insect Bite Removal (Elderly)
symptoms: Swelling, potentially leading to numbness or tingling in hands and feet
immediate_steps: Clean the bite with mild soap and lukewarm water.
Apply a thin layer of antibiotic ointment, avoiding harsh chemicals.
Cover the bite with an elastic bandage to prevent further irritation.
when_to_seek_help: Numbness or tingling in hands and feet that worsens
do_not: Using harsh soap or hydrogen peroxide, which can exacerbate conditions like diabetes or kidney disease.
Ibuprofen or aspirin if taking, as these may increase bleeding risk.

scenarios.title: Insect Bite Removal - Critical
symptoms: Swelling that covers more than 1 inch
immediate_steps: Call 911 immediately.
Clean the bite with soap and water.
Apply an antibiotic ointment to reduce infection risk.
Cover the bite with a bandage, but avoid tight clothing that may constrict breathing.
do_not: Using harsh soap or hydrogen peroxide on the affected area.
Applying a tourniquet or attempting to suck out the venom.

scenarios.title: Burn Removal in Elderly (65+)
symptoms: Pain, especially in joints or arthritis-prone areas
immediate_steps: Cool the burn with cool tap water for 10-15 minutes.
Apply a topical antibiotic ointment to reduce infection risk. Be cautious of medication interactions.
when_to_seek_help: Burns covering large area or vital organs
do_not: Using harsh soap or hydrogen peroxide due to skin fragility.
Removing clothing unless absolutely necessary to avoid further injury.

scenarios.title: Severe Burn Removal
symptoms: Swelling that covers the entire limb or face
Extreme pain, difficulty moving affected area
immediate_steps: Call 911 immediately for emergency medical attention
Cool the burn with cool tap water for 10-15 minutes, but do not remove clothing if it is stuck to the burn
Apply a topical antibiotic ointment to reduce infection risk, but only if available and safe to use
when_to_seek_help: Burns covering large areas (over 20% of body surface)
do_not: Using harsh soap or hydrogen peroxide on the burn
Removing clothing that is stuck to the burn without medical supervision
scenarios.additional_info: Severe burns can lead to shock, organ failure, and death if not treated promptly. Do not attempt to treat a severe burn on your own.

scenarios.title: Elderly Ingestion of Medication
immediate_steps: Call Poison Control online or by phone at 1-800-222-1222
Stay with the patient until medical help arrives
Do not give activated charcoal without consulting a doctor first
do_not: Administer aspirin or any other medication without consulting the doctor first
scenarios.additional_info: If the patient is experiencing difficulty breathing, call 911 immediately.

scenarios.title: Critical Eye Damage from Chemical
immediate_steps: Flush the eye with water for 10-15 minutes
Remove any contact lenses
Apply a cold compress to reduce swelling
Administer a topical anesthetic (if available)
Call 911 immediately
do_not: Use household cleaning products to clean the affected area
Apply heat to the eye
scenarios.additional_info: If the irritation persists or worsens, seek medical attention immediately. Do not attempt to treat at home.

scenarios.title: Snake Bite in Elderly (65+)
symptoms: Severe pain and swelling at the bite site
Numbness, tingling, or weakness in hands and feet
immediate_steps: Keep the affected limb below heart level, but avoid extreme positions that may exacerbate swelling
Do not attempt to suck out the venom; instead, clean the bite area with mild soap and water
Use a cold compress or ice pack wrapped in a cloth to reduce swelling (15-20 minutes at a time)
when_to_seek_help: Difficulty breathing, chest pain, or severe dizziness
do_not: Apply a tourniquet or use ice to constrict the wound; these actions can worsen bleeding and numbness
Give yourself medication without consulting a doctor first; elderly may have interactions with current medications
Use over-the-counter pain relievers without medical guidance
scenarios.additional_info: If you are in an area with no cell service, find a way to get to a hospital as soon as possible; elderly may require specialized care and transportation

scenarios.title: Dehydration from Ingestion (Elderly)
immediate_steps: Call Emergency Services immediately
Loosen clothing and provide a cool, dry space for the person to sit or lie down
when_to_seek_help: No improvement after 30 minutes of rest in a cool, dry place
do_not: Do not give fluids unless instructed by Emergency Services
Do not attempt to induce vomiting
scenarios.additional_info: Keep medications and supplements within reach, and have emergency contact information handy

scenarios.title: Critical Poisoning from Ingestion
symptoms: Severe nausea and vomiting, unable to keep fluids down
Extreme dizziness and loss of consciousness
Difficulty breathing, blue-tinged skin or lips
immediate_steps: Call 911 immediately for critical medical attention
Get the person to the hospital NOW. Do not delay.
Remove any clothing or jewelry that may be contaminated with the poison. Wear gloves if possible.
when_to_seek_help: Symptoms worsen within 5 minutes of ingestion
do_not: Induce vomiting unless instructed by Poison Control
Give the person anything to eat or drink, including water, except for the poison
scenarios.additional_info: Keep the phone number handy and have all medications or substances readily available. Do not attempt to treat symptoms at home.

scenarios.title: Burns from Scalding (Elderly)
immediate_steps: Stop the burning process and call for emergency help immediately
Remove contaminated clothing or jewelry carefully to avoid further injury
when_to_seek_help: Burns covering 10% or more of body surface area, especially on the face, neck, or chest
Signs of shock, respiratory distress, or cardiac problems
do_not: Use ice or ice water to cool burns in elderly patients
Apply topical creams or ointments without medical supervision
scenarios.additional_info: Elderly may experience medication interactions with burn injuries, so seek immediate medical attention

scenarios.title: Severe Burns from Scalding
symptoms: Severe burning sensation that spreads quickly
Extensive blistering, with multiple blisters covering a large area of skin
Difficulty breathing, rapid heartbeat, and feeling of impending doom
immediate_steps: Call 911 immediately. Do not attempt to drive yourself to the hospital.
Remove contaminated clothing or jewelry as quickly and carefully as possible while minimizing further exposure to the burn
Cool the burn with cool tap water for no more than 10 minutes to reduce damage
when_to_seek_help: Burns covering 20% or more of body surface area, or signs of inhalation injury
Signs of severe shock, including pale skin, rapid heartbeat, and shallow breathing
do_not: Use ice or ice water to cool burns. This can cause further damage and frostbite.
Apply any topical ointment without consulting a medical professional first.
scenarios.additional_info: Burns of this severity are life-threatening and require immediate medical attention. Do not delay in seeking help.

scenarios.title: Allergic Reaction (Elderly)
immediate_steps: Call emergency services immediately if symptoms worsen or progress rapidly
Administer epinephrine auto-injector (if prescribed) while lying down
Loosen tight clothing and keep the person calm, but avoid lifting or moving them
when_to_seek_help: Difficulty breathing or swallowing due to dehydration
do_not: Use antihistamines without consulting a doctor first, as they may interact with other medications
Administer aspirin or ibuprofen, as they can exacerbate bleeding risks
scenarios.additional_info: Monitor symptoms closely for signs of anaphylaxis and be prepared to call emergency services quickly

scenarios.title: Button Battery Ingestion: Elderly Patient Care
symptoms: Nausea and vomiting (less common in elderly)
immediate_steps: Stay calm and assess the situation.
Sit the patient up, if possible, to improve breathing.
when_to_seek_help: Symptoms worsening or showing signs of distress
Failure to respond to initial treatment
do_not: Administer any medication without consulting a doctor first.
Try to induce vomiting unless instructed by medical professionals.
scenarios.additional_info: Seek immediate medical attention if symptoms worsen or do not improve.

scenarios.title: Button Battery Ingestion: Critical Condition
immediate_steps: Call 911 immediately and provide the following information: child's age, weight, and symptoms.
Administer CPR if child is unresponsive.
Provide first aid for shock: place child on their back, tuck chin to chest, and use a firm blanket or towel under the back.
Do not attempt to induce vomiting; instead, focus on keeping airways clear.
when_to_seek_help: Symptoms worsen or do not improve within 1 hour
do_not: Delay seeking medical attention for more than 30 minutes
Administer medication without consulting a doctor
Use any first aid methods not recommended by authorities
scenarios.additional_info: Battery ingestion can cause severe internal injuries and is often fatal if left untreated.

scenarios.title: Battery Acid Burns in Elderly
symptoms: Blisters around mouth, throat, or digestive tract
immediate_steps: Remove contaminated clothing and jewelry carefully.
Flush the affected area with water for 5-10 minutes, then seek medical attention.
Call emergency services immediately and provide your age group.
do_not: Apply ointment or dress the wound without consulting a doctor first
Give medication without consulting a doctor
scenarios.additional_info: Seek medical attention right away, as elderly patients are at higher risk for complications.

scenarios.title: Battery Acid Burns - Critical
symptoms: Severe burns leading to charring of skin and underlying tissue
Blistering with signs of infection (redness, swelling, increased pain)
Respiratory distress with difficulty breathing or wheezing
immediate_steps: Remove contaminated clothing and jewelry IMMEDIATELY
Flush the affected area with water for 20-30 minutes using a hose or showerhead, starting from the burned area and working outward; avoid using soap, ointment, or other substances on the burn
Call 911 RIGHT AWAY
Get to the hospital ASAP if possible
when_to_seek_help: Symptoms persisting more than 15 minutes after initial treatment
Signs of cardiac problems (chest pain, arrhythmia) present
do_not: Apply ointment or dress the wound without consulting a doctor FIRST
scenarios.additional_info: Seek medical attention immediately. Do not attempt to treat at home.

scenarios.title: Critical Poisoning from Electronic Cigarette Liquid
symptoms: Dizziness, confusion, and loss of consciousness
immediate_steps: Call 911 immediately and provide your location
Administer CPR if the person is unresponsive
Remove contaminated clothing and jewelry while staying on the line with emergency services
when_to_seek_help: Any sign of poisoning, even a small taste or exposure
do_not: Administering food, water, or medication before medical help arrives
scenarios.additional_info: Even a small amount of exposure can cause severe nicotine poisoning leading to critical illness or death.

scenarios.title: Seizures from Nicotine Poisoning in Elderly
immediate_steps: Position the person on their side to prevent choking and ensure clear airway
Stay with the person until medical help arrives and avoid giving medication unless instructed by a medical professional
when_to_seek_help: Unresponsiveness or confusion that lasts more than 30 minutes
do_not: Giving medication without consulting with a doctor first due to potential interactions with prescribed medications
Using oxygen unless instructed by medical personnel
scenarios.additional_info: Elderly individuals may experience altered mental status, confusion, or unresponsiveness. Seek immediate medical attention if seizures last more than 5 minutes.

scenarios.title: Severe Allergic Reaction to E-Cigarette Liquid
symptoms: Swelling of the face, lips, tongue, or throat
immediate_steps: Call emergency services immediately (911)
Remove contaminated clothing and jewelry
Apply epinephrine auto-injector (if available) and administer
Administer oxygen if available and know how to use it
Lie patient down and keep airway open
when_to_seek_help: Any of the following symptoms occur: difficulty breathing, rapid heartbeat, swelling of the face, lips, tongue, or throat, abnormal heartbeat, nausea, vomiting
do_not: Using oral antihistamines before medical help arrives
Driving or operating heavy machinery while experiencing symptoms

scenarios.title: Chest Compressions for E-Cigarette Overdose in Seniors (65+)
immediate_steps: Call 911 immediately if experiencing symptoms
Start chest compressions only if trained and able to perform them safely (consider seeking help from others)
Continue until medical help arrives, even if experiencing symptoms of a heart attack
do_not: Using medication without consulting doctor first
Driving or operating heavy machinery while experiencing symptoms
Ignoring symptoms or attempting to treat yourself
scenarios.additional_info: Seniors may experience different symptoms than younger adults, such as confusion and dizziness. Prioritize seeking medical help immediately.

scenarios.title: Chest Compressions for E-Cigarette Overdose (Life-Threatening)
immediate_steps: Call 911 immediately and provide your location
Start chest compressions if trained
Continue CPR until medical help arrives, then try to administer naloxone if available
when_to_seek_help: Severe chest pain or rapid breathing
do_not: Using medication without medical guidance
Trying to smoke or vape again while waiting for help
scenarios.additional_info: Administer naloxone if available, but only if trained and supervised.

scenarios.title: Burns from Hot Surface (Elderly)
immediate_steps: Move the person away from heat source, gently to avoid falls.
Run cool tap water over burns for 10-15 minutes, be cautious of circulation.
Remove any clothing near the burned area, especially loose or constrictive items.
when_to_seek_help: Infection (common in elderly due to compromised immune system)
Nerve damage, numbness in hands and feet
do_not: Apply oil or butter to burned skin
Break blisters, as they may lead to infection in elderly
scenarios.additional_info: Monitor for signs of hypovolemic shock (dizziness, confusion) and cardiac problems.

scenarios.title: Opioid Overdose in Elderly
immediate_steps: Call 911 or your local emergency number immediately.
Administer naloxone according to the package instructions, if available.
Try to keep the person awake and comfortable until medical help arrives.
do_not: Giving any medication without consulting a healthcare professional first, especially those with complex medical conditions or multiple medications.
Trying to treat the symptoms at home without medical supervision, as they may be taking other medications that could interact with naloxone.
scenarios.additional_info: Act quickly and follow local protocols for responding to opioid overdoses in elderly patients. Consider their underlying medical conditions and medications when providing care.

scenarios.title: Elderly Ingests Azalea or Rhododendron
immediate_steps: Call Poison Control or 911 immediately.
Administer activated charcoal if available and have patient lie down.
when_to_seek_help: Severe symptoms, such as difficulty breathing
do_not: Try to induce vomiting
Give epinephrine (adrenaline)
scenarios.additional_info: Azaleas and rhododendrons can cause cardiac problems and respiratory issues in elderly.

scenarios.title: Critical Puncture Wound from Quill
symptoms: Puncture site is bleeding heavily, profusely, and not stopping after 10 minutes of pressure
Swollen at the site to an extent that makes it difficult to move affected area
Signs of infection present (fever above 103째F, redness/pink discoloration beyond wound edge)
Increased pain and tenderness around the wound
immediate_steps: Call 911 immediately, as this is a life-threatening situation
Apply firm pressure to the wound with a clean dressing or gauze for at least 5 minutes to stop bleeding
Elevate the affected area above heart level and monitor vital signs closely
Administer pain management medication (if available) but do not delay calling 911
when_to_seek_help: Any sign of difficulty breathing, rapid heartbeat, or severe dizziness
Increased redness or swelling around the wound that worsens over time
Signs of shock present (pale, cool, clammy skin, weak pulse)
do_not: Try to remove the quill, as this can push bacteria deeper into the wound and cause further infection
scenarios.additional_info: Prompt medical attention is essential to prevent long-term damage or life-threatening complications

scenarios.title: Ingestion of Non-Lithium Button Battery - Severe
symptoms: severe esophageal burns with risk of perforation
immediate_steps: Call 911 immediately
Remove any visible batteries from the mouth and throat area using a pair of gloves or tweezers, if possible
Administer oxygen via mask if available, and provide back blows until breathing improves
Provide plenty of fluids to stay hydrated
when_to_seek_help: any increase in symptoms or worsening condition
do_not: attempt to remove battery yourself
use water to try and dissolve battery
administer any medications without medical supervision
scenarios.additional_info: Monitor for potential complications, such as esophageal damage and cardiac arrest, and be prepared for emergency surgery

scenarios.title: Inhalation of Paint Fumes (Severe)
symptoms: Cough, shortness of breath, chest pain, rapid heartbeat, confusion, loss of consciousness
immediate_steps: Call 911 immediately and provide address
Leave the area NOW and get fresh air
Remove contaminated clothing and wash skin thoroughly with soap and water
Administer oxygen if available
when_to_seek_help: Chest pain, rapid heartbeat, loss of consciousness
do_not: Continue working in the same environment
scenarios.additional_info: Monitor for signs of respiratory failure and cardiac arrest

scenarios.title: Severe Skin Exposure to Pesticide
symptoms: Severe redness, itching, burning sensation, blistering, swelling, difficulty breathing
immediate_steps: Call 911 immediately. Provide address and a detailed description of the exposure.
Wash skin with soap and water for 20 minutes, then rinse with clean water
Remove contaminated clothing and wash thoroughly, taking care to avoid re-exposure
Apply cool compresses or calamine lotion to affected areas
Monitor for signs of shock, respiratory distress, or cardiac issues
do_not: Apply more pesticide
Rubbing affected area with hands
Using hydrocortisone cream without medical supervision
scenarios.additional_info: Seek immediate medical attention at the nearest emergency room or pediatric intensive care unit.

scenarios.title: Eye Splash from Chemical (Severe)
symptoms: Sudden, severe eye pain and redness, conjunctival hemorrhaging, vision loss or complete blindness
Inability to move eyes, blurred vision, double vision, photophobia
immediate_steps: IMMEDIATELY CALL 911 OR YOUR LOCAL EMERGENCY NUMBER. DO NOT WAIT.
Flush eyes with water for exactly 20 minutes while trying to keep the affected eye open
Remove contaminated clothing and wash skin thoroughly with soap and water
Seek immediate medical attention if symptoms worsen or do not improve within 5-10 minutes
when_to_seek_help: Any severe symptoms, including difficulty breathing or swallowing, chest pain or rapid heartbeat
do_not: Apply any cleanser or soap to the affected area
Put contact lenses in the eyes if they are present
scenarios.additional_info: Do not attempt to administer any first aid or treatment. Only provide basic life support (e.g., CPR, bleeding control) until medical professionals arrive.

scenarios.title: Inhalation of Paint Fumes (Elderly)
immediate_steps: Leave the area immediately and call Poison Control at 1-800-222-1222
Remove contaminated clothing and wash skin carefully to avoid further irritation
Provide information about the substance inhaled, but only if able to do so safely
when_to_seek_help: Difficulty breathing, chest pain, dizziness or lightheadedness
do_not: Inhale again or try to retrieve the substance, as this can worsen symptoms and lead to respiratory failure
Use a vacuum cleaner or other device to clean up the area, as this can stir up more fumes and exacerbate symptoms
Drive or operate heavy machinery until symptoms have improved
scenarios.additional_info: Seek medical attention immediately if symptoms worsen or do not improve within 30 minutes. Elderly individuals may be at increased risk for respiratory complications due to pre-existing conditions, medications, or underlying health issues.

scenarios.title: Skin Burn from Scalding Water (Elderly)
symptoms: Blisters that may be slower to heal due to age-related circulation issues
immediate_steps: Cool the burn with cool tap water for 10-15 minutes, but avoid prolonged exposure as it can cause shock in elderly patients
Remove contaminated clothing and wash skin gently with mild soap
Apply a topical antibiotic ointment, but avoid applying too much pressure or rubbing the area
when_to_seek_help: Blisters that are large, white, or have a foul odor, as these can be signs of infection in elderly patients
Severe pain, difficulty moving, or if symptoms worsen or do not improve within 24 hours due to potential age-related complications
do_not: Use ice water to cool the burn, as this can cause further damage to fragile skin in elderly patients
Apply butter or any greasy substance to the burn, as these can slow healing and increase risk of infection
Take pain medication without consulting a doctor first, as certain medications may interact with other age-related health conditions
scenarios.additional_info: Seek medical attention immediately if symptoms worsen or do not improve within 24 hours due to potential age-related complications.

scenarios.title: Skin Burn from Scalding Water (Severe)
symptoms: Blisters that are large, white, or have a foul odor
Difficulty moving due to severe pain
immediate_steps: Call 911 immediately and provide your location. Do not move the person unless absolutely necessary.
Cool the burn with cool tap water for 10-15 minutes, but do not get under the person's clothes.
when_to_seek_help: Any signs of shock or organ failure
Severe burns that cover a large area of the body
do_not: Use ice water to cool the burn
Apply butter or any greasy substance to the burn
Break any blisters with your fingers, as this can lead to infection
scenarios.additional_info: Seek immediate medical attention if symptoms worsen or do not improve within 24 hours.

scenarios.title: Lidocaine Allergic Reaction (Elderly)
immediate_steps: Call Poison Control at 1-800-222-1222 and inform them you are elderly
Administer epinephrine if available, but be cautious due to fragile bones
Do not take any medications without consulting a doctor first, especially if they have multiple conditions
do_not: Using antihistamines without medical supervision due to potential interactions with blood thinners
Trying to treat the reaction with over-the-counter medications, as they may not be suitable for elderly patients
scenarios.additional_info: Elderly individuals are more susceptible to dehydration and electrolyte imbalances. Monitor vital signs closely.

scenarios.title: Oral Pain Relief for Elderly
symptoms: swelling of the face, lips, tongue
immediate_steps: Rinse with cool or lukewarm water to reduce swelling
Gently massage the affected area with a clean finger
when_to_seek_help: Severe pain that worsens over time
do_not: Using lidocaine products without consulting doctor
Taking antacids or acid-reducing medications

scenarios.title: Lidocaine Teething Pain (Severe)
symptoms: severe irritability of the gums causing facial swelling
excessive drooling leading to choking risk
immediate_steps: Call 911 immediately and provide symptom details
Administer one dose of acetaminophen (acetaminophen suppository) or ibuprofen (ibuprofen suppository)
Apply a cold compress to the affected area for 10-15 minutes, 3-4 times a day
do_not: Using lidocaine products for relief in severe cases
Administering any medication without consulting a healthcare professional
Ignoring signs of respiratory distress or difficulty breathing
scenarios.additional_info: Monitor vital signs and watch for signs of neurological toxicity (e.g., seizures, confusion)

scenarios.title: Lidocaine Absorption through Broken Skin in Elderly Patients
immediate_steps: Call Poison Control at 1-800-222-1222
Remove any clothing or jewelry near the affected area and apply a cold compress to reduce swelling, while seated and supported by others if necessary
Do not attempt to treat the person without medical supervision
when_to_seek_help: Seizures, especially in those with pre-existing conditions such as heart disease or diabetes
do_not: Using topical anesthetics on broken skin, as absorption can be unpredictable in elderly patients
Administering IV lidocaine without medical supervision

scenarios.title: Lidocaine Absorption through Broken Skin - Critical
symptoms: Rapid and irregular heartbeat, potentially leading to cardiac arrest
immediate_steps: Call 911 IMMEDIATELY and provide the medical professional with your location
Remove any clothing or jewelry near the affected area and apply a cold compress to reduce swelling
Administer CPR if the person is unresponsive or showing signs of cardiac arrest, and continue until emergency services arrive
do_not: Using topical anesthetics on broken skin
Trying to treat the person with self-administered medications or remedies

scenarios.title: Child Burns (Severe/Critical)
symptoms: Difficulty breathing due to inhalation of smoke or soot
immediate_steps: Call 911 immediately
Administer CPR if child is unresponsive
Apply cool water for no more than 10 minutes, then seek medical attention
when_to_seek_help: Any severe burn greater than 20% of body surface area
do_not: Apply butter or grease to burned skin
Break any blisters that form
scenarios.additional_info: Do not leave child alone until medical help arrives. Monitor for signs of infection, such as increased redness, swelling, or pus.

scenarios.title: Adult Seizure in Elderly (65+)
immediate_steps: Clear airway
Turn individual onto side with care to avoid hip fracture
Check for breathing and pulse, use oxygen if available
Call emergency services immediately
Do not give medication without medical advice, consider using anticonvulsant medications prescribed by doctor
when_to_seek_help: Continue seizure for more than 5 minutes
Lack of responsiveness or difficulty awakening
Difficulty breathing or shows signs of respiratory distress
do_not: Try to restrain the person or inject themselves with medication
Use physical restraints that may cause injury
Apply ice or cold compresses (may worsen condition)
Administer general anesthesia without medical guidance

scenarios.title: Medication Overdose in Elderly
immediate_steps: Call emergency services immediately
Administer oxygen if available
Check for medications and their interactions
Remove any loose medications or pills from the patient
do_not: Try to treat with home remedies without medical advice
Give the patient anything to eat or drink unless advised by a doctor

scenarios.title: Child Poisoning - Severe

immediate_steps.description: Do not wait to get an answer, caller will dispatch help

immediate_steps: Give water to drink (only after medical advice)
Remove any packaging or labels from the substance and place in a sealed container for disposal
when_to_seek_help: Vomiting that lasts more than 2 hours
do_not: Try to induce vomiting without medical advice or guidance
Give the child anything to eat or drink until medical help arrives

scenarios.title: Animal Bites in the Elderly
symptoms: Pain, swelling, bruising, or discoloration around the bite area
immediate_steps: Wash the wound with mild soap and lukewarm water for 15 minutes
Apply a topical antibiotic ointment and cover with a bandage
Seek medical attention immediately if unable to move or experiencing numbness/tingling
when_to_seek_help: If symptoms worsen or do not improve within 24 hours
If signs of infection (redness, warmth, pus) appear
If bite area becomes numb, tingling, or weakened
do_not: Try to suck out the venom without medical advice or use home remedies
Take pain medication unless advised by a doctor first
scenarios.additional_info: Bites can be more serious in elderly due to weakened immune system and potential underlying medical conditions.

scenarios.title: Allergic Reaction in Elderly
immediate_steps: Call 911 or emergency services immediately
Lie patient down and elevate legs if swelling is severe
Administer epinephrine if prescribed by a doctor, but only if able to do so safely
when_to_seek_help: Any time symptoms worsen or fail to improve with treatment
do_not: Take antihistamines unless medically advised
Drive or operate heavy machinery until symptoms have resolved
scenarios.additional_info: Elderly may be more susceptible to complications from allergic reactions. Seek immediate medical attention if symptoms persist or worsen.

scenarios.title: Severe Burns from Battery Arc
symptoms: Severe, fourth-degree burns to the skin and underlying tissues, potentially involving internal organs
immediate_steps: Call 911 immediately and provide your location
Administer 1-2 mg/kg of epinephrine (if available) via IV or IM only if trained personnel are present
Cool the burn with cool tap water for 10-15 minutes, but do not immerse in water
when_to_seek_help: Infection or increased redness around the wound within hours of the incident
do_not: Use ice to treat burns
Apply butter or any greasy substance to a burn
Leave the person alone without medical attention

scenarios.title: Button Battery Ingestion: Minor Burns in Elderly
immediate_steps: Run cool tap water over the affected area for 5-7 minutes
Apply a topical antibiotic ointment and cover with a non-stick dressing
Monitor for signs of infection, as they may be delayed in elderly patients
when_to_seek_help: redness and swelling around the affected area
do_not: use harsh soap on sensitive skin
apply ice to the affected area, as it can cause further damage
move the patient excessively, as this can dislodge the battery
scenarios.additional_info: Elderly patients may experience delayed symptoms due to decreased circulation and medication use. Seek medical attention immediately.

scenarios.title: Button Battery Ingestion: Severe Burns
symptoms: Severe burning sensation that spreads rapidly
Difficulty breathing due to inhalation of toxic fumes
immediate_steps: Call 911 immediately and provide the person's location, age, weight, and size
Gently remove any remaining battery pieces from the mouth, if possible
Provide CPR if the person is unresponsive, not breathing, or has no pulse
when_to_seek_help: Any symptoms of severe burns or poisoning
do_not: Use harsh soap or apply ice to the affected area
Administer any medications without consulting a medical professional
Allow the person to continue breathing on their own if they are unconscious
scenarios.additional_info: Severe burns can lead to permanent scarring, organ damage, and even death.

scenarios.title: Button Battery Ingestion: Severe Chemical Burns in Elderly
symptoms: numbness or tingling in hands and feet
immediate_steps: Call emergency services immediately
Administer first aid for burns (cool water, topical antibiotic ointment)
Seek immediate medical attention and provide current medications
when_to_seek_help: respiratory distress or failure to respond
do_not: inhalate smoke or fumes from the affected area, as this can exacerbate respiratory issues common in elderly patients

scenarios.title: Button Battery Ingestion: Critical Chemical Burns
symptoms: Severe burning sensation that spreads rapidly
Systemic effects including cardiac arrest, respiratory failure, and seizures

Administer first aid for burns (immersion in cool water for 10-15 minutes), but do not delay
Provide CPR if the person is unresponsive
Apply a non-stick dressing or coverings to prevent further injury

scenarios.title: Rosary Pea Seed Identification (High Risk of Toxicity)
symptoms: Rapid heartbeat and shortness of breath
immediate_steps: Call 911 IMMEDIATELY if symptoms occur
Take pictures of the seed, but prioritize medical attention
Do not attempt to identify plant or ingest any part of it
Remove contaminated clothing and wash skin thoroughly with soap and water
when_to_seek_help: Seed is identified as Abrus precatorius (caused by Ricin)
Ingestion suspected, even if symptoms are mild
scenarios.additional_info: Prevention is key

scenarios.title: Mild Adderall Side Effects in Elderly Patients (65+)
immediate_steps: Contact the prescriber to see if a lower dose or different medication is needed and consider switching to a shorter-acting formula
Take over-the-counter pain relievers as directed, but with caution (avoid NSAIDs)
Get plenty of rest, stay hydrated, and follow a healthy diet
do_not: overdosing on the medication due to potential cardiac complications
ignoring symptoms that worsen or persist (e.g. confusion, difficulty walking)
scenarios.additional_info: Elderly patients may be more susceptible to cardiovascular events; seek immediate medical attention if symptoms worsen.

scenarios.title: Severe Adderall Side Effects
immediate_steps: Call 911 immediately and report your symptoms
Administer the antidote, if available (do not attempt to give medication without proper training)
Lay the person down in a safe location, elevate their legs, and stay with them until medical help arrives
when_to_seek_help: any severe symptom worsens or lasts longer than expected
do_not: do not try to treat yourself without proper medical training
do not give more medication than prescribed
do not drive or operate heavy machinery while experiencing side effects
scenarios.additional_info: If symptoms worsen or do not improve, seek immediate medical attention. In case of an overdose, call 911 right away.

scenarios.title: Severe Burn Scald
immediate_steps: Call 911 immediately for severe burns
Remove contaminated clothing, including jewelry or tight clothing that may constrict the affected area
Cool the affected area with water for 10-15 minutes, but do not apply ice or ice water as it can cause further damage
when_to_seek_help: Any burn covering more than 5% of body surface area
Difficulty breathing, rapid heartbeat, or fainting
Severe swelling or blisters that are increasing in size
Severe pain that does not respond to pain medication
do_not: Apply grease or butter to burn
Use household items like baking soda, egg whites, or honey to treat burns
scenarios.additional_info: Do not attempt to treat severe burns yourself. Medical professionals must be present for proper treatment.

scenarios.title: Severe Poisoning from Insecticide
immediate_steps: Call 911 immediately and provide the name of the insecticide used
Remove contaminated clothing and shoes, but do not attempt to shower or bathe
Lay victim down on their back with legs elevated 12-18 inches
Perform CPR if the victim is unresponsive
do_not: Induce vomiting
scenarios.additional_info: Seek immediate medical attention, as severe symptoms can be fatal within minutes

scenarios.title: Bleeding from Injury in Elderly
immediate_steps: Apply firm pressure to the wound with one hand
Sit or lie down, elevate the injured area above heart level if possible
Call for medical help if bleeding doesn't stop and you experience dizziness or fainting
when_to_seek_help: Signs of shock (dizziness, pale skin, rapid heartbeat)
do_not: Try to clean or apply tourniquet without proper training or if you have a medical condition
Move around excessively while bleeding to avoid dislodging the clot
scenarios.additional_info: Prompt action is crucial for elderly, as bleeding can lead to rapid blood loss and serious complications

scenarios.title: Life-Threatening Bleeding from Injury
symptoms: Extreme heavy bleeding that soaks through clothing and bedding
Severe swelling of the affected limb, making it difficult to move
immediate_steps: Apply immediate firm pressure with a clean cloth or gauze to the wound
Elevate the injured area above heart level and below elbow height
Call emergency services (911) immediately for assistance, even if you feel like you can stop the bleeding yourself
when_to_seek_help: Signs of shock, including pale or cool skin, shallow breathing, or a weak pulse
do_not: Try to clean or apply tourniquet without proper medical training
Apply a tight bandage or tourniquet that may cut off circulation
Use home remedies like applying ice or using over-the-counter medications
scenarios.additional_info: Seek immediate medical attention in the emergency room, as prompt action can save a life

scenarios.title: Chest Pain in Elderly Patients (65+)
immediate_steps: Call 911 or local emergency number immediately
Help the person sit comfortably with support
Loosen any tight clothing and remove any constricting items
Do not give the person anything to eat or drink until medical help arrives, as they may have swallowing difficulties
Stay with the person, try to keep them calm, and reassure them that help is on the way
do_not: give the person water or medication without medical supervision, as they may be taking medications that interact with each other
lift the person or move them excessively, as this can cause falls and injuries
try to walk the person to the emergency department themselves
use aspirin or ibuprofen unless advised by medical professionals
scenarios.additional_info: If the person is experiencing severe symptoms, such as difficulty breathing, rapid heartbeat, or loss of consciousness, seek immediate medical attention. Elderly patients may also experience confusion, disorientation, or altered mental status.

scenarios.title: Life-Threatening Chest Pain in Adults
symptoms: chest pain of acute onset, severe enough to limit movement or make breathing difficult
shortness of breath with blue discoloration of the skin (cyanosis)
loss of consciousness or near-loss of consciousness
immediate_steps: Call 911 immediately and provide critical information about your symptoms
Administer oxygen if available, but only under medical supervision
Lay the person on their back with their feet elevated and keep them stable
Do not attempt to give the person water or medication until paramedics arrive
Provide reassurance and try to keep the person calm, but do not leave them alone
when_to_seek_help: chest pain of acute onset, severe enough to limit movement or make breathing difficult
shortness of breath with blue discoloration of the skin (cyanosis)
loss of consciousness or near-loss of consciousness
do_not: give the person water or medication without medical supervision
scenarios.additional_info: If you are unsure about the severity of your symptoms, err on the side of caution and call 911. Seek immediate medical attention if any of the following occur: cardiac arrest, severe difficulty breathing, or severe chest pain that worsens over time.

scenarios.title: Burns on the Face and Neck in Elderly
symptoms: pain, especially in the face and neck
immediate_steps: Call 911 or local emergency number immediately
Cool the burn with cool tap water for 5-10 minutes (avoid submerging head)
Apply a topical ointment, such as hydrocortisone cream, to help soothe the burn
Cover the burn with a non-stick dressing or bandage to protect it from further irritation
Monitor the burn and watch for signs of infection, especially in immunocompromised individuals
when_to_seek_help: burns on the face and neck in elderly patients
burns that cover a large area or are deep
do_not: use ice or cold compresses on the burn (may cause tissue damage)
apply antibiotic ointment without consulting a doctor
scenarios.additional_info: Elderly individuals may be more susceptible to complications from burns, such as infections and dehydration. Seek immediate medical attention if necessary.
scenarios.base_scenario_id: Burns on the Face and Neck

scenarios.title: Ingestion of Household Cleaner
symptoms: burns in mouth, throat, and esophagus
immediate_steps: Call 911 IMMEDIATELY
Remove any remaining cleaner from the person's mouth and clothing
Provide small, frequent sips of water to drink (avoid large amounts)
do_not: attempt to induce vomiting in elderly patients
give medication unless advised by a healthcare professional
scenarios.additional_info: Use web POISON CONTROL tool or call Poison Control at 1-800-222-1222 for guidance tailored to elderly populations. Consider calling ahead and asking about emergency department preparedness.

scenarios.title: Swallowing a household cleaner (Severe)
symptoms: severe burns in mouth and throat
immediate_steps: CALL 911 OR YOUR LOCAL EMERGENCY NUMBER IMMEDIATELY AND STAY ON THE LINE
REMOVE ANY REMAINING CLEANER FROM THE PERSON'S MOUTH AND CLOTHING USING GLOVES
administre activated charcoal orally or via IV if available
do_not: attempt to induce vomiting
give the person anything to eat or drink except activated charcoal
scenarios.additional_info: Use web POISON CONTROL tool or call Poison Control at 1-800-222-1222 for guidance, PREPARE FOR POTENTIAL HOSPITAL TRANSPORTATION

scenarios.title: Exposure to chemical fumes
immediate_steps: Move to fresh air immediately, if possible
Remove contaminated clothing and replace with clean clothes, be careful not to exacerbate existing medical conditions
Call emergency services or seek immediate medical attention
do_not: attempt to move the person or provide first aid without proper training
give medication without consulting a doctor
scenarios.additional_info: Use Poison Control at 1-800-222-1222 for guidance

scenarios.title: Severe Inhalation of Chemical Fumes
immediate_steps: Call 911 immediately and provide patient's location
Remove contaminated clothing and replace with clean clothes, while keeping patient calm
Position patient on their back with feet elevated, if possible
do_not: attempt to move the person or provide first aid without proper training
administer any medication without consulting a medical professional
scenarios.additional_info: Use web POISON CONTROL tool or call Poison Control at 1-800-222-1222 for guidance

scenarios.title: Severe Dog Bite
symptoms: severe swelling that covers a large area of the face, neck, or body
immediate_steps: Call 911 immediately and provide your location
Apply a clean, dry bandage to the wound to control bleeding
Elevate the affected limb above heart level if possible
Stay calm and try to remain still until medical help arrives
when_to_seek_help: swelling worsens or does not improve with treatment
bleeding does not stop after 10 minutes of pressure
do_not: attempt to suck out the venom or apply a tourniquet
use a homemade remedy or over-the-counter medication without consulting a doctor first
scenarios.additional_info: Use web POISON CONTROL tool or call Poison Control at 1-800-222-1222 for guidance if symptoms worsen

scenarios.title: Burn from Scalding (Elderly)
symptoms: burn pain that worsens with age
redness, swelling, and potential for limited mobility
infection symptoms such as increased redness, swelling, or pus, which can be more serious in elderly
immediate_steps: Run cool tap water over the burn for 10-15 minutes, but avoid immersing hands or feet.
Remove any clothing or jewelry near the burned area, and consider using a compression bandage to reduce swelling
Apply a topical antibiotic ointment, and monitor for signs of infection
when_to_seek_help: Burning sensation that lasts more than an hour
Infection symptoms such as increased redness, swelling, or pus, which require urgent medical attention
do_not: Use ice or ice water on the burn
Apply butter or petroleum jelly to the burned area, as this can slow healing
Drive yourself to medical attention; consider having someone else drive you if possible
scenarios.additional_info: Seek medical attention immediately if the burn covers a large area or is deep, as elderly may be more susceptible to infection and complications.

scenarios.title: Severe Burn from Scalding
immediate_steps: Call 911 immediately, do not wait for responses.
Run cool tap water over the burn for 10-15 minutes, but be cautious of scalding
Remove any clothing or jewelry near the burned area and cover with a clean dressing
when_to_seek_help: Burning sensation that lasts more than 30 minutes
Infection symptoms such as increased redness, swelling, or pus, or signs of organ failure (e.g. severe abdominal pain, vomiting blood)
do_not: Use ice or ice water on the burn, can cause further damage
scenarios.additional_info: Seek immediate medical attention if the burn covers a large area or is deep

scenarios.title: Senior Falls or Burns
symptoms: pain or swelling in joint or limb
immediate_steps: Call emergency services immediately
Lift carefully and position safely if fall occurs
Cool burn with cool water for 10 minutes (if burned)
when_to_seek_help: Severe pain, difficulty breathing, or loss of consciousness
do_not: Apply heat to the affected area
scenarios.additional_info: Monitor vital signs and seek medical help if confusion or altered mental status develops

scenarios.title: Critical Burns
symptoms: Severe burning sensation, charring of skin
Extreme redness and swelling, difficulty breathing
immediate_steps: Call 911 IMMEDIATELY if burn is life-threatening or cover more than 20% of body surface
Cool burn with cool water for 10-15 minutes, but do not immerse in water if unconscious or unable to move
Remove clothing around burned area carefully, taking care not to touch burnt skin
when_to_seek_help: Burn covers more than 20% of body surface
Severe pain, difficulty breathing, or loss of consciousness
Signs of infection, such as increased redness, swelling, or pus
do_not: Apply oil or butter to burn
Break blisters or scab over burned area
Use tourniquet or constrict clothing around burnt area
scenarios.additional_info: Monitor vital signs closely and seek medical help if fever develops or if symptoms worsen

scenarios.title: Senior Poisoning
immediate_steps: Call poison control hotline immediately
Stay with the person until help arrives
Do not attempt to give medications unless instructed by poison control
when_to_seek_help: Symptoms worsen or do not improve within 30 minutes
do_not: Take any medications without consulting poison control, especially blood thinners
scenarios.additional_info: Provide information about the substance ingested, including dosage and time of ingestion

scenarios.title: Adult Poisoning (Severe)
symptoms: Nausea and vomiting with bloody stools
Headache with severe confusion and disorientation
immediate_steps: Call 911 immediately for critical poisoning response
Provide person's location and information about the substance ingested to emergency responders
Administer CPR if the person is unresponsive, not breathing, or has no pulse
Do not attempt to treat symptoms at home; follow all instructions from poison control
when_to_seek_help: Symptoms worsen or do not improve within 30 minutes of ingestion
do_not: Take any medications without consulting poison control and following their instructions
Induce vomiting unless specifically instructed to do so by poison control
Administer any medications without medical supervision
scenarios.additional_info: Provide information about the substance ingested, including its quantity and time of ingestion, to poison control or emergency responders

scenarios.title: Elderly Ingests Medication
immediate_steps: Remain calm and assess the situation
Contact Poison Control immediately
Sit with the elderly person and provide support until help arrives
when_to_seek_help: If symptoms worsen or do not improve within 30 minutes
If the elderly person experiences difficulty breathing
do_not: Do not attempt to induce vomiting
Do not give any medications unless instructed by Poison Control
scenarios.additional_info: Monitor the elderly person's vital signs closely and report any changes to Poison Control

scenarios.title: Severe Poisoning from Household Cleaning Products
immediate_steps: Remove contaminated clothing and wash skin with soap and water IMMEDIATELY.
Flush eyes with plenty of water for at least 30 seconds.
Call 911 or Poison Control IMMEDIATELY if symptoms worsen or last longer than expected.
Administer antidote according to the product label or medical guidance.
Provide supportive care, including oxygen and cardiac monitoring.
Do not touch mouth or let person ingest anything after exposure.
do_not: Apply ice to the affected area
Give the person something to eat or drink
Use first aid kits without proper training
Administer any medication not recommended by Poison Control
scenarios.additional_info: Wear protective gloves when handling cleaning products.

scenarios.title: Severe Medication Poisoning
symptoms: Extreme dizziness, confusion, and loss of consciousness
Vomiting blood or coffee ground-like material
Severe headache with stiff neck and sensitivity to light
immediate_steps: Call 911 IMMEDIATELY. Do not wait for Poison Control.
Administer sodium bicarbonate IV if available, but only under medical guidance.
Monitor vital signs closely and prepare the patient for transport.
do_not: Try to treat symptoms at home. Call emergency services immediately.
Drink anything other than water or clear fluids until medical help arrives.
Take any medication without consulting a doctor.
scenarios.additional_info: Mixing medications with alcohol can lead to catastrophic consequences
scenarios.source: American Association of Poison Control Centers

scenarios.title: Snake Bite (Critical)
symptoms: Extremely painful bite site with difficulty moving affected limb
Excessive bleeding that won't stop with pressure
immediate_steps: Call 911 immediately and provide snake species information if known
Keep the person calm, still, and warm until medical help arrives
Do not attempt to suck out venom, apply a tourniquet, or use ice
Clean the wound with soap and water only if absolutely necessary
when_to_seek_help: Severe symptoms appear within 30 minutes of bite
do_not: Use antivenom without medical supervision
Apply a tight bandage or wrap to the affected area
scenarios.additional_info: Seek medical attention in the emergency room immediately

scenarios.title: Burn from Fireworks (65+)
immediate_steps: Flush the burn with cool water for 10-15 minutes, avoiding direct pressure on fragile bones
Apply a topical ointment to reduce pain and promote healing, avoiding harsh chemicals or soap
Cover the burn with a non-stick dressing, changing daily as needed
when_to_seek_help: Infection, increased redness or swelling, difficulty breathing
do_not: Break blisters, use harsh soap or cleansers, apply antibiotic ointment without doctor's advice
Disregard pain medication to manage burn pain
scenarios.additional_info: Medications like blood thinners may interact with burn care; consult doctor before treating.

scenarios.title: Severe Burn from Fireworks
immediate_steps: Flush the burn with cool water for 10-15 minutes, then call 911 immediately
Apply a topical ointment to reduce pain and promote healing, but only if instructed to do so by emergency medical personnel
Cover the burn with a non-stick dressing, but prioritize getting to the hospital
do_not: Break blisters
Use harsh soap or cleansers
Apply ice or apply a tourniquet
scenarios.additional_info: Do not delay seeking medical attention if symptoms worsen or do not improve.

scenarios.title: Hive Allergic Reaction (Elderly)
symptoms: Itchy skin on face and hands
immediate_steps: Apply antihistamine cream or hydrocortisone cream to affected areas with gentle massage
Take an oral antihistamine and sit upright to prevent choking
Use saline nasal spray while sitting upright
when_to_seek_help: Difficulty breathing, chest pain, or rapid heartbeat
Swelling of the face, lips, tongue, or throat
do_not: Rub the affected area with your hands, as this can worsen itching and swelling
Take any medication without consulting your doctor first, especially if you're on blood thinners or have kidney problems
scenarios.additional_info: Consult your doctor immediately if symptoms worsen or do not improve. Elderly individuals may be more susceptible to complications from hives.

scenarios.title: Hive Allergic Reaction (Severe)
symptoms: Itchy skin that cannot be relieved with antihistamines
Sudden swelling of the face, throat, and tongue
immediate_steps: Call 911 or your local emergency number immediately
Administer an epinephrine auto-injector (e.g. EpiPen) if available
Apply a cold compress to the affected area to reduce swelling
when_to_seek_help: Any severe symptoms that worsen over time
do_not: Rub the affected area with your hands
Take any medications without consulting a doctor first
Delay seeking medical attention for more than 15 minutes
scenarios.additional_info: Seek immediate medical attention if symptoms worsen or do not improve.

scenarios.title: Poisoning from Ingested Substance (Elderly)
immediate_steps: Call Poison Control immediately
Give water to drink in small amounts (1-2 ounces) every 10 minutes to avoid overhydration
when_to_seek_help: Loss of consciousness, seizures, or difficulty breathing
