do_not: Try to administer first aid at home without proper training; call for emergency assistance
Take any medications not prescribed by a healthcare professional
scenarios.additional_info: Elderly may be more susceptible to dehydration and electrolyte imbalances. Monitor vital signs closely.

scenarios.title: Critical Poisoning from Ingested Substance
symptoms: Severe nausea and vomiting, dizziness, confusion, rapid heartbeat, difficulty breathing, loss of consciousness
immediate_steps: Call 911 immediately for emergency assistance
Administer first aid by backslapping the victim's chest until they vomit (only do this if you've been instructed to by a medical professional)
Do not give the victim water to drink unless explicitly instructed to do so by emergency responders
when_to_seek_help: Any symptom, especially difficulty breathing or loss of consciousness
do_not: Delay calling for emergency assistance
Administer first aid at home without proper training
Try to treat the victim yourself until help arrives
scenarios.additional_info: Do not attempt to provide treatment until medical professionals arrive. The victim's life may be in danger.

scenarios.title: Critical Cut from Broken Glass
symptoms: Severe pain, swelling, bruising, difficulty moving the affected area
Excessive bleeding that doesn't stop with pressure
Visible signs of infection, such as increased redness, swelling, or pus
immediate_steps: Apply immediate pressure to the cut with a clean cloth or bandage and call 911 or your local emergency number. Do not delay.
Elevate the injured area above heart level, but do not remove any constrictive clothing
Clean the cut with mild soap and water, but avoid using harsh chemicals
when_to_seek_help: If symptoms worsen or do not improve within 30 minutes of treatment
If you experience difficulty breathing, dizziness, or fainting
If you notice signs of infection, such as increased redness, swelling, or pus
do_not: Do not attempt to clean the cut with harsh chemicals or apply tourniquets
Do not remove any constrictive clothing that may be wrapped around the injured area
scenarios.additional_info: If you are experiencing severe symptoms or if the cut is deep or bleeding heavily, seek immediate medical attention

scenarios.title: Button Battery Ingestion in Elderly (65+ years)
immediate_steps: Call the National Poison Data System (NPDS) or National Battery Ingestion Hotline (NBIH)
Administer activated charcoal
do_not: Force the battery out of the body
Try to induce vomiting
Give antacids without consulting a doctor
scenarios.additional_info: Seek medical attention immediately, as elderly patients are at risk of severe complications.

scenarios.title: Button Battery Ingestion in Elderly - Critical
immediate_steps: Call 911 immediately and inform the operator of a button battery ingestion
Administer activated charcoal as soon as possible
Monitor vital signs closely, including temperature, pulse, and blood pressure
when_to_seek_help: Seizures or loss of consciousness within 30 minutes of ingestion
Coma or unresponsiveness within 1 hour of ingestion
do_not: Force the battery out of the body under any circumstances
Try to induce vomiting, as it can cause more harm than good
scenarios.additional_info: Seek immediate medical attention if symptoms worsen or if there is any sign of cardiac arrest.

scenarios.title: Severe Eye Irritation from Cleaner
symptoms: severe eye irritation with discharge and redness
tearing and blurred vision that worsens over time
sensitivity to light, severe eye pain
immediate_steps: CALL 911 IMMEDIATELY FOR EMERGENCY ASSISTANCE
Flush eyes with large amounts of water for at least 20 minutes
Remove contact lenses if present and discard them
Apply a cool, wet compress to the eye and avoid heat or cold packs
Move to a well-ventilated area and rest
when_to_seek_help: Severe eye damage, vision loss, or prolonged blurred vision that lasts more than an hour
Difficulty breathing, rapid heartbeat, dizziness, or fainting
do_not: Apply heat or cold packs to the affected eye
Use any medication without consulting a doctor first
Share or consume food and drinks with contaminated hands

scenarios.title: Burned Hands in Elderly (65+)
immediate_steps: cool burn with cool water for 10 minutes, but avoid soaking
remove clothing and jewelry, taking care not to break bones
apply topical antibiotic ointment, but avoid using too much pressure
cover wound with a non-stick dressing, securing it with medical tape
seek medical attention if blisters don't heal or if you experience infection
when_to_seek_help: if symptoms worsen, don't improve, or if you have diabetes, poor circulation, or neuropathy
if you take medications that affect blood clotting or have a weakened immune system
do_not: use household cleaners on burn
apply ice directly to burn
break any jewelry or clothing on burned area without medical help

scenarios.title: Environmental Exposure (Critical)
symptoms: severe irritation to eyes, nose, or throat
coughing or wheezing with difficulty breathing
immediate_steps: CALL 911 IMMEDIATELY and provide location and description of the person
move the person out of exposure area immediately and to a safe location
remove contaminated clothing and shoes, and wash hands thoroughly with soap and water
administer oxygen if available, but only by trained medical professional
provide fresh air and ventilation, and monitor vital signs closely
when_to_seek_help: if symptoms worsen or last more than 30 minutes
if person shows signs of respiratory failure (severe difficulty breathing)
do_not: try to treat the person yourself with medications without medical training
administer epinephrine or other medications unless trained to do so
scenarios.additional_info: Seek immediate medical attention if symptoms are severe or worsening.

scenarios.title: Burn Scald from Hot Liquid (Elderly)
immediate_steps: Flush the burn with cool water for 10-15 minutes, avoiding immersion of hands in icy water.
Apply a topical antibiotic ointment and cover with a non-stick dressing, using clean hands.
Elevate the affected area above heart level, taking regular breaks to avoid numbness.
when_to_seek_help: signs of infection (increased redness, swelling, pain, or fever)
do_not: break blisters or scab over burn, as this can lead to infection and delayed healing.
use harsh soap, astringents, or wet dressings on the burned area
apply ice directly to the burn
scenarios.additional_info: Avoid using grease or oil on burns, as these can slow healing. Consider taking pain medication as directed by your doctor.

scenarios.title: Critical Burns from Hot Liquid Scalds
immediate_steps: Call 911 immediately. If unable to call, go to the nearest hospital.
Flush the burn with cool water for 10-15 minutes while keeping the wound elevated above heart level.
when_to_seek_help: any signs of infection (increased redness, swelling, or pain)
do_not: break blisters or scab over burn
apply antibiotic ointment without medical supervision
use harsh soap or cleanser on the wound
scenarios.additional_info: Avoid using grease or oil on burns, and never apply a tourniquet.

scenarios.title: Broken Arm (Elderly)
symptoms: Severe pain, swelling, and limited mobility, especially at night
immediate_steps: Stop activity immediately and apply the RICE principle (Rest, Ice, Compression, Elevation)
Immobilize the arm with a sling or splint, and elevate above heart level
Monitor for numbness or tingling in the hand or fingers
when_to_seek_help: Severe pain that doesn't improve with rest and medication, swelling or bruising
Difficulty moving the arm or using the hand
do_not: Try to move the arm or put weight on it, as this can dislocate the joint
Take acetaminophen or ibuprofen without consulting a doctor first
scenarios.additional_info: If the bone is displaced, seek medical attention promptly. Elderly patients are at risk of osteoporosis-related complications and may require surgical intervention.

scenarios.title: Severe Fracture of Arm
symptoms: Extreme pain, swelling, and limited mobility; difficulty moving arm or wrist; numbness or tingling in hand or fingers; coldness or paleness of the skin
immediate_steps: Call 911 immediately; if unable to call 911, call local emergency number
Apply a rigid splint or sling as tightly as possible and immobilize arm above heart level
Monitor for numbness or tingling in hand or fingers and report to medical staff
when_to_seek_help: Severe pain; swelling that is increasing rapidly; difficulty moving arm or wrist; numbness or tingling in hand or fingers; coldness or paleness of the skin
do_not: Try to move arm or put weight on it; attempt to straighten or bend arm
Apply ice, heat, compression, or elevation alone without medical supervision
scenarios.additional_info: If unable to call 911, find a trusted adult or caregiver and have them call 911 for you. If bone is displaced, seek immediate medical attention.

scenarios.title: Poisoning from Insect Bite in Elderly Patients
symptoms: Redness, swelling, and itching; possible bruising or discoloration
immediate_steps: Wash the affected area with soap and lukewarm water to prevent skin irritation
when_to_seek_help: Severe symptoms (difficulty breathing), fever above 101.5째F (38.6째C), swollen lymph nodes
do_not: Use topical ointments or apply heat, as this can worsen the reaction
scenarios.additional_info: If you experience dizziness, confusion, or rapid heartbeat, seek immediate medical attention.

scenarios.title: Severe Poisoning from Insect Bite
symptoms: Redness, swelling, itching, difficulty breathing, rapid heartbeat, dizziness, confusion, numbness or tingling in face, arms, or legs
Severe pain at the bite site
immediate_steps: Call 911 immediately
Wash the affected area with soap and water
Apply a cold compress or calamine lotion to reduce itching
Use epinephrine auto-injector (e.g. EpiPen) if available
Administer antihistamines and pain medication as directed
when_to_seek_help: Severe symptoms, difficulty breathing, rapid heartbeat, confusion, numbness or tingling in face, arms, or legs, swollen eyelids, lips, or tongue
do_not: Use topical ointments or apply heat
Drive or operate heavy machinery
Participate in strenuous activities
scenarios.additional_info: If you experience severe symptoms, call 911 and seek immediate medical attention.

scenarios.title: Choking on Food (Elderly)
symptoms: Difficulty breathing, gagging, or coughing, or feeling lightheaded or faint
immediate_steps: Encourage the person to cough and clear their airway slowly and carefully
Support the person's head and back while performing a backblow (backslap) if necessary
Perform the Heimlich maneuver with caution, taking care not to exacerbate any underlying medical conditions
when_to_seek_help: No coughing, gagging, or breathing, or showing signs of hypovolemic shock (e.g., pale skin, rapid heartbeat)
do_not: Try to remove the object yourself, as this can cause further injury
Administer oxygen without proper training and equipment
scenarios.additional_info: Continue CPR until emergency services arrive.

scenarios.title: Cut Laceration on Hand (65+)
symptoms: bleeding that doesn't stop with pressure
swelling, redness, or warmth around the wound
immediate_steps: Apply pressure with clean cloth for 10-15 minutes
Elevate the injured area above heart level to reduce swelling
Clean and dress the wound with antibiotic ointment and seek medical attention if symptoms worsen or don't improve within 24 hours
when_to_seek_help: if you're taking blood thinners or have a history of bleeding disorders
if you notice signs of infection (increased redness, swelling, warmth, or pus)
do_not: don't apply a tourniquet or ice to the wound
scenarios.additional_info: Consider seeking medical attention if you're unsure about the severity of your injury or have concerns about your overall health

scenarios.title: Severe Cut Laceration on Hand
symptoms: severe bleeding that doesn't stop with pressure
intense pain that's difficult to manage
numbness or tingling in the fingers
immediate_steps: Apply firm, direct pressure on the wound with a clean cloth for at least 10 minutes
Elevate the injured area above heart level and apply an ice pack wrapped in a cloth to reduce swelling
Call 911 immediately and provide as much detail as possible about the injury
do_not: Do not attempt to clean or dress the wound yourself
Do not apply any topical treatments without consulting a medical professional first
scenarios.additional_info: If the bleeding doesn't stop after 10 minutes of pressure, seek help immediately

scenarios.title: Burn to Face - Critical
immediate_steps: Call 911 immediately. Cool the burn with cool tap water for 5 minutes, then apply a topical antibiotic ointment and cover with non-stick dressing
Administer oxygen if available
Get patient to emergency room as soon as possible
when_to_seek_help: Signs of infection such as increased redness, swelling, or pus; Difficulty breathing; Seizures or loss of consciousness
do_not: Do not apply ice or use a tourniquet
scenarios.additional_info: Burns to the face can be life-threatening and require immediate medical attention

scenarios.title: Burn Scald (Elderly)
symptoms: Redness, swelling, and pain; may also include numbness, tingling, or decreased sensation
immediate_steps: Stop the burning process
Cool the burn with cool tap water (no ice, as it can cause further damage)
Remove clothing near the burned area, but avoid disrobing if it's a pressure ulcer risk
when_to_seek_help: Blisters or white patches form; seek immediate help if you experience difficulty walking or moving due to pain
do_not: Break blisters or scrape burnt skin, as this can lead to infection; avoid using harsh soap or cleanser on burned areas
Use a tourniquet or tight bandages, as this can cut off circulation
scenarios.additional_info: Burns in elderly may be more severe due to decreased sensation and reduced ability to move away from heat. Be cautious of pressure ulcers and ensure good blood flow to the affected area.

scenarios.title: Heat Stroke in the Elderly
symptoms: High body temperature, confusion, slurred speech, dizziness, rapid heartbeat
immediate_steps: Remove clothing, especially around the neck and waist
when_to_seek_help: Loss of consciousness, difficulty breathing, or severe dehydration
Taking certain medications (e.g., diuretics) that may increase risk
do_not: Give medication without medical help, as it may interact with existing meds
scenarios.additional_info: Elderly may be more susceptible to heat stroke due to decreased sweat glands' ability to cool the body. Check on vulnerable individuals regularly.

scenarios.title: Blunt Force Injury from Car Crash (Elderly)
immediate_steps: Apply gentle pressure to bleeding wounds
Immobilize the affected area using pillows or a splint
Elevate the injured limb above heart level, but be cautious of blood pooling
Call emergency services and ask for help with transportation if needed
when_to_seek_help: Confusion or disorientation that lasts longer than 15 minutes
do_not: Apply tourniquets or tight bandages
Disregard injuries and try to get up quickly
scenarios.additional_info: Monitor for signs of shock, bleeding, and decreased urine output
scenarios.base_scenario_id: Blunt Force Injury from Car Crash

scenarios.title: Severe Blunt Force Injury from Car Crash
immediate_steps: Apply CPR if unresponsive, start compressions immediately
Immobilize the affected area using a splint or sling, take control of the injured limb to prevent further injury
Elevate the injured limb above heart level and apply an ice pack or cold compress to reduce swelling and pain
Call emergency services (911) and provide your location immediately
Stay on the line with 911 dispatch and follow their instructions
when_to_seek_help: Severe numbness or weakness in limbs
do_not: Disregard injuries, seek medical attention immediately
scenarios.additional_info: Monitor for signs of shock and bleeding, check for airway patency and perform a head-to-toe assessment
scenarios.base_scenario_id: Blunt Force Injury from Car Crash

scenarios.title: Broken Finger from Car Accident in Elderly
symptoms: Swelling, bruising (can be a sign of poor circulation)
Limited mobility or numbness in hand or arm
immediate_steps: Immobilize the affected finger using a splint or bandage, avoiding disuse
Apply ice to reduce swelling and ease pain
Elevate the injured hand above heart level, with pillows for support
when_to_seek_help: Increasing pain or difficulty moving the finger (especially if accompanied by numbness or tingling)
Coldness or pale color of the skin
do_not: Disregard the injury and attempt to move or use the affected finger
Apply heat, which can worsen swelling and pain
scenarios.additional_info: Monitor for signs of infection, such as redness, warmth, or increased swelling

scenarios.title: Severe Finger Fracture from Car Accident
symptoms: Swelling and bruising that covers the entire finger
Loss of mobility, inability to straighten or bend the finger
immediate_steps: Call 911 immediately for emergency assistance
Immobilize the affected finger using a splint or bandage as quickly and securely as possible
Apply ice to reduce swelling and ease pain, but avoid direct contact with the injured area
when_to_seek_help: Any increase in pain or difficulty moving the finger
Coldness or numbness in the affected digit
Visible deformity or misalignment of the finger
do_not: Disregard the severity of the injury
Try to move or straighten the injured finger without proper immobilization
scenarios.additional_info: Monitor for signs of infection and potential nerve damage

scenarios.title: Burns from Car Crash (Elderly)
immediate_steps: Cool the burns with cool tap water for 10-15 minutes, avoiding immersion of joints or bones
Remove clothing and jewelry near the burn area, especially if elderly person has fragile bones or takes medications that may increase risk of infection
Apply a topical antibiotic ointment and cover with a non-stick dressing, but avoid applying too tightly as this can restrict blood flow
when_to_seek_help: Increasing pain or redness, especially if elderly person is immobile or has difficulty breathing
Signs of infection, such as increased swelling, pus, or fever
Difficulty moving or walking due to burns
do_not: Use heat or ice on the burns
Apply a tourniquet or restrict blood flow at the burn site
scenarios.additional_info: Monitor for signs of infection and potential complications, such as pneumonia or sepsis

scenarios.title: Severe Burns from Car Crash
symptoms: Severe redness and swelling that spreads beyond the initial burn area
Blisters filled with fluid, which may rupture and release pus
Pain that is excruciating and difficult to manage with medication
Difficulty breathing due to smoke inhalation
Abnormal heart rhythms or cardiac arrest
immediate_steps: Call 911 immediately and provide location
Remove clothing and jewelry near the burn area, but avoid breaking any blisters
Apply a topical antibiotic ointment and cover with a non-stick dressing, then move to a hospital
Cool the burns with cool tap water for 10-15 minutes, but be cautious not to break any blisters
when_to_seek_help: Any sign of difficulty breathing or cardiac distress
Increasing pain or redness that spreads beyond the initial burn area
Blisters that rupture and release pus
do_not: Use heat or ice on the burns, as this can cause further damage
Try to move someone with severe injuries unless they are in a life-threatening situation
scenarios.additional_info: Monitor for signs of infection and cardiac distress at all times

scenarios.title: Head Injury in Elderly
immediate_steps: Keep the person calm, quiet, and in a comfortable position.
Loosen any tight clothing or constrictive headgear.
Remove any jewelry around the neck.
when_to_seek_help: numbness or weakness in arms or legs
do_not: give medication without proper medical guidance and knowing current medications
move the person suddenly or vigorously
scenarios.additional_info: Monitor for signs of increased intracranial pressure, such as a change in mental status.

scenarios.title: Minor Cuts and Scrapes in Older Adults (65+)
immediate_steps: stop bleeding
clean wound with mild soap and lukewarm water
apply antibiotic ointment, but avoid too tight bandages as they can cut off circulation
when_to_seek_help: increased bleeding or difficulty stopping it
signs of infection (fever, chills, redness spreading)
wound won't stop bleeding after 10-15 minutes of pressure
do_not: tight bandages, which can reduce blood flow and worsen healing
using harsh soap, hydrogen peroxide, or iodine, as they can irritate skin
ignoring the wound for extended periods, as it may lead to infection
scenarios.additional_info: Monitor for signs of infection, especially in patients with diabetes, kidney disease, or immunocompromised conditions. Consider seeking help if patient is taking medications that may increase bleeding risk (e.g., anticoagulants)

scenarios.title: Severe Cuts and Lacerations
immediate_steps: stop bleeding IMMEDIATELY
clean wound thoroughly with soap and water
apply antibiotic ointment and cover with sterile bandage
call 911 or seek immediate medical attention
when_to_seek_help: bleeding does not stop after 10-15 minutes of pressure
signs of shock (cold skin, fast heart rate)
do_not: tight bandages that constrict wound
using harsh soap or hydrogen peroxide on open wounds
scenarios.additional_info: Monitor for signs of infection and shock. Do not delay seeking medical attention.

scenarios.title: Allergic Reactions in Elderly
immediate_steps: call 911 or emergency services
remove contact with allergen and sit down in a safe position
administer epinephrine (if trained) carefully, as they may have multiple medications
when_to_seek_help: chest pain or shortness of breath
do_not: using antihistamines without medical supervision, especially if taking blood thinners
ignoring symptoms and continuing with daily activities
scenarios.additional_info: Administering epinephrine can be lifesaving in elderly patients. Be cautious of potential interactions with medications.

scenarios.title: Severe Allergic Reactions (Anaphylaxis)
symptoms: hives that cover large areas of the body
itching that is severe and persistent
swelling of the face, lips, tongue, or throat
difficulty breathing or feeling of suffocation
immediate_steps: remove all contact with allergen and put on a mask to prevent inhalation
administer epinephrine via auto-injector (if trained) or seek immediate medical attention
when_to_seek_help: severe difficulty breathing or loss of consciousness
do_not: using antihistamines without medical supervision and without administering epinephrine
driving after symptoms appear
scenarios.additional_info: Administering epinephrine can be lifesaving, but only if done correctly. Seek immediate medical attention.

scenarios.title: Bites and Stings in Seniors
symptoms: swelling, especially on hands or feet
pain, numbness or tingling in extremities
immediate_steps: clean wound with mild soap and lukewarm water
apply antibiotic ointment and cover with breathable dressing
monitor for signs of infection, such as increased redness or swelling
do_not: using harsh soap
tight bandages that may cut off circulation
ignoring numbness or tingling
scenarios.additional_info: Certain areas of the body, such as hands and feet, are more susceptible to infection in seniors

scenarios.title: Heat-Related Illnesses in Elderly
immediate_steps: move to shaded area immediately
remove excess clothing, especially around neck and chest
administer cool water or ice packs wrapped in a cloth
do_not: using hot showers or baths
engaging in strenuous activities
scenarios.additional_info: Watch for signs of dehydration closely

scenarios.title: Critical Head Injury
immediate_steps: call 911 immediately and provide location
stop bleeding with gauze or a clean cloth, apply pressure if possible
immobilize neck and head with a sling, do not move injured person
administer oxygen if available, use a face mask if necessary
do_not: move injured person without proper equipment and training
administer medication, including painkillers
scenarios.additional_info: Prompt medical attention is critical to prevent long-term brain damage or death. Call 911 before attempting any first aid.

scenarios.title: Dehydration in Elderly
immediate_steps: drink water or an electrolyte-rich beverage slowly and in small amounts to avoid overhydration
rest in a cool, comfortable place and elevate legs if possible
apply cold compresses to pulse points, but avoid numbness or tingling
consider using assistive devices for walking
when_to_seek_help: severe dehydration symptoms, such as severe dizziness or fainting
no improvement after 2 hours of fluid intake, or if symptoms worsen
do_not: give aspirin or any medication without consulting doctor first, especially with blood thinners or diabetes medications
overhydrate by drinking too much fluid at once
scenarios.additional_info: Seek medical attention immediately if elderly patient shows signs of dehydration, such as confusion, disorientation, or loss of consciousness

scenarios.title: Dehydration - Severe
symptoms: dark urine with blood or sediment
severe dizziness, confusion, or loss of consciousness
immediate_steps: call 911 immediately and provide location and number of people affected
administer oral rehydration solution (ORS) if available, but only under medical guidance
lie person down in a cool, shaded area and elevate legs 12 inches above floor level
when_to_seek_help: any severe dehydration symptoms within the first hour of exposure
no improvement after 1 hour of fluid intake
do_not: give aspirin or any medication without consulting doctor first
use tourniquets, ice packs, or other treatments without proper medical training
scenarios.additional_info: Dehydration can lead to shock, organ failure, and death if left untreated. Do not attempt to treat on your own.

scenarios.title: Eye Injury in Elderly
immediate_steps: flush with lukewarm water for 5-10 minutes
apply antibiotic ointment (consult doctor before use)
cover eye with a protective shield or gauze, avoid rubbing or touching the injured area
when_to_seek_help: severe pain or vision loss, difficulty walking or balance issues
do_not: touch the injured area without gloves to avoid introducing infection
use harsh soap or hot water
scenarios.additional_info: Elderly may be more susceptible to complications from eye injuries. Seek medical attention immediately if symptoms worsen or do not improve with treatment.

scenarios.title: Severe Eye Injury
immediate_steps: call 911 immediately
apply firm pressure to the injured eye with a clean cloth or gauze for 10-15 minutes
cover eye with a protective shield or gauze
when_to_seek_help: any signs of infection, severe pain, or vision loss
do_not: touch the injured area without gloves
use soap or water to clean the eye
scenarios.additional_info: Seek emergency medical attention if symptoms worsen or do not improve with treatment

scenarios.title: Severe Burn Scald from Hot Surface
symptoms: Severe redness, swelling, blistering, and charring of the skin.
Burning pain, difficulty breathing, and inhalation of smoke or soot.
immediate_steps: Call emergency services immediately (911) and provide your location.
Remove burned clothing and jewelry, but do not attempt to wash the burn.
Cool the burn with cool tap water for no more than 10 minutes.
Apply a topical antibiotic ointment to prevent infection, if available.
when_to_seek_help: Any burn that covers an area larger than 5% of your body surface area, blisters that are large or multiple, fever over 104째F (40째C), chills, shortness of breath, or difficulty breathing, or loss of consciousness.
do_not: Break blisters with your fingers.
Use home remedies such as butter or egg whites to promote healing.
Apply ice or ice water to the burn.
scenarios.additional_info: If you are unconscious or experiencing difficulty breathing, call 911 first and then follow these steps. If the burn is on the face, neck, or hands, seek immediate medical attention.

scenarios.title: Pet Bites/Scratches in Seniors (65+)
symptoms: Pain, swelling, bruising at the bite or scratch site
immediate_steps: Wash the bite or scratch with mild soap and lukewarm water.
Apply a thin layer of antibiotic ointment to prevent infection.
Monitor for signs of infection, such as increased redness, swelling, or bruising.
when_to_seek_help: Increased redness, swelling, bruising, fever over 100.4째F (38째C), difficulty breathing
do_not: Try to suck out the venom with a clean cloth or object.
Apply a tourniquet to restrict blood flow.
scenarios.additional_info: People 65+, especially those with osteoporosis, may be at risk of fractures from pet bites or scratches. Seek medical attention if you experience severe pain, swelling, or bruising.

scenarios.title: Pet Bites/Scratches (Critical)
symptoms: Severe redness, swelling, pain, bruising, and discoloration
immediate_steps: Call 911 immediately.
Wash the bite or scratch with soap and water as quickly as possible.
when_to_seek_help: Any signs of infection, such as increased redness, swelling, pus, fever over 103째F (39.4째C), difficulty breathing, rapid heartbeat, pale skin
do_not: Try to suck out the venom with a clean cloth or object.
Apply a tourniquet to restrict blood flow.
scenarios.additional_info: If you are experiencing severe symptoms, do not wait for further evaluation - proceed directly to emergency room care if possible. If unable to reach medical help, try to remain calm and still until assistance arrives.

scenarios.title: Dog/Animal Poisoning in Elderly Patients
immediate_steps: Call the ASPCA's Animal Poison Control Center at (888) 426-4435 or your local poison control center for assistance.
when_to_seek_help: Seizures, difficulty breathing, collapse, signs of dehydration (excessive thirst, dark urine)
do_not: Administer CPR if your pet is unresponsive and not breathing; seek immediate medical attention.
Give your pet any medications without consulting a veterinarian first.
scenarios.additional_info: Elderly patients may be more susceptible to medication interactions and underlying health conditions. Be aware of any ongoing medications, including blood thinners, diabetes medications, and blood pressure medications.

scenarios.title: Dog Sprains/Strains in Elderly Patients (65+)
symptoms: Increased pain, difficulty walking, or using the affected limb
Swelling that is painful to touch or moves with movement
immediate_steps: Apply ice pack to reduce swelling (5-10 minutes) and then seek medical attention if symptoms worsen.
Elevate the affected limb above heart level, but avoid numbness or tingling.
when_to_seek_help: Increased pain, swelling, redness, or difficulty walking
do_not: Overstretch or immobilize the injured area without consulting a veterinarian.
Use a sling or cast without medical supervision, as this may worsen underlying health conditions.
scenarios.additional_info: Elderly patients may have underlying health conditions that make them more susceptible to complications. Seek immediate medical attention if symptoms worsen or do not improve with rest and ice.

scenarios.title: Dog Sprains/Strains - Critical
symptoms: Severe limp, extreme swelling, pain that won't subside, difficulty breathing
immediate_steps: Apply an ice pack to reduce swelling while carefully immobilizing the affected limb with a splint.
Elevate the affected limb above heart level and immediately seek veterinary attention.
Administer a 1mg/kg dose of carprofen (Rimadyl) orally or as directed by a veterinarian for pain management
when_to_seek_help: Severe symptoms, difficulty breathing, fainting, collapse
Redness, swelling, increased pain, and warmth around the injury site
do_not: Overstretch or immobilize the injured area without proper splinting.
Use a sling or cast without consulting a veterinarian first.
scenarios.additional_info: If your dog is showing signs of shock ( pale gums, rapid heartbeat), call emergency services immediately. A clear and concise description of your dog's symptoms to the operator will ensure prompt assistance.

scenarios.title: Household Chemical Burns (Elderly)
symptoms: Confusion, dizziness, rapid heartbeat, slurred speech, weakness
immediate_steps: Flush the affected area with cool tap water for at least 15 minutes.
Remove contaminated clothing and jewelry, but avoid breaking blisters or scratching the affected skin.
when_to_seek_help: Blisters that are large or multiple, fever over 100.4째F (38째C), chills, difficulty breathing
do_not: Take any medications without consulting a doctor first.
Apply ice or heat to the affected area.
scenarios.additional_info: Certain medications can interact with each other when burned. Inform your doctor before seeking treatment.

scenarios.title: Allergic Reaction (Pet) in Elderly
immediate_steps: Call your primary care physician or a pet poison hotline for advice.
when_to_seek_help: Difficulty breathing, severe dizziness, or fainting
do_not: Use over-the-counter medications without consulting your doctor first.
Apply topical corticosteroids to the face or sensitive areas without medical guidance.
scenarios.additional_info: Elderly individuals may be more susceptible to allergic reactions due to age-related changes in their immune system.

scenarios.title: Severe Allergic Reaction (Pet)
immediate_steps: Call 911 IMMEDIATELY and have someone administer epinephrine injector (EpiPen) if available.
Administer antihistamines and/or steroids as advised by a veterinarian or medical professional.
do_not: Wait for symptoms to resolve on their own. Immediate medical attention is required.
Use epinephrine injectors unless advised by a veterinarian or medical professional.
scenarios.additional_info: Seek help from a pet emergency clinic or veterinary hospital if possible.

scenarios.title: Seizure (Pet) in Elderly
immediate_steps: Place your pet on their side to prevent choking.
Loosen tight clothing around the neck and throat.
when_to_seek_help: Seizures lasting longer than 5 minutes, difficulty breathing, or vomiting blood
do_not: Try to stop the seizure by holding your pet's head or forcing them to breathe.
Administer any medication without consulting a veterinarian first.
Get up from a fall if you are able, as this can lead to further injury.
scenarios.additional_info: Elderly pets may have underlying medical conditions that can exacerbate seizures. Consult with your veterinarian before administering any medication.

scenarios.title: Overdose (Elderly Pet)
immediate_steps: Call the ASPCA's Animal Poison Control Center at (888) 426-4435 or your local veterinary emergency number.
Provide your pet's name, age, weight, and the type of substance ingested to the veterinarian or veterinary staff.
Do not induce vomiting unless advised by a veterinarian.
do_not: Give your elderly pet any medications without consulting a veterinarian first, as they may interact with their current medications or have adverse effects.
Administer CPR if your elderly pet is unresponsive and not breathing, as they may be frail and vulnerable to injury.
scenarios.additional_info: Elderly pets may experience more severe symptoms due to age-related health conditions. Be cautious when handling or administering care to prevent further harm.

scenarios.title: Pet Heatstroke in Elderly
immediate_steps: Move your pet to a cooler location immediately.
Remove excess clothing and provide cool water for drinking.
Apply a cooling pad or wet cloth to the affected area.
when_to_seek_help: Loss of coordination, dizziness, high blood pressure
do_not: Try to revive your pet by applying heat.
Use ice packs or refrigerate your pet without consulting a veterinarian first.
scenarios.additional_info: Elderly pets are more susceptible to heatstroke due to age-related medical conditions. If you suspect your elderly pet has heatstroke, contact your veterinarian immediately.

scenarios.title: Critical Pet Heatstroke
symptoms: Severe lethargy, rapid breathing, excessive drooling, dark urine, seizures, loss of consciousness
immediate_steps: Call 911 IMMEDIATELY and follow instructions. Move your pet to a shaded area or indoors if possible.
Remove excess clothing, wet the pet's skin with cool water, and provide ice packs wrapped in towels to reduce body temperature.
Apply a cooling pad or wet cloth to the affected area while keeping your pet calm.
when_to_seek_help: Severe vomiting, inability to breathe, collapse, or loss of consciousness
do_not: Try to revive your pet by applying heat.
Use ice packs or refrigerate your pet without consulting a veterinarian first.
Administer any medication yourself.
scenarios.additional_info: Heatstroke can be fatal. Every minute counts. Seek immediate veterinary attention if symptoms persist or worsen.

scenarios.title: Dog Head Injury (Elderly)
immediate_steps: Call emergency services immediately.
Sit or lie down in a comfortable position until help arrives.
when_to_seek_help: Increased pain, swelling, or redness, difficulty breathing, rapid heartbeat, dizziness
do_not: Try to walk or move the injured area.
Take any medication without consulting a doctor first.

scenarios.title: Dog Head Injury (Severe/Critical)
immediate_steps: Apply a cold compress to reduce swelling.
Elevate the affected area above heart level.
Monitor for signs of infection, such as increased redness or swelling.
Call 911 immediately and provide your location.
Do not move the dog unless absolutely necessary
Keep the dog calm and quiet until medical help arrives
when_to_seek_help: Any sign of severe injury, such as difficulty breathing, unconsciousness, or seizures
Increased swelling or bruising that is spreading beyond the initial area
do_not: Move the dog unless absolutely necessary.
Use a sling or cast without consulting a veterinarian first.
Administer any medication without consulting a veterinarian first.

scenarios.title: Dog Eye Injury (Elderly)
symptoms: Blurred vision, sensitivity to light, eye pain
immediate_steps: Call a family member or caregiver for assistance.
Apply a cold compress to the affected area for 5-10 minutes.
Avoid touching or rubbing the eye.
when_to_seek_help: Vision changes, increased sensitivity to light, severe pain
do_not: Try to flush your pet's eyes without consulting a veterinarian first.
Use soap or shampoo on your pet's eyes, as this can further irritate the eye.

scenarios.title: Dog Burns in Elderly
symptoms: Redness, swelling, blistering (may not be as noticeable due to decreased sensation)
Fever over 100.5째F (38째C) may be less severe in elderly
immediate_steps: Flush the burn with cool tap water for at least 15 minutes, but avoid soaking
Remove contaminated clothing and jewelry carefully to avoid further irritation
Apply a topical antibiotic ointment, but avoid using too much pressure
when_to_seek_help: Blisters that are large or multiple, fever over 101.5째F (38.6째C), chills, difficulty breathing
Signs of infection such as increased redness, swelling, or pus
do_not: Break blisters with your fingers to avoid further irritation and potential for infection
Use home remedies such as butter or egg whites to promote healing (may not be suitable for elderly)
Apply a tourniquet or tight bandage around the affected area, as this can restrict blood flow

scenarios.title: Dog Burns (Severe)
symptoms: Severe redness, swelling, blistering; blackened skin; difficulty breathing or swallowing
immediate_steps: IMMEDIATELY CALL 911! If unavailable, call local emergency number. Remove contaminated clothing and jewelry.
Flush the burn with cool tap water for at least 20 minutes. Do not use hot water.
when_to_seek_help: Any sign of systemic infection (e.g., fever over 103째F (39.4째C), chills, nausea/vomiting). Blisters that are large or multiple
Severe breathing difficulties or inability to breathe.
do_not: Break blisters with your fingers.
Use home remedies such as butter or egg whites to promote healing.
scenarios.additional_info: Burns from dog bites can be life-threatening. Seek immediate medical attention even if symptoms seem minor.

scenarios.title: Anaphylactic Shock (Human)
symptoms: Constriction of airways, difficulty breathing, rapid heartbeat, pale skin, confusion, seizures
immediate_steps: Call emergency services immediately and inform them of anaphylaxis. Use the phone's emergency button if available.
Administer epinephrine injectors (e.g., EpiPen) according to device instructions and recommended by medical professionals.
Provide CPR if trained, but only after administering epinephrine injectors.
do_not: Administer any medication without consulting medical professionals first.
Use epinephrine injectors unless advised by medical professionals.
Delay calling emergency services for more than 5 minutes.

scenarios.title: Cardiac Arrest in Elderly
symptoms: Pale skin, cold hands and feet, confusion, or loss of consciousness
immediate_steps: Call emergency services immediately.
Use an automated external defibrillator (AED) if available and trained to use it.
do_not: Try to revive your elderly loved one yourself. Call for help immediately.
Use CPR without proper training. Elderly patients may have underlying medical conditions that require specialized care.
scenarios.additional_info: Elderly patients may experience different symptoms and require special consideration. Take steps to prevent falls and injuries during emergency response.

scenarios.title: Seizure (Elderly)
symptoms: Loss of consciousness, confusion, difficulty speaking
immediate_steps: Place the person on their side to prevent choking and ensure clear airway.
Loosen tight clothing around the neck and throat.
Turn them onto their back if necessary, and support their head and neck.
when_to_seek_help: Incontinence, difficulty breathing, seizures that last longer than 5 minutes
do_not: Try to stop the seizure by holding your pet's head or forcing them to breathe.
Administer any medication without consulting medical professionals first.
scenarios.additional_info: Consider the person's pre-existing conditions and medications when providing care.

scenarios.title: Seizure (Human) - Critical
symptoms: Convulsions, loss of consciousness, difficulty breathing, incontinence, vomiting
Eye roll back, tongue fall out, drooling, stiffening of the body
immediate_steps: Call 911 immediately and place the person on their side to prevent choking.
Loosen tight clothing around the neck and throat, and remove any constrictive items.
Clear the area of any objects that could cause injury if moved
Do not attempt to hold the person down or restrain them.
when_to_seek_help: Any sign of seizure activity, including eye roll back or tongue fall out
Incontinence, vomiting, seizures that last longer than 5 minutes
do_not: Try to stop the seizure by holding your pet's head or forcing them to breathe.
Administer any medication without consulting medical professionals first.
scenarios.additional_info: Seizures can be a sign of a serious underlying condition. Do not attempt to treat the person until help arrives.

scenarios.title: Overdose (Elderly)
immediate_steps: Call emergency services immediately.
Provide information about the substance ingested to medical professionals and inform them of any medications currently being taken.
Do not administer activated charcoal unless advised by medical professionals.
do_not: Give any medication without consulting medical professionals first.
Administer CPR if your loved one is unresponsive and not breathing.
scenarios.additional_info: Elderly individuals may be more susceptible to dehydration due to decreased thirst sensation. Monitor for signs of dehydration such as dark urine, decreased urine output, or dizziness.

scenarios.title: Heat Exhaustion (Elderly)
immediate_steps: Move the person to a cooler location immediately and sit them down.
Remove excess clothing, provide cool water for drinking, and avoid strenuous activities.
Apply a cooling pad or wet cloth to the face, neck, and wrists.
when_to_seek_help: Loss of consciousness, severe headache, stiff muscles
do_not: Try to revive your elderly person by applying heat.
Use ice packs or refrigerate your elderly person without consulting medical professionals first.

scenarios.title: Heatstroke (Human) - Critical
symptoms: Extreme lethargy, rapid shallow breathing, excessive drooling, confusion, seizures, muscle weakness
immediate_steps: Call emergency services (911) immediately. Find a cooler location and turn the person onto their side to help them breathe.
Remove excess clothing and provide cool water for drinking. Apply a cooling pad or wet cloth to the affected area as quickly as possible.
Stay with the person and monitor their condition closely.
when_to_seek_help: High fever, seizures, vomiting blood or bile, rapid heart rate, difficulty breathing
do_not: Try to revive your pet by applying heat. Do not attempt to administer medication without consulting medical professionals first.
Use ice packs or refrigerate your pet.
scenarios.additional_info: Heatstroke is a life-threatening condition that requires immediate medical attention. If you are unsure about what to do, err on the side of caution and call for emergency help.

scenarios.title: Dog Heatstroke in Elderly Patients
immediate_steps: Move your pet to a cooler location immediately and call for veterinary help.
Provide cool water for drinking and check blood sugar levels (if prescribed).
Apply a cooling pad or wet cloth to the affected area with caution to avoid slipping hazards.
when_to_seek_help: Increased heart rate, vomiting, seizures, difficulty breathing
do_not: Try to revive your pet by applying heat, as this can worsen condition.
Use ice packs or refrigerate your pet without consulting medical professionals first, as this can cause frostbite.

scenarios.title: Dog Heatstroke (Critical)
symptoms: Extreme lethargy, rapid shallow breathing, excessive drooling, sunken eyes, pale gums
immediate_steps: Call 911 IMMEDIATELY and provide your location. Move your pet to a cooler location as quickly as possible.
Remove excess clothing and provide cool water for drinking. Use a fan or other cooling device on low setting.
Apply a cooling pad or wet cloth to the affected area, but avoid direct contact with skin.
when_to_seek_help: Increased heart rate (>200 bpm), vomiting, seizures, collapse, unconsciousness
do_not: Try to revive your pet by applying heat, as this can worsen symptoms.
Use ice packs or refrigerate your pet without consulting medical professionals first. Ice can cause further harm.
scenarios.additional_info: Heatstroke is a life-threatening condition that requires immediate veterinary attention. Prompt treatment can help prevent organ damage and improve survival rates.

scenarios.title: Hypoglycemia in Elderly Patients
immediate_steps: Call emergency services or seek immediate medical attention if symptoms worsen or unable to administer glucose on own.
Administer glucose tablets or a glucose solution according to doctor's instructions, but only if able to do so safely and without assistance.
Have someone assist with administration and provide constant support until recovery is complete.
do_not: Administer glucose if unable to do so safely, as this can cause more harm.
Drive or perform tasks that require focus until glucose levels are stable.

scenarios.title: Dog Hypoglycemia - Critical
immediate_steps: Administer glucose tablets or a glucose solution according to veterinarian instructions immediately.
Call 911 and seek emergency veterinary care immediately.
Keep your pet calm and warm in a safe location until help arrives.
when_to_seek_help: Increased thirst, vomiting, seizures, difficulty breathing
Pawing at the mouth, drooling, confusion
do_not: Administer any medication without consulting a veterinarian first.
Use epinephrine injectors unless advised by a veterinarian.
Try to give your pet anything to eat or drink until help arrives.
scenarios.additional_info: Hypoglycemia in dogs can be life-threatening if left untreated. Every minute counts, so do not delay seeking emergency veterinary care.

scenarios.title: Dog Dehydration in Elderly Patients
immediate_steps: Administer a subcutaneous fluid replacement according to veterinarian instructions.
Monitor the pet's condition closely for at least an hour after administration.
Keep your pet calm and warm until recovery is complete.
Consider consulting with your primary care physician or a geriatric specialist for guidance
when_to_seek_help: Increased thirst, vomiting, seizures, difficulty breathing
Severe dizziness or fainting spells that don't improve with fluid replacement
do_not: Administer any medication without consulting a veterinarian first.
Use epinephrine injectors unless advised by a veterinarian.
Overexert your pet while recovering from dehydration

scenarios.title: Dog Dehydration - Critical
symptoms: Severe dry mouth, excessive thirst, vomiting, lethargy, seizures, rapid heartbeat, pale gums, and sunken eyes
immediate_steps: Call emergency services (911) immediately and administer a subcutaneous fluid replacement according to veterinarian instructions.
Perform CPR if the pet stops breathing or has no pulse. Continue CPR until paramedics arrive.
Administer oxygen therapy as directed by a veterinarian, if available.
when_to_seek_help: Increased thirst, vomiting, seizures, rapid heartbeat, pale gums, sunken eyes
do_not: Administer any medication without consulting a veterinarian first. Do not delay seeking help for more than 30 minutes.
Use epinephrine injectors unless advised by a veterinarian. Do not attempt to treat with adrenaline.
scenarios.additional_info: Dehydration can lead to serious complications, including organ failure and death. Immediate veterinary attention is critical.

scenarios.title: Dog Bloat in Elderly Patients (65+)
symptoms: Difficulty swallowing, regurgitation of food, bloating, confusion, dizziness
immediate_steps: Administer an anti-emetic medication according to veterinarian instructions and monitor for potential interactions with existing medications.
Provide your pet with a dry, easy-to-swallow diet for at least 24 hours and consider a homemade diet if needed.
Monitor the pet's condition closely for signs of complications and be aware of potential dehydration risks.
when_to_seek_help: Vomiting blood, difficulty breathing, abdominal pain, loss of consciousness
do_not: Give any medication without consulting a veterinarian first and consider consulting with your primary care physician before administering any treatment.
Use epinephrine injectors unless advised by a veterinarian and be aware of potential interactions with existing medications.

scenarios.title: Dog Bloat - Critical
symptoms: Severe difficulty swallowing, regurgitation of food, severe bloating leading to abdominal distension
immediate_steps: Administer an anti-emetic medication according to veterinarian instructions immediately.
Provide your pet with a dry, easy-to-swallow diet and administer oxygen via nasal cannula or mask if symptoms worsen.

Call 911 (or local emergency number) and provide critical information: 'Dog experiencing severe gastrointestinal distress. Administering medication, providing oxygen. Please dispatch emergency services immediately.'
when_to_seek_help: Vomiting blood, difficulty breathing, abdominal pain, decreased consciousness or collapse
No improvement after administering medication and supportive care within 1 hour
do_not: Give any medication without consulting a veterinarian first.
Use epinephrine injectors unless advised by a veterinarian.

scenarios.title: Dog Paralysis in the Elderly
symptoms: Weakness, numbness or tingling in extremities
immediate_steps: Call a veterinary emergency service immediately.
Provide information about the pet's symptoms and medical history to veterinary professionals.
when_to_seek_help: Increased weakness, loss of speech or vision
do_not: Try to revive your pet by applying heat or cold.
Use CPR without proper training.
Drive yourself to the vet if you're experiencing symptoms
Take pain medication that may interact with other medications

scenarios.title: Dog Paralysis (Critical)
symptoms: Weakness, paralysis, lack of sensation, difficulty breathing, seizures, loss of consciousness
immediate_steps: Call 911 immediately and provide information about your pet's symptoms.
Administer epinephrine via auto-injector (if available) and begin CPR if trained to do so.
Do not attempt to revive your pet or move them unless absolutely necessary.
when_to_seek_help: Seizures lasting > 30 seconds, loss of consciousness
do_not: Try to revive your pet by applying heat or cold.
Use CPR without proper training.
Administer any medications without veterinary guidance.
scenarios.additional_info: In cases of suspected spinal cord injury, DO NOT move the pet unless absolutely necessary. Secure the neck and head in a stable position to prevent further injury.

scenarios.title: Dog Poisoning (Elderly)
immediate_steps: Call emergency services immediately and provide information about the substance ingested to medical professionals.
Do not administer any medication without consulting your doctor first.
do_not: Try to induce vomiting unless advised by medical professionals.
Administer CPR if you are unsure or untrained
Drive yourself to the hospital or emergency services.

scenarios.title: Dog Poisoning - Critical
symptoms: Vomiting, diarrhea, lethargy, seizures, difficulty breathing, collapse, pale gums, rapid heartbeat, and irregular breathing
immediate_steps: Call 911 IMMEDIATELY and provide your location to the dispatcher.
Administer activated charcoal if recommended by medical professionals and only if you have prior experience with pet poisoning.
Provide information about the substance ingested to medical professionals and seek immediate attention.
when_to_seek_help: Seizures, difficulty breathing, collapse, pale gums, rapid heartbeat, irregular breathing
do_not: Give any medication without consulting a veterinarian or poison control hotline first.
Administer CPR if your pet is unresponsive and not breathing. CPR should only be performed by trained professionals.
scenarios.additional_info: If your dog is experiencing any of these symptoms, seek immediate veterinary attention. Antivenom may be necessary in severe cases. Keep the substance ingested and its packaging in case medical professionals need this information.

scenarios.title: Dog Trauma (Elderly)
immediate_steps: Apply gentle pressure to stop bleeding using a clean cloth or gauze.
Call a veterinarian or emergency animal service immediately.
Sit or lie down with the pet if it's injured to prevent further injury.
when_to_seek_help: Increased pain, swelling, redness, difficulty breathing, signs of shock (cooling, pale gums)
If you have a pre-existing medical condition, consult your doctor before seeking help
do_not: Try to revive your pet by applying heat or using ice packs without consulting a veterinarian first.
Give medication to the pet without consulting a veterinarian.

scenarios.title: Burns in the Elderly
symptoms: Redness, swelling, blistering; pain, numbness, or tingling
immediate_steps: Flush the burn with cool tap water for at least 15 minutes; avoid hot showers.
Remove contaminated clothing and jewelry, and loosen tight clothing.
Apply a topical antibiotic ointment to prevent infection; use a non-stick dressing if possible.
when_to_seek_help: Blisters that are large or multiple, fever over 100.4째F (37.8째C), chills, dizziness, or confusion
do_not: Break blisters with your fingers; use home remedies such as butter or egg whites to promote healing.
scenarios.additional_info: Burns in the elderly can be more serious due to age-related changes in skin and circulation.

scenarios.title: Dog Burns from Fire - Critical
symptoms: Severe redness, swelling, blistering, charring of skin and fur, potential exposure to toxic fumes
immediate_steps: Call 911 immediately for emergency assistance. Administer first aid until paramedics arrive.
Flush the burn with cool tap water for at least 15 minutes while also providing oxygen if possible.
Remove contaminated clothing and jewelry as soon as safely possible, without delaying medical attention.
when_to_seek_help: Any signs of severe burns, difficulty breathing, dizziness or fainting, chills, fever over 102째F (39째C)
do_not: Break blisters with your fingers.
Use home remedies such as butter or egg whites to promote healing.
Apply any topical ointment without consulting a medical professional first.
scenarios.additional_info: Potential exposure to toxic substances, ensure ventilation in the affected area.

scenarios.title: Eye Injury from Fire in Elderly
immediate_steps: Apply a clean cloth or gauze to the affected area and sit comfortably.
Flush with cool tap water for at least 5 minutes, then seek medical attention.
when_to_seek_help: Increased pain, vision changes, discharge from the eye
do_not: Try to flush your own eyes without consulting a doctor first.
Use soap or shampoo on your eyes. This can push bacteria further into the eye.
scenarios.additional_info: Elderly individuals may be more susceptible to eye infections due to age-related changes in the eye and immune system. It's essential to seek medical attention promptly if symptoms persist or worsen.

scenarios.title: Dog Wound from Fire - Critical
symptoms: Severe bleeding, profuse swelling, bruising, blackened skin, charred fur
immediate_steps: Call 911 IMMEDIATELY and provide your location.
Apply firm pressure to the wound with a clean cloth or gauze for at least 10 minutes to stop bleeding.
Provide your pet's breed, size, age, and weight to emergency responders.
when_to_seek_help: Severe pain, swelling, redness, fever over 103째F (39.4째C), difficulty breathing, decreased responsiveness
do_not: Try to revive your pet by applying heat or attempting CPR without proper training.
Use ice packs or refrigerate your pet without consulting a veterinarian first.
scenarios.additional_info: Do not wait for symptoms to worsen before seeking help. Every minute counts in critical situations like this.

scenarios.title: Minor Cuts and Scrapes in Elderly Patients (65+)
immediate_steps: Apply clean gauze to the wound, and secure with a bandage if necessary.
Elevate the affected area above heart level, but avoid extreme positions that may worsen circulation.
Clean and disinfect the wound with soap and water, being cautious not to disrupt any medical devices.
when_to_seek_help: showing signs of infection (increased redness, swelling, or pus)
do_not: pushing, taping, or binding the wound too tightly
scenarios.additional_info: Monitor for signs of deep vein thrombosis, and report to your doctor if symptoms persist.

scenarios.title: Life-Threatening Wounds
symptoms: severe bleeding, swelling, redness, difficulty breathing, pale or cool skin
immediate_steps: Call 911 immediately. Do not attempt to treat the wound yourself.
Apply firm pressure to the wound with a clean gauze to control bleeding.
Elevate the affected area above heart level and immobilize the limb if possible.
when_to_seek_help: Any sign of severe bleeding, difficulty breathing, or severe swelling.
do_not: pushing, taping, or binding the wound
administering any medication without medical supervision
scenarios.additional_info: Seek immediate medical attention if you experience any of the above symptoms.

scenarios.title: Bleeding from a Wound in Elderly
symptoms: excessive bleeding, pale skin, dizziness, lightheadedness
immediate_steps: Apply firm pressure to the wound with a clean gauze or cloth for 5-10 minutes.
Elevate the affected area above heart level, but avoid bending or lifting.
Clean and disinfect the wound with soap and water, avoiding excessive force.
when_to_seek_help: if bleeding doesn't stop after 15 minutes of pressure
do_not: removing the source of bleeding
using tourniquets or constrictive devices
scenarios.additional_info: Use hemostatic agents like QuikClot if available, but only if able to apply safely.

scenarios.title: Severe Bleeding from a Wound
symptoms: excessive, life-threatening bleeding, pale skin, rapid heartbeat, shortness of breath, cool or clammy skin, loss of consciousness
immediate_steps: Apply firm pressure to the wound with a clean gauze or cloth for 5-10 minutes, then call 911 immediately.
Elevate the affected area above heart level.
Clean and disinfect the wound with soap and water.
Administer oxygen if available.
Use hemostatic agents like QuikClot if available.
Prepare to transport patient to nearest hospital.
Call for emergency medical services (EMS) before transporting patient.
Do not remove source of bleeding
Do not apply tourniquet unless trained in use
Do not delay calling 911
when_to_seek_help: Immediately seek help if symptoms appear or worsen over time
do_not: removing the source of bleeding, delaying calling 911
applying a tourniquet unless trained in its use
scenarios.additional_info: Use hemostatic agents like QuikClot if available.

scenarios.title: Broken Bones in Elderly
symptoms: pain, swelling, bruising, limited mobility, numbness or tingling in hands and feet
immediate_steps: Immobilize the affected area with a splint or sling, take pain medication as directed.
Apply ice packs to reduce pain and swelling, elevate legs above hip level.
when_to_seek_help: difficulty moving the limb, severe pain, difficulty breathing
numbness or tingling in face, arms, or legs
do_not: bending or moving the affected joint without medical guidance
ignoring numbness or tingling symptoms
scenarios.additional_info: Elderly patients may be more susceptible to falls and fractures. Seek medical attention immediately for suspected fractures.

scenarios.title: Critical Fractures
symptoms: severe pain, swelling, bruising, limited mobility, numbness, tingling, weakness in the affected limb, pale or cool skin
immediate_steps: Call 911 immediately and provide location and injury description to emergency services.
Apply ice packs to reduce pain and swelling, but do not move the patient.
when_to_seek_help: difficulty moving the limb, severe pain, numbness or tingling, weak pulse
do_not: bending or moving the affected joint
removing any casts, splints, or bandages
scenarios.additional_info: Seek immediate medical attention for suspected fractures. Do not attempt to treat at home.

scenarios.title: Burns and Blistering in Elderly
symptoms: slow healing, increased risk of infection, pain, swelling
immediate_steps: Cool the burn with cool tap water for 10-15 minutes, but be cautious not to shock the body.
Loosen tight clothing and jewelry near the burned area to prevent further irritation.
when_to_seek_help: burning sensation, difficulty breathing, or signs of infection (increased redness, swelling, or pus)
do_not: using water above 100째F (38째C) or applying topical treatments without medical supervision
scenarios.additional_info: Elderly may be more susceptible to hypovolemic shock; seek immediate medical attention if symptoms worsen or do not improve with treatment.

scenarios.title: Severe Burns and Blistering
symptoms: extreme redness, swelling, intense pain, blistering, charring, difficulty breathing, rapid heartbeat, dizziness, nausea
immediate_steps: Call 911 or your local emergency number immediately. If you are in a remote area with no cell service, try to find someone to call for you.
Remove any clothing or jewelry near the burned area and apply a non-stick dressing as tight as possible.
Apply a topical antibiotic ointment only if the burn is not life-threatening.
when_to_seek_help: any sign of inhalation, severe difficulty breathing, rapid heartbeat, dizziness, nausea, or loss of consciousness
do_not: using water above 100째F (38째C)
immobilizing the burned area with a tight bandage
ignoring signs of shock or severe pain
scenarios.additional_info: Seek immediate medical attention for severe burns, especially if you experience difficulty breathing or have a weakened immune system.

scenarios.title: Bleeding from a Cut on the Face (65+ years)
immediate_steps: Apply gentle pressure to the wound with a clean cloth for 5-10 minutes, using your arms rather than your hands if possible
Elevate the injured area above heart level, but avoid bending or straining
Clean and dress the wound with sterile bandages, taking care not to dislodge any blood clots
when_to_seek_help: severe bleeding that doesn't stop after 10-15 minutes of pressure
signs of infection, such as redness, swelling, and increased pain
do_not: Remove the dressing or apply ice to the wound if you're over 65, as this can dislodge blood clots or worsen bleeding
Bend or strain while applying pressure or elevating the injured area
scenarios.additional_info: Monitor for signs of infection and consult your doctor about taking medications that may thin your blood, such as aspirin or warfarin.
scenarios.base_scenario_id: Bleeding from a Cut on the Face

scenarios.title: Severe Bleeding from a Cut on the Face
symptoms: severe bleeding that won't stop after 10 minutes of pressure
immediate_steps: Call 911 immediately and provide your location
Apply a clean, firm cloth to the wound to control bleeding for 10-15 minutes
Elevate the injured area above heart level to reduce blood flow
Clean and dress the wound with sterile bandages
when_to_seek_help: any sign of severe bleeding that won't stop
do_not: Remove the dressing or apply ice to the wound
Try to stop the bleeding yourself without medical help
scenarios.additional_info: Monitor for signs of shock, such as pale skin, rapid heartbeat, and shallow breathing.
scenarios.base_scenario_id: Bleeding from a Cut on the Face

scenarios.title: Elderly Person Suffers Burns
symptoms: difficulty moving or walking due to pain
immediate_steps: Call emergency services immediately
Remove tight clothing and jewelry that may be in contact with the burn
Cool the burn with cool tap water for 10-15 minutes, but avoid soaking
Apply a topical antibiotic ointment and cover with a non-stick dressing, if advised by caregiver or doctor
Seek immediate medical attention
do_not: Use ice or ice packs to treat the burn, as this can cause further damage
Break blisters with fingers or other objects, as this can lead to infection
scenarios.additional_info: Burns can be serious and potentially life-threatening in elderly individuals, especially if they have underlying medical conditions or take medications that affect healing.

scenarios.title: Critical Burns from Fire
symptoms: scarring and potential permanent damage to skin and underlying tissues
immediate_steps: Call 911 immediately and provide your location
Stop the burning process by smothering the flames with a non-flammable material while protecting yourself from further injury
Remove clothing and jewelry that may be in contact with the burn, but avoid breaking blisters
Cool the burn with cool tap water for 10 minutes, but do not use ice or immerse in water
Apply a topical antibiotic ointment and cover with a non-stick dressing, but only if you are able to move safely
when_to_seek_help: extreme burning sensation that cannot be managed by bystanders
difficulty breathing or speaking due to airway constriction
do_not: Use household cleaners or harsh chemicals to treat the burn
Break blisters with fingers or other objects
Apply any topical creams or ointments without medical guidance
scenarios.additional_info: Burns can be life-threatening, especially in children. Delayed treatment can lead to serious complications and long-term damage.

scenarios.title: Adult Elderly Fall Injury
immediate_steps: Call 911 or your local emergency number immediately
Keep the person calm and comfortable until medical help arrives
Loosen tight clothing around the neck, head, and torso, but avoid dislodging glasses or dentures
Stabilize the person's airway, breathing, and circulation (ABCs)
Do not give medication unless absolutely necessary and only if trained to do so
do_not: Move the person excessively, as this can cause further injury
Try to remove jewelry or tight clothing around the neck, which can also worsen the situation
Assume they are awake and alert when in fact they may be experiencing altered mental status
scenarios.additional_info: Elderly individuals are at higher risk of complications from head injuries due to age-related health conditions. Prompt medical attention is crucial.

scenarios.title: Adult Head Injury from Fall - Critical
symptoms: disorientation with no recall of recent events
immediate_steps: Call 911 immediately, do not wait for response (critical)
Apply firm but gentle head and neck support to stabilize the person's airway, breathing, and circulation (ABCs) while waiting for help arrives
Keep the person calm and comfortable by speaking in a soft voice and maintaining eye contact
when_to_seek_help: loss of consciousness for more than 30 seconds
do_not: Move the person excessively, even if they appear to be okay
Try to remove jewelry or tight clothing around the neck
scenarios.additional_info: Head injuries can be life-threatening and require immediate medical attention. Timely treatment is crucial to preventing long-term brain damage or death.
scenarios.source: American Association of Neurological Surgeons Online

scenarios.title: Bleeding Control in Elderly
symptoms: dizziness or lightheadedness due to blood loss
immediate_steps: Apply direct pressure firmly but carefully
Elevate the affected limb above heart level
Use a clean cloth or gauze and apply pressure for at least 10 minutes
Avoid using tourniquets unless absolutely necessary, as they can cut off circulation
when_to_seek_help: Bleeding doesn't stop after 15-20 minutes of pressure
If you experience dizziness or lightheadedness
If you have a history of bleeding disorders or take blood thinners
If the wound is on an area with poor circulation
do_not: Remove clothing to access wound, as this can lead to infection
Use harsh soap or clean gauze that may irritate the skin
scenarios.additional_info: Be aware of any medications that may increase bleeding risk and consult your doctor if necessary

scenarios.title: Bleeding Control - Severe
symptoms: severe bleeding that soaks through multiple layers of clothing
life-threatening bleeding that shows no signs of slowing down after direct pressure
immediate_steps: Apply immediate pressure with clean gauze, ideally using a tourniquet if available
when_to_seek_help: Bleeding doesn't stop or worsens after 5 minutes of pressure
Visible signs of circulatory failure (shock) such as pale skin, fast heart rate, and shallow breathing
do_not: Remove clothing to access wound if bleeding is severe
Apply direct pressure without tourniquet if available
scenarios.additional_info: Act quickly and remain vigilant; a 911 call is strictly required in case of severe bleeding

scenarios.title: Cardiopulmonary Resuscitation (CPR) for Elderly Patients
symptoms: No breathing after a sudden illness or injury
Confusion, disorientation, or loss of consciousness
immediate_steps: Start chest compressions on the upper half of the body (around 6 inches)
Give rescue breaths for only 5-6 breaths to avoid overexertion
Continue CPR until emergency services arrive or you are too exhausted
when_to_seek_help: CPR is not successful after 2-3 minutes of uninterrupted CPR
do_not: Use a bag-valve mask on an elderly patient with underlying medical conditions
Apply firm chest compressions; use gentle compression instead
Continue CPR beyond 5 minutes if you are unable to get help
scenarios.additional_info: Consider seeking medical attention before starting CPR, especially if the patient has a history of heart disease or stroke

scenarios.title: Cardiopulmonary Resuscitation (CPR) - Critical
symptoms: No breathing for more than 1 minute
immediate_steps: Call 911 immediately if the above symptoms occur. Ensure help is on the way before starting CPR.
Start chest compressions at a rate of 100 to 120 per minute
Give rescue breaths at a rate of 12 to 15 per minute
when_to_seek_help: CPR is not successful after 1 minute of uninterrupted CPR
do_not: Use a bag-valve mask on a child under 1 year old unless absolutely necessary
Administer any medication without proper training and equipment
scenarios.additional_info: Use a defibrillator if available and follow manufacturer's instructions. Follow the device's voice prompts to determine the best treatment.

scenarios.title: Automated External Defibrillator (AED) Use in Elderly
immediate_steps: Turn on the AED and follow voice prompts carefully (due to hearing sensitivity)
Attach electrodes to the person's chest with one hand, if possible, to avoid falls
when_to_seek_help: AED is not needed if CPR is being performed and the person shows signs of regaining consciousness
Consider seeking help from emergency services before using an AED
do_not: Use an AED on a frail or elderly individual with multiple medical conditions unless trained in geriatric use
Avoid using an AED if the person is taking certain medications that may interact with the device's electrical shock
scenarios.additional_info: The device will provide instructions to guide you through the process, but always call emergency services first

scenarios.title: Automated External Defibrillator (AED) Use in Critical Situations
immediate_steps: Call 911 immediately while turning on the AED
Attach electrodes to the person's chest as quickly and accurately as possible
Follow voice prompts or analyze a heart rhythm without delay
when_to_seek_help: Do not use an AED if CPR is being performed, but seek immediate medical help instead
Seek help immediately if the person shows no signs of regaining consciousness after 5 minutes of CPR
do_not: Use an AED on a child under 8 years old unless trained in pediatric use and have explicit parental consent
Attempt to revive a person with cardiac arrest outside of your training area or without access to emergency services
scenarios.additional_info: The device will provide urgent instructions to guide you through the process, but do not hesitate to seek immediate medical help if unsure about the situation
scenarios.source: American Heart Association Guidelines for Cardiopulmonary Resuscitation and Emergency Cardiovascular Care

scenarios.title: Burns in Older Adults (65+)
symptoms: Redness, swelling, pain, decreased sensation or numbness, difficulty moving the affected area
immediate_steps: Remove clothing and jewelry near the burn, but be cautious not to remove any vital signs (e.g. glasses, dentures)
when_to_seek_help: Burns cover more than 10% of the body surface area or are life-threatening
do_not: Use ice to treat burns in older adults, as this can cause frostbite
scenarios.additional_info: Never use butter or cream on burns, as this can lead to infection. Monitor for signs of dehydration and hypovolemic shock

scenarios.title: Burns (Severe/Critical)
symptoms: Severe redness, swelling, pain; blisters or charring; difficulty breathing
Loss of consciousness or decreased level of consciousness
immediate_steps: Remove clothing and jewelry near the burn immediately
Cool with cool water for exactly 10 minutes
Apply a sterile dressing; do not apply any topical creams or ointments
Call 911 or your local emergency number immediately; provide as much information as possible about the injury
when_to_seek_help: Burns cover more than 30% of the body surface area or are life-threatening
Difficulty breathing or decreased level of consciousness
do_not: Use ice to treat severe burns
scenarios.additional_info: Never use butter or cream on burns, as this can lead to infection; seek medical attention immediately if you suspect a burn is severe.

scenarios.title: Frozen Pipe Injuries in Elderly
immediate_steps: Turn off the main water valve if possible.
Call a plumber to thaw the pipe safely and consider assistance for mobility issues.
when_to_seek_help: If symptoms worsen or don't improve within 24 hours
If unable to turn off main water valve due to limited mobility
do_not: Try to use hot water to thaw the pipe without proper precautions, as this can cause burns.

scenarios.title: Frozen Pipe Injuries (Severe)
immediate_steps: Turn off the main water valve if possible.
Call a plumber to thaw the pipe safely and urgently.
Move to a warm location and remove any wet clothing.
Apply an ice pack or heat wrap to affected area (with caution)
when_to_seek_help: If symptoms worsen, or if you experience: severe pain, difficulty moving, numbness or tingling in face, arms, or legs, swelling of hands or feet, shortness of breath, or chest pain.
do_not: Try to use hot water to thaw the pipe without proper precautions.
Disregard symptoms or delay seeking medical attention.

scenarios.title: Hypothermia (Critical)
immediate_steps: Call 911 IMMEDIATELY and provide your location.
Remove any wet clothing and apply warm compresses to exposed skin.
Loosen tight clothing and cover the person with a dry blanket or emergency bivvy sack.
do_not: Administer oxygen without proper training or equipment.
Give the person anything to eat or drink until medical help arrives.

scenarios.title: Carbon Monoxide Poisoning in Elderly Patients
immediate_steps: Get the person outside and into fresh air immediately.
Call emergency services and try to provide oxygen if available. Sit them upright if possible.
do_not: Try to revive the person without proper training. Do not attempt to give any medication, including aspirin or ibuprofen.

scenarios.title: Frozen Finger or Toe in Elderly
symptoms: painful sensations in toes or fingers, especially in cold weather
immediate_steps: Run warm water over the affected area for 5-10 minutes.
Apply a warm compress or use a heating pad on low setting (check with doctor first).
Remove any constrictive clothing around the affected area.
when_to_seek_help: If pain persists or worsens, or if numbness or tingling is severe or lasts longer than 2 hours.
If diabetes symptoms are worsening or if you experience difficulty walking or balance problems.
do_not: Use ice to treat the injury without proper precautions (may cause frostbite).
Apply heat directly to skin, especially on weakened areas.

scenarios.title: Frostbite of Finger or Toe
symptoms: Extreme pain that's severe and unrelenting
Numbness or tingling that spreads to other parts of the body
Discoloration (pale, blue, or purple) of the affected area
immediate_steps: Call 911 immediately. Do not delay.
Move the affected limb to a warmer location if possible without touching it.
when_to_seek_help: If you experience difficulty moving the affected limb
do_not: Use ice or warm water to treat the injury
Apply a heating pad or take a warm bath

scenarios.title: Frostbite in Elderly
immediate_steps: Run warm water over the affected area for 10-15 minutes.
Apply a warm compress or use a heating pad on low setting, avoiding direct heat to sensitive areas.
when_to_seek_help: Loss of sensation in hands and feet
do_not: Use ice to treat the injury without proper precautions, as it can worsen circulation issues common in seniors.
Leave frostbite untreated for extended periods, as this can lead to permanent damage.

scenarios.title: Frostbite - Critical
symptoms: Numbness, tingling, and weakness in extremities
immediate_steps: Call 911 immediately if symptoms are severe
Run hot water (not boiling) over the affected area for 10-15 minutes.
Apply a warm, damp dressing or use a heating pad on medium-high setting.
Remove any constrictive clothing around the affected area and seek shelter.
when_to_seek_help: Frostbite affecting face, hands, or feet
do_not: Use ice to treat the injury without proper precautions.
Leave frostbitten area to thaw in warm environment.

scenarios.title: Cuts from Sharp Objects (Elderly)
immediate_steps: Apply gentle pressure to stop bleeding using a clean cloth or gauze (avoid using bare hands)
