Elevate the injured area above heart level to reduce blood flow
Clean the cut with mild soap and water (avoid using harsh soaps, hydrogen peroxide, or iodine)
when_to_seek_help: severe bleeding that doesn't stop after 10-15 minutes of pressure
do_not: apply tourniquet (can cut off circulation)
use tight bandages or constrictive clothing
scenarios.additional_info: Monitor for signs of infection, such as redness, warmth, or increased swelling

scenarios.title: Cuts from Sharp Objects - Critical
symptoms: severe bleeding that won't stop with pressure
numbness or tingling in the affected area
immediate_steps: Call 911 immediately and provide your location
Apply firm, steady pressure to the wound with a clean cloth or bandage for at least 5 minutes
Elevate the injured area above heart level to reduce blood flow
do_not: apply tourniquet without medical guidance
move the person who was cut unless it's absolutely necessary to do so
scenarios.additional_info: Monitor for signs of shock, infection, and nerve damage. Seek immediate medical attention.

scenarios.title: Severe Burns from Fire or Heat
symptoms: severe burning sensation that can't be relieved with water or pain medication
extreme redness and swelling of the burned area
charring or blackening of the skin
difficulty breathing due to inhalation of smoke or fumes
immediate_steps: CALL 911 IMMEDIATELY and get help on the way if possible
Stop burning activity and find a safe location as soon as possible
Cool the burn with cool tap water for no more than 10 minutes and then apply a topical antibiotic ointment, if available
when_to_seek_help: If symptoms worsen or don't improve within 1 hour
do_not: use ice or snow
apply butter or oil
break any tight clothing that's around the burned area
try to treat the burn with pain medication, as this can slow healing
scenarios.additional_info: Monitor for signs of infection and watch for respiratory distress

scenarios.title: Poisoning from Ingestion in the Elderly
immediate_steps: Call the national Poison Help hotline at 1-800-222-1222
Do not induce vomiting unless advised by a healthcare provider, as elderly may be at risk for aspiration
Offer small amounts of water to drink if advised by a healthcare provider
when_to_seek_help: if symptoms worsen or do not improve within 1 hour
if the person experiences difficulty breathing, chest pain, or severe dizziness
do_not: give the person anything to eat or drink unless advised by a healthcare provider
scenarios.additional_info: Provide information about the ingested substance and any pre-existing medical conditions

scenarios.title: Broken Bones (Fractures) in Elderly
immediate_steps: Apply ice to reduce swelling for 15-20 minutes, several times a day (avoid frostbite risk)
Immobilize the injured area using a sling or splint with consideration for joint mobility and comfort
Elevate the injured area above heart level, but avoid prolonged elevation to prevent deep vein thrombosis
when_to_seek_help: if symptoms worsen, numbness/tingling in limbs, difficulty breathing, dizziness or fainting
scenarios.additional_info: Be cautious of dehydration and electrolyte imbalance; watch for signs of infection, immobilize until further evaluated by a medical professional

scenarios.title: Severe Fracture (Critical)
symptoms: numbness or tingling in the affected limb
immediate_steps: Apply ice to reduce swelling for 15-20 minutes, several times a day, and elevate above heart level
Immobilize the injured area using a sling or splint immediately
Call 911 or your local emergency number right away and provide your location
when_to_seek_help: if symptoms worsen within 30 minutes of injury
do_not: move the injured area unless absolutely necessary (e.g. to avoid crushing)
remove any clothing or accessories near the injury
scenarios.additional_info: Watch for signs of infection, such as redness, warmth, or pus, and seek medical attention immediately

scenarios.title: Snake Bites or Stings in the Elderly
immediate_steps: Remove any constrictive clothing or jewelry
Clean the bite area with mild soap and water, taking care not to scrub too hard
Apply a cold compress to reduce swelling, but avoid applying pressure directly on wounds that are difficult to see
when_to_seek_help: if symptoms worsen or do not improve within 30 minutes
if difficulty breathing, rapid heartbeat, or dizziness occur
if mobility is affected or falls happen frequently
do_not: attempt to suck out the venom or use a tourniquet, as this can cause further harm
drive yourself to the hospital if symptoms are severe or worsening
ignoring swelling or pain for an extended period
scenarios.additional_info: Elderly patients may experience numbness, tingling, or weakness due to age-related nerve damage. Monitor for these additional symptoms and seek medical attention promptly.

scenarios.title: Snake Bites or Stings (Critical)
immediate_steps: Call 911 IMMEDIATELY
Remove any constrictive clothing or jewelry
Clean the bite area with mild soap and water
Apply a cold compress to reduce swelling, but only if able to move limb
Keep the affected limb below heart level
when_to_seek_help: if symptoms worsen within 30 minutes of initial bite
if difficulty breathing or swallowing persists
if pale or cool skin does not improve with cold compress
do_not: Do not attempt to suck out the venom or use a tourniquet
Do not give any medication without medical guidance
scenarios.additional_info: Do not drive yourself to the hospital. Call ahead to notify emergency department of snake bite and provide estimated time of exposure.

scenarios.title: Severe Laceration on Hand
symptoms: severe bleeding that won't stop with gentle pressure
swelling that's increasing in size and redness
numbness or tingling in the hand or fingers
immediate_steps: Call 911 immediately and provide your location.
Apply firm pressure to the wound using a clean cloth or gauze for at least 5-10 minutes.
Clean the cut with soap and water, then apply an antibiotic ointment and cover the wound with a sterile bandage.
when_to_seek_help: If symptoms worsen or don't improve after 30 minutes of treatment
If you experience difficulty moving your fingers or hand
do_not: Apply harsh soap, hydrogen peroxide, or iodine to the wound
Disregard pain or try to apply pressure without proper training and equipment
scenarios.additional_info: Monitor for signs of shock, such as pale skin, rapid heartbeat, or shortness of breath.

scenarios.title: Severe Allergic Reaction in Elderly
symptoms: Confusion, dizziness, or loss of consciousness
immediate_steps: Call 911 or your local emergency number immediately.
Sit the person upright if possible and elevate their legs.
Administer epinephrine using an EpiPen or auto-injector if available.
do_not: Try to treat with antihistamines without proper training
Use oxygen unless instructed by medical professional
scenarios.additional_info: Continue CPR if the person becomes unresponsive.

scenarios.title: Critical Allergic Reaction
symptoms: Severe swelling of the face, lips, tongue, or throat leading to loss of consciousness
Difficulty breathing with rapid onset of respiratory failure
immediate_steps: Call 911 immediately. Do not attempt to drive yourself or others to the hospital.
Administer epinephrine using an EpiPen or auto-injector if available. Repeat as directed by the device's instructions.
Lay the person on their back, tilt their head back, and use a pillow under the knees to elevate the lower legs.
Start CPR if the person becomes unresponsive.
do_not: Try to treat with antihistamines without proper training or medication guidance.
Administer oxygen without proper training or equipment.
scenarios.additional_info: Continue CPR and monitor vital signs if the person becomes unresponsive.

scenarios.title: Back Sprain in Elderly
immediate_steps: Apply ice to the affected area for 15-20 minutes, three times a day. Be cautious not to numb the skin.
Elevate the affected leg above the level of your heart and avoid crossing your legs, which can cut off circulation.

Take prescribed pain medication as directed by your doctor or take over-the-counter acetaminophen (325mg or less) every 4-6 hours. Avoid taking ibuprofen with other medications without consulting your doctor.
when_to_seek_help: If you experience numbness, tingling, or weakness in your legs
If pain worsens or persists for more than 2 days
do_not: Bend or lift the injured area. Ask for help with lifting heavy objects
Continue to use heavy weights, exercise vigorously, or perform strenuous activities until symptoms improve
scenarios.additional_info: Monitor for signs of infection such as increased redness, swelling, or pus. Consult your doctor if you have a fever, chills, or difficulty urinating.

scenarios.title: Severe Back Sprain
symptoms: swelling and bruising that is spreading or worsening
immediate_steps: Apply ice to the affected area for 20-30 minutes, four times a day.
Elevate the affected leg above the level of your heart and immobilize with a splint if necessary.
Take prescription-strength pain medication such as oxycodone or hydrocodone immediately and follow dosage instructions.
when_to_seek_help: if symptoms worsen or do not improve after 48 hours
if you experience numbness, tingling, or weakness in the legs
do_not: Bend or lift the injured area
Drive yourself to a hospital if symptoms are severe
Attempt to move or transfer the injured person
scenarios.additional_info: Monitor for signs of infection such as increased redness, swelling, or pus. Watch for numbness, tingling, or weakness in the legs and seek immediate help.

scenarios.title: Severe Cut on the Hand (Elderly)
immediate_steps: stop bleeding
apply pressure gently (avoid tight bandages)
clean the wound with mild soap and water
wrap with a soft bandage or dressing
seek medical attention immediately
when_to_seek_help: swelling, pain, or numbness in hands or fingers
do_not: try to stitch the wound (consult doctor before)
apply tourniquet unless advised by medical professional
scenarios.additional_info: Consider taking anticoagulant medications with caution

scenarios.title: Critical Hand Injury
symptoms: numbness or tingling in hand or arm
immediate_steps: call 911 immediately
apply firm pressure to stop bleeding
clean the wound with soap and water
wrap tightly with gauze and secure with tape
immobilize affected arm with splint if possible
when_to_seek_help: excessive bleeding that soaks through multiple layers of clothing
swelling that causes difficulty moving fingers or hand
numbness or tingling that spreads to other areas of body
do_not: try to stitch the wound yourself
use tourniquet without proper training and equipment
scenarios.additional_info: Do not move injured arm unless absolutely necessary to prevent further injury
scenarios.source: American Red Cross Guidelines for Wound Care

scenarios.title: Poisonous Insect Bite in Elderly Patients (65+)
immediate_steps: remove any constrictive clothing carefully to avoid further irritation
apply a cold compress, but avoid extreme temperature changes
take an oral antihistamine, and consider adding a pain reliever (e.g., acetaminophen) if symptoms persist
seek medical attention immediately if symptoms worsen or you experience difficulty breathing
when_to_seek_help: persistent numbness or tingling in hands/feet
signs of dehydration (e.g., dark urine, decreased urine output)
do_not: use home remedies that may exacerbate the condition, such as applying heat or using harsh soaps
scenarios.additional_info: Monitor for signs of anaphylaxis and consider consulting a doctor if symptoms persist or worsen over time

scenarios.title: Life-Threatening Insect Bite
symptoms: swelling of face, lips, tongue, or throat
immediate_steps: remove any constrictive clothing IMMEDIATELY
apply a cold compress and elevate the affected area above heart level
administer an oral antihistamine and/or epinephrine auto-injector, if available
call 911 or your local emergency number IMMEDIATELY
perform CPR if the person stops breathing
start chest compressions if the person's heart has stopped
do_not: use home remedies that may exacerbate the condition
delay seeking medical attention
scenarios.additional_info: Anaphylaxis can occur within minutes of an insect bite; treat as a medical emergency.

scenarios.title: Heat-Related Illness (Critical)
immediate_steps: call 911 immediately
get the person cool and hydrated as quickly as possible
remove excess clothing
apply ice or cold compresses to the pulse points
loosen tight clothing around the neck, chest, and waist
when_to_seek_help: if symptoms worsen or do not improve after 30 minutes of treatment
do_not: try to give the person hot beverages
attempt to treat at home without medical attention
drive the person to the hospital
scenarios.additional_info: Monitor for signs of heat stroke and seek immediate medical attention.

scenarios.title: Bleeding from a Minor Cuts in Seniors (65+)
immediate_steps: Apply pressure with clean cloth for 5-10 minutes, then elevate affected area
Clean wound with mild soap and lukewarm water
when_to_seek_help: Significant blood loss (even small amounts can be concerning)
do_not: Apply a tourniquet, as it may cut off circulation
Use harsh soap or hydrogen peroxide, which can irritate skin
scenarios.additional_info: Monitor for signs of blood loss and seek help if symptoms worsen. Consider taking anticoagulant medications with you to the hospital.

scenarios.title: Severe Bleeding from a Deep Laceration
immediate_steps: Apply firm, direct pressure to stop bleeding
Elevate affected area above heart level
Clean with soap and water
Call 911 immediately if unable to control bleeding after 5 minutes of pressure
when_to_seek_help: Any severe bleeding that won't stop after 5 minutes of pressure
Signs of shock (rapid heartbeat, pale skin, rapid breathing)
do_not: Apply a tourniquet
Use a tourniquet device without proper training
scenarios.additional_info: If unable to control bleeding, call 911 before attempting any first aid measures

scenarios.title: Burn from Scalding Water (Severe)
immediate_steps: Call 911 IMMEDIATELY and get to a hospital
Cool the burn with cool tap water for no more than 5 minutes
Remove any clothing near the burn and apply a sterile dressing
do_not: Use ice or ice water on burns (this can cause further damage)
Apply any topical ointments without medical guidance
scenarios.additional_info: Get to a hospital as soon as possible for treatment. Do not attempt to treat the burn yourself.

scenarios.title: Anaphylaxis - Critical
symptoms: Hives covering most of the body
Swelling of the face, lips, tongue, or throat to the point of airway obstruction
immediate_steps: Call 911 immediately (no exceptions)
Administer epinephrine using an EpiPen or auto-injector as soon as possible
Lay person down on back with legs elevated at least 12 inches if breathing difficulties persist
Start CPR if unresponsive and not breathing
when_to_seek_help: Symptoms include any of the following:
- Swelling of the face, lips, tongue, or throat that affects breathing
- Rapid heartbeat or feeling of impending doom
do_not: Use antihistamines without medical supervision
Delay administering epinephrine for more than 5 minutes
Leave someone alone who is experiencing anaphylaxis symptoms
scenarios.additional_info: Epinephrine should be administered as soon as possible to prevent airway constriction. Anaphylaxis can progress quickly, so prompt action is essential.

scenarios.title: Burns from Wildfire Smoke in Seniors (65+)
immediate_steps: Remove clothing and jewelry carefully to avoid further injury
Cool the burn with cool tap water for 10 minutes, then apply a topical antibiotic ointment (if possible)
Monitor temperature and seek help if it exceeds 103째F (39.4째C)
do_not: Break blisters, as this can lead to infection in elderly with compromised immune systems
Use household cleaners, which can exacerbate burns and other injuries in seniors
scenarios.additional_info: If you experience difficulty breathing, dizziness, or confusion, call emergency services immediately. Elderly patients may also require oxygen therapy.

scenarios.title: Burns from Wildfire Smoke - Critical
symptoms: Coughing up blood or yellow mucus
immediate_steps: Remove clothing and jewelry immediately
Cool the burn with cool tap water for 10 minutes, then cover with a non-stick dressing
Apply a topical antibiotic ointment and take over-the-counter pain medication (as needed)
do_not: Break blisters, as this can lead to infection
Use household cleaners on the burn
scenarios.additional_info: Call 911 IMMEDIATELY if you experience any of these symptoms. If you are in a remote area with no cell service, try to find your way to the nearest hospital or medical facility.

scenarios.title: Wildfire-Related Injuries from Falling Debris in the Elderly
symptoms: Falls with fractures or osteoporosis-related bone breaks
Bruises, sprains, or strains without immediate severe pain
immediate_steps: Call emergency services immediately for assistance
Immobilize the affected area with a splint, if possible
Elevate the injured limb above heart level, but avoid exacerbating the injury
when_to_seek_help: Severe bleeding that may be harder to control in older adults
Confusion, dizziness, or difficulty walking due to injuries
do_not: Disregard pain to move an injured person, as this can lead to further injury
Apply a tourniquet unless absolutely necessary and trained to do so
scenarios.additional_info: Elderly individuals may have underlying medical conditions that affect healing. Ensure emergency responders are aware of any pre-existing conditions.

scenarios.title: Life-Threatening Injuries from Falling Debris in Wildfires
symptoms: Compressive fractures with risk of nerve damage
immediate_steps: Call 911 immediately and provide location information
Apply a tourniquet if necessary, but only by trained personnel
Immobilize the affected area with a splint, but prioritize stabilization over immobilization
when_to_seek_help: Severe bleeding (more than 2 units of blood lost)
Numbness or tingling in the extremities that persists after 10 minutes
Difficulty breathing or signs of cardiac distress
do_not: Disregard pain to move an injured person, as this can exacerbate internal injuries
Apply a tourniquet without proper training, as this can cause more harm than good
Leave the scene without providing location information to emergency services
scenarios.additional_info: If you experience severe bleeding, apply pressure and seek medical attention immediately. If you are in a life-threatening situation, call 911 first.
scenarios.source: National Institute for Occupational Safety and Health (NIOSH)

scenarios.title: Wildfire-Related Burns from Direct Exposure in the Elderly
symptoms: Severe burns with possible respiratory compromise
immediate_steps: Remove clothing and jewelry immediately, taking care not to exacerbate existing medical conditions
Cool the burn with cool tap water for 10 minutes, avoiding excessive soaking
Apply a topical antibiotic ointment, but avoid using it on broken skin or open wounds
when_to_seek_help: Difficulty breathing, rapid heartbeat, or dizziness
Severe chest pain, shortness of breath, or confusion
do_not: Break blisters with fingers, as this can introduce infection
Use household cleaners on burns, as these can cause further irritation and delay healing
scenarios.additional_info: If you experience difficulty breathing, call emergency services immediately. Elderly individuals may be more susceptible to heat exhaustion; seek medical attention if symptoms persist or worsen.

scenarios.title: Life-Threatening Wildfire-Related Burns from Direct Exposure
symptoms: Severe burns that cover large areas of the body
Charring of skin and hair, potentially leading to eschar formation
Difficulty breathing due to inhalation of smoke particles
Severe chest pain and potential for cardiac complications
immediate_steps: Remove clothing and jewelry immediately and call 911
Cool the burn with cool tap water for 10 minutes, then move to a shaded area
Apply a topical antibiotic ointment and cover the wound with sterile gauze
when_to_seek_help: Difficulty breathing or shortness of breath
Inability to move arms or legs due to severe burns
do_not: Break blisters, as this can lead to infection
Use household cleaners or apply topical ointments without medical guidance
scenarios.additional_info: If you experience any of the above symptoms, call emergency services immediately and follow any instructions provided by the operator.

scenarios.title: Severe Cut from Finger
immediate_steps: Apply firm pressure to stop bleeding
Elevate injured finger above heart level
Clean with soap and water
Call 911 immediately
Wrap tightly but not too tightly
Monitor for signs of compartment syndrome
Seek medical attention immediately
Do not move the injured finger
when_to_seek_help: Pain or coldness in the injured finger
do_not: Use a tourniquet
Apply ice or heat
Disregard numbness or symptoms
Delay seeking medical attention
scenarios.additional_info: Seek immediate medical attention if numbness persists or worsens, and monitor for signs of compartment syndrome

scenarios.title: Severe Burn from Scald
symptoms: Extreme burning sensation, possibly accompanied by pain and nausea
immediate_steps: Call 911 immediately and provide your location
Run cool tap water over the burn for exactly 10 minutes
Remove any clothing or jewelry near the burned area, taking care not to further irritate the burn
when_to_seek_help: Significant burns covering more than 20% of the body surface area, severe blisters, or difficulty breathing
If you are unconscious or experiencing a loss of consciousness
do_not: Use ice or ice water
scenarios.additional_info: Seek immediate medical attention for severe burns

scenarios.title: Broken Bone (Wrist) in Elderly
immediate_steps: Apply ice to reduce swelling, but for short periods (5-10 minutes)
Immobilize the wrist with a splint or sling, and avoid bending or straightening the wrist
Monitor for numbness or tingling, and report to doctor if worsens
when_to_seek_help: Difficulty moving the wrist or fingers
Coldness or paleness of skin in hands or feet
do_not: Move the injured arm excessively, as this can cause further injury
Take NSAIDs without consulting doctor first, as they may interact with medications
scenarios.additional_info: Seek medical attention for difficulty moving the wrist, numbness, tingling, or if pain worsens at night

scenarios.title: Severe Wrist Fracture (Critical)
immediate_steps: Apply ice to reduce swelling immediately
Immobilize the wrist with a splint or sling tightly
Monitor for numbness or tingling closely
Call 911 immediately if symptoms worsen or do not improve with treatment
when_to_seek_help: Severe pain or numbness that does not improve within 30 minutes of initial treatment
Difficulty moving the wrist or hand
Coldness or discoloration of the skin around the injury
do_not: Move the injured arm excessively
Disregard a diagnosis without consulting a medical professional
scenarios.additional_info: Wrist fracture can lead to permanent nerve damage, loss of function, and chronic pain if left untreated.

scenarios.title: Snake Bite in Elderly Patients (65+)
symptoms: pain, swelling, bruising around the bite site, weakness or numbness in limbs
immediate_steps: Remove any constrictive clothing or jewelry carefully to avoid further injury
Keep the bite below heart level, but be cautious not to exacerbate bruising
Do not attempt to suck out venom, and be aware of potential risk of aspiration in elderly patients
when_to_seek_help: Increasing pain or swelling, difficulty breathing, dizziness or fainting
Numbness or weakness in limbs that worsens over time
do_not: Use ice or ice water, as this can worsen circulatory issues and slow healing
Take antihistamines without medical supervision, as elderly patients may have underlying health conditions
scenarios.additional_info: Elderly patients may experience delayed symptoms, making timely medical attention crucial

scenarios.title: First Aid for Burns in Elderly (65+)
immediate_steps: Cool the burn with cool tap water for 10-15 minutes, avoiding immersion of hands or feet
Remove any constrictive clothing and apply a non-stick dressing, taking care to avoid further irritation
Cover the burned area with a clean, dry cloth and monitor for signs of infection
when_to_seek_help: Severe burns (more than 10% body surface area)
do_not: Use ice or ice water to cool the burn, as it can cause further tissue damage
Apply topical creams or ointments without consulting a doctor first
scenarios.additional_info: Avoid moving the affected limb unless absolutely necessary. Apply antibiotic ointment and cover the burn with a non-stick dressing only if advised by a healthcare professional

scenarios.title: Emergency Care for Severe Burns
symptoms: Severe charring of skin and underlying tissue
immediate_steps: Call 911 IMMEDIATELY and provide your location
Apply a cool, wet dressings to the burned area for up to 10 minutes
Remove any constrictive clothing and apply a non-stick dressing
Cover the burned area with a sterile, breathable cloth
when_to_seek_help: Any sign of severe burn injury
do_not: Use ice or ice water to cool the burn
Break any blisters or scabs that form
Apply topical creams or ointments without medical supervision
scenarios.additional_info: Monitor vital signs closely and seek further medical attention immediately if symptoms worsen

scenarios.title: Bleeding Control from a Deep Wound in the Elderly
immediate_steps: Apply pressure to the wound with a clean cloth or dressing for 10-15 minutes before seeking medical attention
Call emergency services immediately if bleeding doesn't stop after 10-15 minutes of pressure
Sit upright and elevate legs above heart level while waiting for help
when_to_seek_help: Excessive bleeding that doesn't stop after 10-15 minutes of pressure
Dizziness or fainting, signs of shock or circulatory failure
do_not: Apply a tourniquet unless absolutely necessary and only by trained personnel
Use hemostatic agents without proper training
scenarios.additional_info: Elderly patients are more susceptible to blood loss due to decreased blood volume. Tourniquets should be used with caution and only in life-threatening situations.

scenarios.title: Critical Bleeding Control from a Deep Wound
immediate_steps: Call 911 immediately and begin CPR if necessary
Apply firm, steady pressure to the wound with a clean cloth or dressing
Use a tourniquet only as a last resort in life-threatening situations
Elevate the injured limb above heart level
when_to_seek_help: Excessive bleeding that doesn't stop after 5 minutes of pressure
Signs of cardiac arrest or respiratory failure
do_not: Apply a tourniquet if it's not available or not used correctly
Use a hemostatic agent without proper training
Leave the patient alone or wait for medical help to arrive
scenarios.additional_info: Tourniquets should only be used in life-threatening situations. Hemostatic agents are for emergency use only and require proper training.

scenarios.title: Life-Threatening Bite or Sting from a Venomous Snake
symptoms: Severe pain, swelling, and redness at the bite site that spreads rapidly
Difficulty breathing, rapid heartbeat, or cardiac arrest
Numbness or tingling that can spread to face, arms, or legs
immediate_steps: Remove any constrictive clothing around the affected area immediately
Keep the affected limb below heart level and elevate above heart level if possible
Apply a cold compress to reduce swelling and seek medical help at once
when_to_seek_help: Any signs of severe reaction, including difficulty breathing, rapid heartbeat, or cardiac arrest
If you're unsure of the type of snake that bit you or suspect multiple bites
If you experience numbness or tingling that spreads to face, arms, or legs
do_not: Try to suck out the venom without proper training and equipment
Apply a tourniquet without proper training and equipment
Drive yourself to medical help; call emergency services immediately (911)

scenarios.title: Severe Fracture
symptoms: Sudden, excruciating pain; swelling and bruising that spreads rapidly; numbness or tingling; difficulty breathing
Severe limited mobility; inability to move affected limb
immediate_steps: Call 911 IMMEDIATELY and provide location information
Apply an ice pack to reduce pain, but do not attempt to immobilize the injured limb yourself
Take severe pain medication as directed by a medical professional
when_to_seek_help: Any of the above symptoms or if you suspect a severe reaction
If unsure of injury severity or unable to move
do_not: Move or lift injured limb without proper assistance and equipment
Apply tourniquet or use other constrictive methods
Drive yourself to medical facility
scenarios.additional_info: Severe fractures can lead to long-term disability if not treated promptly and properly

scenarios.title: Minor Burn in Elderly
immediate_steps: Stop the burning process, sit down and elevate affected area
Cool the burn with cool water for 10-15 minutes, change frequently
Apply a topical antibiotic ointment, but avoid breaking blisters
Cover with non-stick dressing, avoid harsh soap or cleansers
when_to_seek_help: Difficulty moving affected limb due to pain
Signs of infection: red streaks, increased swelling, pus
do_not: Use tourniquets or ice packs on elderly, as it may cut off circulation
Break blisters, as it can lead to infection and delayed healing
scenarios.additional_info: Monitor for signs of infection and seek medical attention if symptoms worsen or do not improve within 3-5 days

scenarios.title: Critical Burn
immediate_steps: Call 911 IMMEDIATELY
Apply a non-stick dressing to cover the burn and hold it in place with a clean, dry towel
Administer 1-2% lidocaine topical gel or spray for pain management (if available)
when_to_seek_help: Signs of shock (dizziness, nausea, rapid heartbeat)
do_not: Break blisters
Use harsh soap or cleansers
Apply any ointments without medical supervision
Move the person unless they are in a life-threatening position
scenarios.additional_info: Get the person to a hospital as soon as possible. Do not attempt to treat at home.

scenarios.title: Severe Cut on Finger
symptoms: swelling that covers the entire finger
numbness or tingling in the affected hand
immediate_steps: Call 911 immediately and provide location and number of injured person.
Apply firm and steady pressure to the wound with a clean cloth or bandage for 10-15 minutes, while staying on the phone with emergency services.
Elevate the injured hand above heart level and keep it immobile.
when_to_seek_help: Any sign of severe bleeding that doesn't stop after 5 minutes
Signs of infection (redness, warmth, swelling, or pus)
Severe pain that worsens over time
do_not: Disregarding first aid and applying tourniquet without medical guidance
Ignoring severe symptoms or waiting more than 30 minutes for help to arrive
scenarios.additional_info: Do not attempt to drive yourself to the hospital. Stay on the phone with emergency services until they arrive.

scenarios.title: Burn on Face (Elderly)
symptoms: Blistering, may indicate decreased blood flow
immediate_steps: Cool the burn with cool tap water for 10-15 minutes.
Remove any clothing or jewelry near the burned area, be cautious of fragile bones.
do_not: Ignoring infection symptoms, as elderly may be more susceptible to complications.
Applying petroleum jelly, can delay healing and increase risk of infection.
scenarios.additional_info: Seek medical attention if burns are severe, blisters cover large areas, or you experience numbness/tingling sensations

scenarios.title: Critical Burn on Face
symptoms: Blisters covering large areas of the face
immediate_steps: Call 911 immediately.
Cool the burn with cool tap water for 10-15 minutes, but DO NOT get under the person.
Remove any clothing or jewelry near the burned area, and apply a topical antibiotic ointment.
Place the person on their back with their head lower than their feet to help reduce swelling.
Loosen tight clothing around the neck and chest.
do_not: Applying petroleum jelly or butter
Using harsh soap or cleanser
Trying to treat the burn yourself without medical attention
scenarios.additional_info: Seek immediate medical attention if you suspect a critical burn on the face. Burns that cover large areas of the body can be life-threatening if not treated promptly.

scenarios.title: Broken Nose in the Elderly
immediate_steps: Apply ice pack to reduce swelling, but be careful not to apply too much pressure
Use gauze to apply gentle pressure to the nose and elevate your head 6-8 inches to reduce bleeding
Sit upright with pillows for support to prevent swallowing blood
when_to_seek_help: If symptoms worsen or do not improve after 24 hours
If you experience severe headache, vomiting, or difficulty breathing
If you have a history of bleeding disorders or take anticoagulant medications
do_not: Try to clean the wound with soap and water, as this can push bacteria into the wound
Use harsh or abrasive materials to apply pressure
Take NSAIDs without consulting your doctor first
scenarios.additional_info: Monitor for signs of infection, such as increased swelling, redness, or pus. Consider seeking medical attention if you have a weakened immune system or are taking immunosuppressive medications.

scenarios.title: Severe Fractured Nose
symptoms: profound swelling of the face and neck
immediate_steps: Call 911 IMMEDIATELY
Apply firm pressure to the nose with a clean cloth or gauze for 5-10 minutes
Elevate your head to reduce bleeding, but do not move or lift
do_not: Try to clean the wound with soap and water
Apply ice pack or try to stop the bleeding on your own
scenarios.additional_info: Monitor for signs of airway obstruction, such as difficulty speaking or severe shortness of breath

scenarios.title: Severe Cuts from Broken Glass
immediate_steps: Apply firm pressure to the cut with a clean cloth, elevating the affected limb if possible
Call 911 and provide your location
Use antibacterial soap and water to clean the area, but do not attempt to remove any glass fragments
Cover the cut with a sterile bandage or dressing
Monitor vital signs and watch for signs of shock
Seek immediate medical attention
when_to_seek_help: Severe bleeding that won't stop after 10 minutes of pressure
Signs of shock, such as pale skin, fast heart rate, or difficulty breathing
Increased swelling or redness around the wound
Numbness or tingling in the affected limb
do_not: Try to remove any glass fragments
Apply tourniquet without medical supervision
Drive yourself to the hospital
scenarios.additional_info: Do not delay seeking medical attention. Prompt treatment is essential to prevent further complications.

scenarios.title: Heat Stroke in Seniors (65+)
immediate_steps: Move the person to a cooler location immediately
Loosen excess clothing and layers
Provide cool water or electrolyte-rich drinks, but avoid caffeine
do_not: Try to treat the reaction yourself. Call emergency services immediately
Give medication without medical supervision
scenarios.additional_info: Continue providing cool water and monitoring for signs of improvement. Be aware of medications that can increase dehydration risk, such as diuretics and certain antidepressants.

scenarios.title: Elderly with Burns from Scalding
immediate_steps: Remove clothing, cool burns with lukewarm water for 10-15 minutes
Apply topical antibiotic ointment and non-stick dressings to prevent infection
Sit the patient upright to prevent choking on saliva
Monitor blood pressure and heart rate closely
Call 9-1-1 immediately if symptoms worsen or there is difficulty breathing
when_to_seek_help: Symptoms of shock (rapid heartbeat, pale skin), severe respiratory distress
do_not: Give the patient any medication without consulting a doctor first
Apply butter, oil, or any greasy substance to the burns
scenarios.additional_info: Elderly individuals may be more susceptible to dehydration and electrolyte imbalances due to age-related declines in kidney function. Monitor fluid intake closely.

scenarios.title: Critical Burns from Scalding
symptoms: Severe burns, difficulty breathing, fast heartbeat, confusion, loss of consciousness
immediate_steps: Remove clothing immediately and call 9-1-1. Call emergency services before attempting to cool the burns.
Apply topical antibiotic ointment only after securing the child's airway with a clear plastic bag or mask if available.
Start CPR if victim is unresponsive.
when_to_seek_help: Immediate attention required, do not delay
If breathing is stopped, start CPR
do_not: Do not attempt to remove clothing yourself, as this can cause further injury

scenarios.title: Elderly with Head Injury
symptoms: Loss of consciousness, may experience falls
immediate_steps: Clear airway, turn person onto back, and support neck with pillows
Call 9-1-1 and try to keep person calm
when_to_seek_help: If person has a history of head injuries or is at risk for falls
do_not: Do not move person's head or neck until medical help arrives
Avoid giving anything to drink or eat unless advised by medical professional
scenarios.additional_info: Elderly may have underlying health conditions that affect their response to injury

scenarios.title: Adult with Critical Head Injury
symptoms: Severe confusion, difficulty walking, inability to speak or swallow
immediate_steps: Clear airway, turn person onto back immediately and support head and neck
Stabilize neck with cervical collar and immobilize body
Call 911 emergency number immediately and follow prompts
Start CPR if unresponsive and not breathing normally
when_to_seek_help: Seek immediate medical attention if symptoms worsen or persist
do_not: Do not move person's head or neck without proper stabilization equipment
Do not give anything to eat or drink until medical professionals arrive
scenarios.additional_info: If seizure occurs, clear airway and turn person onto side to protect airway

scenarios.title: Elderly Burns from Scalding Water
symptoms: Redness, swelling, and pain around the burn area
Numbness or tingling in the burned area
immediate_steps: Stop the burning process by turning off the heat source if possible
Remove clothing and jewelry near the burned area
Run cool tap water over the burn for 10-15 minutes, being cautious not to dislodge any prosthetic devices or eye patches
when_to_seek_help: Severe burns covering more than 20% of the body surface area
Blisters or signs of infection such as increased redness, swelling, or pus in elderly patients
Difficulty breathing, chest pain, or rapid heartbeat
do_not: Break blisters or scab the burn in elderly patients
Apply oil, butter, or other greasy substances to the burn in elderly patients
Use harsh soap or cleansers on the burned area
scenarios.additional_info: Prevent falls by ensuring good lighting and traction near heat sources

scenarios.title: Elderly Choking on Food or Objects
symptoms: Inability to speak, coughing, choking, or gagging
Clutching at the throat, chest, or arm
immediate_steps: Back slaps to dislodge the object with caution
Abdominal thrusts (modified Heimlich maneuver) if back slaps are ineffective
Call 911 immediately and provide first aid guidance until medical help arrives
when_to_seek_help: The elderly person is unconscious, showing signs of shock, or experiencing severe difficulty breathing
no response from back slaps and abdominal thrusts, or worsening condition
do_not: Panic or use your own hands to try to dislodge the object due to fragile bones and medical conditions
Apply pressure on the elderly person's chest or throat, as this can exacerbate breathing difficulties
Use a firm grip when performing abdominal thrusts
scenarios.additional_info: Provide reassurance and maintain good posture while assisting

scenarios.title: Child Choking on an Object (Life-Threatening)
symptoms: Severe coughing, choking, gagging, or retching
Clutching at the throat or chest with extreme distress
immediate_steps: Back slaps to dislodge the object (repeat up to 5 times if ineffective)
Abdominal thrusts (Heimlich maneuver) with maximum force until the object is dislodged
Call 911 immediately and provide first aid guidance while continuing chest compressions
when_to_seek_help: The child is unresponsive, unconscious, or showing signs of cardiac arrest
no response from back slaps and abdominal thrusts; call 911 ASAP
do_not: Panic or use your own hands to try to dislodge the object (risk of exacerbating injury)
Apply pressure on the child's chest or throat (can cause airway obstruction)
scenarios.additional_info: Provide reassurance, keep the child calm, and continue CPR if trained

scenarios.title: Adult Burns from Electrical Shock in Elderly (65+)
symptoms: Cardiac arrest, severe burns on the face, neck or torso, confusion or disorientation
immediate_steps: Call 911 immediately and begin CPR if trained to do so (be cautious of weakened bones)
Turn off electrical power source if possible
Run cool tap water over the burn for 10-15 minutes (avoid extreme temperatures)
Apply a topical antibiotic ointment to help prevent infection, avoiding harsh chemicals
when_to_seek_help: Severe cardiac arrest or signs of life-threatening internal injuries, worsening condition over time
Difficulty breathing, severe shortness of breath
do_not: Break electrical connections if not trained to do so (risk of injury)
Apply ice to the burns (frozen temperatures can cause further tissue damage)
scenarios.additional_info: Consider pre-existing medical conditions and medications when providing care

scenarios.title: Adult Burns from Electrical Shock (Critical)
symptoms: Cardiac arrest, severe burns on the face, neck or torso with possible airway compromise
Respiratory failure, cardiac arrest, seizures, or loss of consciousness
immediate_steps: Call 911 immediately and begin CPR while trained to do so. Do not stop CPR until medical personnel arrive.
Turn off electrical power source if possible and avoid touching any exposed wires or components
Run cool tap water over the burn for 10-15 minutes, but only after carefully assessing the adult's airway, breathing, and circulation (ABCs)
Apply a topical antibiotic ointment to help prevent infection, but prioritize stabilizing the adult's vital signs
when_to_seek_help: Severe cardiac arrest or signs of life-threatening internal injuries, such as cardiac tamponade or severe bleeding
Unresponsiveness, seizures, or loss of consciousness lasting more than 30 seconds
Difficulty breathing or inability to breathe, requiring oxygen therapy
do_not: Break electrical connections if not trained to do so, as this can cause further injury and is potentially lethal
Apply ice to the burns, as this can cause frostbite and worsen tissue damage
scenarios.additional_info: Provide emotional support and reassurance to the adult's family while also notifying them of the severity of their condition and the need for immediate medical attention

scenarios.title: Elderly Sprains Ankle
symptoms: Severe pain, swelling and bruising around the affected ankle
Difficulty walking or bearing weight on the ankle
immediate_steps: Apply ice for 15-20 minutes to reduce pain and inflammation
Elevate the ankle above heart level to reduce swelling
Use a compression bandage to help stabilize the ankle, but avoid constricting it too tightly
Monitor for numbness, tingling or weakness in the foot or toes
when_to_seek_help: Increasing pain, swelling, or redness around the affected area
Fainting or dizziness upon standing up from a seated position
do_not: Apply heat to the sprain
Bend or move the ankle excessively before medical help arrives, as this can exacerbate injury
Ignore symptoms and continue daily activities without rest
scenarios.additional_info: Provide reassurance and support while resting and elevating the ankle. Consider reaching out to a family member for assistance.

scenarios.title: Child Severely Sprains Ankle
symptoms: Severe pain, swelling, and bruising around the affected ankle
Significant numbness or tingling in the foot or toes
Weakness, difficulty walking, or inability to bear weight
immediate_steps: Call emergency services immediately (911) for severe injury
Apply ice for 15-20 minutes to reduce pain and inflammation
Elevate the ankle above heart level to reduce swelling as much as possible
Use a compression bandage to help stabilize the ankle
when_to_seek_help: Any sign of severe numbness, tingling, or weakness in the foot or toes
Inability to bear weight on the affected ankle
do_not: Apply heat to the sprain
Bend or move the ankle excessively before medical help arrives
scenarios.additional_info: Provide reassurance and support while resting and elevating the ankle. Do not attempt to move the child.

scenarios.title: Heat Stroke in Adults - Critical
symptoms: severe confusion, disorientation, or altered mental status
immediate_steps: CALL 911 IMMEDIATELY AND PROVIDE YOUR LOCATION.
Move the person to a cooler location, ideally in the shade, and remove excess clothing.
Apply cool compresses or ice packs to the neck, armpits, and groin to lower body temperature.
do_not: Do not attempt to treat the person yourself; call 911 immediately.
Avoid moving the person excessively as this can cause more harm.
scenarios.additional_info: Cardiac arrest, seizures, and respiratory failure are possible complications if heat stroke is left untreated. Seek immediate medical attention.

scenarios.title: Critical Venomous Snake Bites
symptoms: Severe swelling, pain, and redness around the bite; difficulty breathing
Systemic symptoms like severe dizziness, nausea, vomiting, and abdominal pain
Rapid heartbeat, low blood pressure, and confusion
immediate_steps: Call 911 immediately and provide location.
Keep the affected limb below heart level to slow down venom flow, but do not move the person unless absolutely necessary.
Remove any constrictive clothing or jewelry from the affected area, but avoid rubbing or applying pressure.
when_to_seek_help: Severe symptoms such as difficulty breathing
do_not: Do not attempt to suck out venom or use home remedies like applying a tourniquet.
Avoid walking the person excessively as this can cause more harm; instead, try to keep them calm and still.
scenarios.additional_info: Seek medical attention immediately, as antivenom may be required. If you are unsure about the severity of the bite, err on the side of caution and seek help.

scenarios.title: Burn from Fire (Severe/Critical)
symptoms: Severe redness, swelling, charring, and potential exposure of underlying tissues
Difficulty breathing, rapid heartbeat, or loss of consciousness
Visible scorching, charring, or blackening of skin
immediate_steps: Call 911 immediately and provide location information
Apply cool tap water for exactly 10 minutes (no longer)
Remove any clothing or jewelry near the burned area, taking care not to touch the burn
Apply a topical antibiotic ointment and cover with a non-stick dressing, securing with medical tape
when_to_seek_help: Severe burns covering more than 10% of body surface area, difficulty breathing, rapid heartbeat, loss of consciousness, or signs of infection (increased redness, swelling, or pus)
do_not: Use butter, egg, ice, or any topical creams without medical supervision
Apply a tourniquet or constrict clothing around the burned area

scenarios.title: Sprained Ankle (65+)
immediate_steps: Apply an ice pack for no more than 15 minutes, 3 times a day
Elevate the ankle above heart level, use a pillow if needed
Compress with a bandage, check regularly to prevent skin breakdown
Monitor for numbness, tingling, or weakness
when_to_seek_help: Signs of infection (redness, warmth, increased pain)
do_not: Move around excessively, take risks with balance
Jump or put weight on the affected ankle
scenarios.additional_info: Avoid overusing the affected area, consider physical therapy to prevent further injury

scenarios.title: Severe Sprained Ankle
symptoms: Swelling and bruising that covers most of the ankle
Difficulty walking or bearing weight on the affected ankle
Numbness or tingling in the foot or toes
immediate_steps: Call 911 immediately
Apply a cold compress or ice pack to the affected area for 15-20 minutes, then alternate with warm compresses for 10-15 minutes
Elevate the ankle above heart level and use a compression bandage or stocking
Immobilize the ankle in a splint or sling if possible
when_to_seek_help: Anytime, but especially if you experience numbness or tingling, difficulty walking, or severe pain that won't improve with treatment
do_not: Move around excessively
Drive yourself to the hospital
Take ibuprofen or acetaminophen without consulting a doctor first
scenarios.additional_info: Seek immediate medical attention if you experience any of the following: severe swelling, difficulty breathing, coldness or paleness of the skin, or pulselessness in the affected area

scenarios.title: Life-Threatening Allergic Reaction
symptoms: Hives covering face, neck, and torso
Swelling of the lips, tongue, or throat

immediate_steps.action: Call 911 or local emergency number immediately

immediate_steps: Administer epinephrine using an EpiPen (if available) while continuing to call for help
Start CPR if victim is unresponsive and not breathing
do_not: Use antihistamines without medical supervision
Administer oxygen unless specifically trained to do so
scenarios.additional_info: Seek immediate medical attention from a qualified healthcare professional

scenarios.title: Severe Bite from a Venomous Snake or Insect
symptoms: Swelling that covers the entire limb or face
Redness around the bite area spreading rapidly
immediate_steps: Remove any constrictive clothing or jewelry around the affected area immediately
Clean the wound with soap and water, then apply a clean bandage to prevent infection
Call 911 and provide your location to emergency services
Administer antivenom if available
when_to_seek_help: Increased pain or swelling that worsens over time
Difficulty breathing or shortness of breath
Numbness, tingling, or weakness in the face, arm, or leg
do_not: Try to suck out the venom
Use ice or cold compresses on the affected area
Give yourself antivenom without medical supervision
scenarios.additional_info: Transport to a hospital immediately if symptoms worsen or do not improve with treatment
scenarios.base_scenario_id: Bite from a Snake or Insect

scenarios.title: Burns from an Open Flame (Elderly)
symptoms: Pain, redness, and swelling around the affected area; difficulty moving or walking
immediate_steps: Cool the burn with cool tap water for 5-10 minutes (avoid immersion)
Remove any constrictive clothing or jewelry around the affected area carefully
Apply a topical antibiotic ointment to prevent infection (consult doctor before use)
when_to_seek_help: Increased pain, swelling, or difficulty breathing
do_not: Use soap, oil, lotion, or any harsh medication on the burn without consulting a doctor
Take any pain medication without consulting a doctor first
scenarios.additional_info: Monitor for signs of infection closely, and be aware of potential complications such as pneumonia, sepsis, or cardiac issues

scenarios.title: Severe Burns from an Open Flame
symptoms: Severe burning sensation that spreads quickly
Extreme redness and swelling around the affected area, with potential for blistering or charring
Difficulty breathing, rapid heartbeat, or dizziness due to smoke inhalation
immediate_steps: CALL 911 IMMEDIATELY and provide your location. Do not attempt to move the person or remove clothing unless absolutely necessary.
Cool the burn with cool tap water for 10-15 minutes, while also providing oxygen if possible
Remove any constrictive clothing or jewelry around the affected area, but only after medical professionals arrive
when_to_seek_help: Severe pain or swelling that worsens over time
Difficulty moving the affected limb or severe numbness/tingling
Signs of smoke inhalation, such as shortness of breath or rapid heartbeat
do_not: Use soap, oil, or lotion on the burn
Apply a topical antibiotic ointment without consulting medical professionals first
scenarios.additional_info: Monitor for signs of infection closely and watch for potential complications such as organ damage or sepsis

scenarios.title: Cuts from Broken Glass (Elderly)
immediate_steps: Stop the bleeding by applying gentle pressure with a clean cloth or bandage. Be cautious not to dislodge any glass fragments.
Clean the wound with mild soap and lukewarm water. Avoid using harsh soaps or hot water, which can slow healing.
do_not: Try to stitch the wound without proper training
Use harsh soap, hydrogen peroxide, or iodine to clean the wound
scenarios.additional_info: Monitor for signs of infection closely and seek medical help if you experience difficulty breathing, chest pain, or severe confusion. Consider seeking immediate medical attention if you have a weakened immune system or are taking immunosuppressive medications.

scenarios.title: Head Injury from a Fall (Elderly)
immediate_steps: Monitor the person for any signs of worsening symptoms closely
Keep them calm and comfortable, in a quiet and warm environment
Do not give them medication unless specified by a medical professional, as they may interact with their current medications
Assist them with mobility to prevent falls
when_to_seek_help: Previous medical conditions (e.g. diabetes, high blood pressure)
do_not: Try to revive the person without proper training
scenarios.additional_info: Monitor for signs of worsening symptoms closely and be aware of potential complications such as dehydration, infection or stroke

scenarios.title: Critical Head Injury from a Fall
symptoms: Disorientation, confusion with altered mental status
Weakness or numbness in face, arm, or leg
immediate_steps: Call 911 immediately and provide location
Position the person on their side to prevent aspiration
Clear airway, start CPR if trained
Do not attempt to move or restrain the person unless absolutely necessary
when_to_seek_help: Severe symptoms persist or worsen within 30 minutes of injury
do_not: Use medication without medical professional guidance
Try to revive the person without proper training or equipment
scenarios.additional_info: Immediate medical attention required, do not delay treatment

scenarios.title: Exposure to Extreme Cold (Elderly)
immediate_steps: Remove wet clothing and replace with dry, warm clothes
Provide small sips of warm, non-frozen tea or broth to drink slowly
Wrap the pet in a blanket or emergency bivvy sack (if possible)
do_not: attempt to give hot beverages directly to avoid burns
congratulate or try to engage the elderly person if they appear confused
scenarios.additional_info: Monitor temperature and watch for signs of heat exhaustion, as hypothermia can progress more quickly in older adults. Be cautious not to overexert them.

scenarios.title: Extreme Cold Exposure - Critical
symptoms: confusion, disorientation, and loss of motor function
immediate_steps: CALL 911 IMMEDIATELY and administer warm IV fluids if available
Remove wet clothing and replace with dry, layered clothing (base layer: wool or synthetic, mid-layer: fleece, outer layer: windproof and water-resistant)
Provide warm, non-frozen IV fluids to treat hypothermia
when_to_seek_help: severe confusion leading to inability to care for self
do_not: attempt to give hot beverages directly
apply heat (e.g., heating pads, hot water bottles) without medical supervision
scenarios.additional_info: Monitor temperature and watch for signs of cardiac arrest

scenarios.title: Severe Burn from Pet Travel
symptoms: Severe redness and swelling that covers a large area of the skin
Severe pain that is difficult to manage with medication
Difficulty breathing or rapid breathing rate
immediate_steps: Call 911 IMMEDIATELY and follow any instructions provided by emergency services.

Administer 1-2 teaspoons of milk of magnesia (not milk) orally if the person is conscious, but DO NOT give milk to an unconscious person. If you are in a remote area with no cell service, drive to the nearest hospital. If you are in a urban area, drive to the nearest hospital and call for help en route.
when_to_seek_help: Severe pain that is unmanageable with medication
do_not: Break blisters or scratch the burn
Use harsh soap or cleansers
Apply any topical ointments without medical supervision
scenarios.additional_info: Burns of this severity can lead to infection, organ damage, and even death. Do not attempt to treat this burn on your own.

scenarios.title: Pet Travel-Related Bites and Stings in Elderly
immediate_steps: Wash the affected area with mild soap and lukewarm water.
Apply a cold compress wrapped in a cloth to reduce swelling (avoid direct ice).
Take antihistamines or hydrocortisone cream if prescribed by your vet, but avoid taking more than directed.
do_not: Rub the affected area aggressively or use ice directly on the skin
Give the pet medication without consulting a vet first
scenarios.additional_info: Elderly patients may be more susceptible to anaphylaxis. If symptoms persist or worsen, seek immediate medical attention.

scenarios.title: Pet Travel-Related Bites and Stings (Severe)
symptoms: severe swelling that covers large areas of the face, neck, or body
immediate_steps: Call 911 immediately for a critical emergency response.
do_not: Rub the affected area aggressively
Use ice directly on the skin
Try to treat symptoms without medical attention
scenarios.additional_info: Anaphylaxis is a life-threatening allergic reaction that requires immediate medical attention. If you suspect anaphylaxis, start CPR if the person's airway is blocked and begins administering epinephrine using an EpiPen or other auto-injector.

scenarios.title: Pet Heat Stroke in Vehicle (Elderly)
immediate_steps: Turn on the vehicle's air conditioning or open windows to create cross-ventilation, taking care not to over-exert yourself.
Provide cool water for your pet to drink, and offer small frequent meals to prevent dehydration.
Call a veterinarian or emergency service immediately.
do_not: Leave your pet alone in the vehicle for extended periods
Use hot water or direct heat, which can exacerbate dehydration and health conditions.
Neglect to seek medical attention if you or your pet are experiencing symptoms

scenarios.title: Car Crash-Related Injuries for Elderly Patients (65+)
immediate_steps: Call emergency services immediately.
Provide a comfortable and quiet environment for the elderly patient.
do_not: Move the elderly patient excessively
Use heavy equipment or restraints without assistance
scenarios.additional_info: Elderly patients may experience falls and injuries due to decreased mobility. Consider removing tripping hazards and improving lighting in the home.

scenarios.title: Severe Car Crash-Related Injuries for Pets
symptoms: limb deformity with inability to move or use the affected limb
respiratory distress with difficulty breathing and possible blue discoloration of gums, lips, or skin
immediate_steps: Call 911 IMMEDIATELY for emergency veterinary services.
Provide a safe and comfortable environment for your pet, but do not move them excessively.
Use a towel or blanket to gently stabilize the affected limb(s) and keep them still.
Administer oxygen if available, but only by trained personnel.
when_to_seek_help: limb deformity with inability to move
do_not: Move your pet excessively, as this can worsen injuries.
Use heavy equipment or restraints, which can cause further injury.
Drive to a veterinary clinic yourself if symptoms are severe.

scenarios.title: Pet Travel-Related Anxiety in Elderly
immediate_steps: Provide a familiar environment and comfortable seating.
Use calming aids such as pheromone diffusers or calming music.
Consult with your vet about medication options for anxiety.
do_not: Leave your pet alone in the vehicle for extended periods without access to water and rest.
Use sedatives that may interact with prescribed medications or worsen health conditions.

scenarios.title: Pet Travel-Related Anxiety (Severe)
immediate_steps: Provide a familiar environment and comfort object immediately.
Use calming aids such as pheromone diffusers or calming treats, but do not delay.
Call emergency services (911) and place your pet in a secure location if symptoms worsen.
do_not: Leave your pet alone in the vehicle for more than 30 minutes without immediate assistance.
Use sedatives without consulting a vet or in emergency situations where life-threatening symptoms occur.
scenarios.additional_info: If your pet shows signs of cardiac arrest, difficulty breathing, or severe vomiting, call 911 immediately.

scenarios.title: Life-Threatening Burn Scalds from Hurricane Debris
symptoms: Severe burning sensation that cannot be relieved with pain medication
Blisters filled with pus or fluid
immediate_steps: Call 911 immediately and provide as much information as possible about the injury
Remove any clothing or jewelry near the burned area, but do not attempt to move the person if they are unconscious
Apply a topical antibiotic ointment and cover with a non-stick dressing, while also keeping the affected area elevated above heart level
when_to_seek_help: Signs of severe infection, such as fever over 103째F or increased redness around the wound
do_not: Use ice to treat burns
Apply a tourniquet or constrict clothing around the burned area
scenarios.additional_info: Burns from hurricane-related debris can be extremely severe and potentially life-threatening

scenarios.title: Severe Burns from Fire (Elderly)
symptoms: Swelling, bruising, or redness in surrounding skin
immediate_steps: Cool the burn with cool water for 10-15 minutes. Avoid cold compresses or ice packs, as they may cause further harm to fragile bones.
Remove clothing and jewelry near the burn area carefully, as elderly skin is more prone to bruising.
when_to_seek_help: Fever, redness, or signs of infection
do_not: Using butter or oil to moisturize the burned area, as this can slow healing and lead to further complications.
scenarios.additional_info: Elderly patients may be more susceptible to burns due to decreased mobility and fragile bones. Seek medical attention immediately for severe burns.

scenarios.title: Hiking Accident with Broken Ankle (Elderly)
immediate_steps: Stop activity and apply the RICE principle (Rest, Ice, Compression, Elevation) with caution to avoid numbness or tingling
Elevate the injured ankle above heart level, but avoid bending or twisting
Apply a compression bandage to help control bleeding, but avoid too much pressure
when_to_seek_help: Significant numbness or tingling in the leg, difficulty walking, or shortness of breath
do_not: Using ice directly on the skin for more than 15 minutes
Bending or twisting the injured ankle
Walking or putting weight on the injured ankle
scenarios.additional_info: Seek medical attention immediately if symptoms worsen or if you have a history of osteoporosis, diabetes, or heart disease.

scenarios.title: Hiking Accident with Fractured Ankle
immediate_steps: Stop activity immediately and apply RICE principle (Rest, Ice, Compression, Elevation)
Elevate injured ankle above heart level
Apply compression bandage to help control bleeding
Call 911 or emergency services for critical injuries
Administer basic life support (CPR) if person is unconscious
when_to_seek_help: Significant numbness or tingling in leg
Coldness to the touch of injured area
Pain not manageable with pain medication
do_not: Using ice directly on the skin without protective wrap
Moving injured ankle excessively
Ignoring numbness/tingling sensations in leg
scenarios.additional_info: Seek immediate medical attention for severe, life-threatening injuries. Prompt medical care can save a limb.

scenarios.title: Sting from Bee or Wasp (65+)
immediate_steps: Remove stinger by scraping it off with a credit card or fingernail; avoid squeezing the stinger further into the skin
Wash the affected area with soap and water; pat dry gently to prevent irritation
Apply a cold compress, but not directly on broken skin
when_to_seek_help: Difficulty breathing, rapid heartbeat, or dizziness
do_not: Using heat to alleviate symptoms, as it can worsen swelling and discomfort
scenarios.additional_info: Monitor for signs of anaphylaxis, especially in older adults with pre-existing conditions

scenarios.title: Life-Threatening Sting from Bee or Wasp
immediate_steps: Call 911 immediately and provide your location
Remove stinger by scraping it off with a credit card or fingernail while carefully avoiding any further exposure to venom
Administer epinephrine auto-injector (e.g. EpiPen) if available
when_to_seek_help: Severe swelling that causes difficulty swallowing or speaking
Hives or itchy skin all over the body
do_not: Using heat to alleviate symptoms
Applying a cold compress without consulting a medical professional
scenarios.additional_info: Monitor for signs of anaphylaxis. If you experience any of these symptoms, call 911 or your local emergency number immediately.

scenarios.title: Burn from Open Flame (Elderly)
immediate_steps: Stop the burning process by smothering with a non-flammable material, if possible. If unable to do so, use a towel or cloth to cover the burn.
when_to_seek_help: Spontaneous combustion of clothing or bedding
Decreased sensation or numbness in hands or feet
do_not: Break blisters or scabbing. This can lead to infection.
Use ice or ice water, as it can cause further damage to fragile bones and tissues.
scenarios.additional_info: Seek medical attention immediately if the burn covers a large area or is deep, especially if you have diabetes, poor circulation, or other health conditions that may affect healing. Elderly individuals with certain medications, such as blood thinners, should also seek immediate care.

scenarios.title: Critical Burn from Open Flame
immediate_steps: Call 911 immediately
Stop the burning process by smothering with a non-flammable material
Remove clothing and jewelry near the burn area
Apply cool water or a burn cream to reduce heat and promote healing
Stabilize the victim's airway, if possible
Provide CPR if trained
Administer epinephrine auto-injector, if available
when_to_seek_help: Spontaneous combustion of clothing or bedding
Loss of bladder or bowel function
do_not: Break blisters or scabbing
Use ice or ice water
Reapply burn cream until medical help arrives
Move the victim excessively
Administer any medications without medical supervision
Apply a tourniquet or constrictive bandage
Use a cold compress on the face, neck, or torso
scenarios.additional_info: Seek immediate medical attention if the burn covers a large area or is deep. Critical burns may require hospitalization for treatment.

scenarios.title: Torn ACL in Elderly
symptoms: Pain in the knee area that worsens with walking or standing
Swelling and bruising around the knee, possibly due to a fall
immediate_steps: Stop activity and apply ice to reduce swelling for 15-20 minutes, then reapply every 2-3 hours
Compress the knee with an elastic bandage, but avoid tightness that may cut off circulation
when_to_seek_help: Signs of infection (redness, warmth, fever) or bleeding around the knee
do_not: Try to put weight on the affected knee until pain subsides
Bend or straighten the knee excessively
Ignore pain and continue with daily activities
scenarios.additional_info: Seek medical attention immediately if you experience severe symptoms, as a torn ACL can increase the risk of osteoporosis and fractures in elderly patients.

scenarios.title: Bleeding Control with Tourniquet for Elderly
symptoms: bleeding, pale skin, dizziness or fainting
immediate_steps: Apply a tourniquet to the affected limb if bleeding is severe and cannot be controlled with pressure alone. However, consider alternative methods first, such as applying a hemostatic agent or seeking medical attention immediately.
when_to_seek_help: bleeding that doesn't stop after 10-15 minutes of pressure
do_not: Remove the tourniquet unless absolutely necessary and in the presence of severe hypotension or cardiac instability, as it can cause more harm
Use a tourniquet on individuals with a history of vascular disease or peripheral artery disease
Apply pressure to wounds that are near the spine or neck
scenarios.additional_info: Consider the patient's underlying medical conditions and medications before applying a tourniquet. Elderly patients may be more susceptible to complications from bleeding control.

scenarios.title: Critical Bleeding Control with Tourniquet
symptoms: severe bleeding, pale skin, rapid heartbeat, shortness of breath
immediate_steps: Apply a tourniquet to the affected limb immediately and call 911. If unavailable, call local emergency number.
Start CPR if person is unresponsive or not breathing. Continue chest compressions until medical help arrives.
Immobilize injured area with a splint or sling if possible.
when_to_seek_help: bleeding that doesn't stop after 1-2 minutes of pressure
do_not: Remove the tourniquet unless absolutely necessary, as it can cause more harm. Do not attempt to apply a tourniquet yourself if you are not trained.
scenarios.additional_info: Tourniquets should only be used by trained professionals in emergency situations.

scenarios.title: Choking on a Foreign Object (Elderly)
symptoms: loss of consciousness, confusion, or disorientation
immediate_steps: Back slaps on the person's back between their shoulder blades, but be cautious not to hit the spine.
Perform abdominal thrusts (if you are trained) until the object is removed or the person becomes unresponsive. Use your arms to support the person's head and body during thrusts.
Continue chest compressions if the person becomes unresponsive.
when_to_seek_help: inability to speak, coughing, choking, loss of consciousness
do_not: Use your fingers to try and remove the object from the person's mouth. This can cause injury or push the object further into the airway.
Apply any sort of forceps or tweezers to try and retrieve the object without proper training.
scenarios.additional_info: Choking in elderly can be more severe due to fragile bones, medications, and underlying medical conditions. Call 911 immediately if you suspect choking or loss of consciousness.

scenarios.title: Life-Threatening Choking on a Foreign Object
symptoms: severe inability to speak, coughing, choking with blood or vomit
increased heart rate and/or blood pressure, blue-tinged lips or face
immediate_steps: Back slaps on the person's back between their shoulder blades to dislodge the object. Call 911 immediately and ask for EMTs.
Perform abdominal thrusts (if you are trained) until the object is removed or the person becomes unresponsive. Continue chest compressions if the person becomes unresponsive.
Start CPR if the person is not breathing.
when_to_seek_help: Severe inability to speak, coughing, choking with blood or vomit, increased heart rate and/or blood pressure
do_not: Use your fingers to try and remove the object from the person's mouth
Continue rescue breaths if you are not trained in CPR. Call 911 immediately.
scenarios.additional_info: Choking can be a sign of anaphylaxis or asthma attack. Delaying help can lead to brain damage or death. Every minute counts.

scenarios.title: Burns from Heat or Flame (Elderly)
immediate_steps: Cool the burn with cool tap water for 10-15 minutes to reduce temperature and ease pain.
Remove any clothing or jewelry near the burned area carefully to avoid further injury.
Apply a topical antibiotic ointment to the affected area, but avoid breaking blisters.
when_to_seek_help: Burns that cover more than 1/3 of the body surface, blisters, charring, fever over 101.5째F (38.6째C)
Difficulty breathing or shortness of breath
do_not: Use ice or ice water on burns
Apply heat to the burned area
scenarios.additional_info: Burns can be serious and lead to infection in elderly patients. Be cautious of potential complications such as cardiac issues.

scenarios.title: Severe Burns from Heat or Flame
symptoms: severe redness, swelling, pain, charring, blisters, difficulty breathing
immediate_steps: Call 911 immediately. Cool the burn with cool tap water for 10-15 minutes to reduce temperature and ease pain.
Remove any clothing or jewelry near the burned area.
Apply a topical antibiotic ointment to the affected area.
Do not move the person unless they are unconscious; if they are conscious, stay with them until medical help arrives.
when_to_seek_help: Burns that cover more than 1/3 of the body surface, blisters, charring, difficulty breathing, loss of consciousness
do_not: Use ice or ice water on burns
Apply a tourniquet or tight bandage
scenarios.additional_info: Severe burns can be life-threatening. Do not attempt to treat the burn yourself; call 911 immediately and follow instructions from emergency responders.

scenarios.title: CPR for Cardiac Arrest in Elderly Patients (65+)
symptoms: no pulse, no breathing, confusion or disorientation
immediate_steps: Call 911 or your local emergency number and begin CPR.
Start chest compressions at a rate of 80-100 per minute (slower pace recommended for elderly).
Continue chest compressions until emergency medical personnel arrive, taking regular breaks to rest.
do_not: Use the person's defibrillator if they are in cardiac arrest; consider alternative options due to potential risks.
Perform back blows or chest thrusts unless you are trained to do so safely and effectively for elderly patients.
scenarios.additional_info: CPR should be started immediately if someone is unresponsive and not breathing or has no pulse. Consider the person's underlying medical conditions when performing CPR.

scenarios.title: Critical CPR for Cardiac Arrest
symptoms: No pulse, no breathing, pale or blue-tinged skin
immediate_steps: Call 911 IMMEDIATELY and begin CPR. Do not wait for an answer.
Start chest compressions at a rate of 100-120 per minute with the heel of one hand on the center of the chest.
when_to_seek_help: No pulse, no breathing, or any signs of cardiac arrest
do_not: Use a bystander's cell phone to call for help. Use your own phone to call 911.
Give the person oxygen unless they are trained to do so.
scenarios.additional_info: CPR should be started immediately if someone is unresponsive, not breathing, or has no pulse. Call 911 while performing CPR if possible.

scenarios.title: Severe Bite or Sting from Insect
symptoms: severe pain, extreme redness, swelling, difficulty breathing, rapid heartbeat
immediate_steps: Call 911 immediately.
Wash the wound with soap and water, then apply a cold compress or an ice pack wrapped in cloth to reduce pain and swelling.
Administer epinephrine auto-injector if available, then give antihistamines.
Immobilize the affected area with a splint if broken limbs are present.
when_to_seek_help: Bites or stings that are severely painful, swollen, infected, or cause difficulty breathing
do_not: Squeeze the insect's body or try to remove the venom with tweezers
Apply heat to the affected area
Delay calling 911 for more than 15 minutes
scenarios.additional_info: Some insect bites and stings can cause life-threatening anaphylaxis. If symptoms persist, seek immediate medical help.

scenarios.title: Broken Bone (Fracture) in the Elderly
symptoms: pain, swelling, difficulty moving the affected limb, dizziness or fainting
immediate_steps: Apply a sling or splint to support the injured limb and keep it elevated.
Call for emergency assistance and get to a hospital as soon as possible. Consider reaching out to family/friends for help with transportation.
Sit or lie down and rest until medical help arrives.
when_to_seek_help: Pain, swelling, difficulty moving the affected limb
Loss of consciousness or severe dizziness
do_not: Try to move or put weight on the injured limb
Take NSAIDs without consulting a doctor first
Drive yourself to the hospital
scenarios.additional_info: Broken bones can be serious in older adults. Consider age-related medications, medical conditions, and co-existing health issues when evaluating symptoms.

scenarios.title: Severe Broken Bone (Fracture) - Critical
symptoms: Severe pain, swelling, difficulty moving the affected limb, numbness or tingling in the face or extremities
immediate_steps: Apply a splint and immobilize the injured limb. Call 911 immediately.
Get to a hospital as quickly and safely as possible.
Keep the person calm and still until medical help arrives.
Do not attempt to move the person or apply ice unless instructed by medical professionals.
when_to_seek_help: Severe pain, swelling, difficulty moving the affected limb
do_not: Try to move the injured limb
Apply ice without medical guidance
Put weight on the injured limb
scenarios.additional_info: Broken bones can be life-threatening. Call 911 and seek immediate medical attention if symptoms occur.

scenarios.title: Choking on Food (Severe)
symptoms: inability to speak, severe coughing, choking, blue-tinged skin or lips, loss of consciousness
immediate_steps: Back slaps on the person's back between their shoulder blades to dislodge the object. If they don't respond, use a second person to perform abdominal thrusts.
Continue chest compressions with a defibrillator if available. Call 911 immediately and begin CPR.
Administer epinephrine auto-injector (EpiPen) if available and known to be effective for the person's allergy history.
when_to_seek_help: Inability to speak, severe coughing, choking, blue-tinged skin or lips
do_not: Use your fingers to try and remove the object from the person's mouth
Give the person anything to drink
scenarios.additional_info: Choking can be a sign of anaphylaxis, asthma attack, or severe food allergy. Call 911 immediately and begin CPR if necessary.

scenarios.title: Severe Head Injury in Elderly
symptoms: Confusion, dizziness, loss of consciousness, sudden severe headache
Slurred speech, difficulty walking, or balance problems
immediate_steps: Call for emergency assistance and get to a hospital as soon as possible.
Keep the person calm, still, and upright if able.
Do not give them anything to eat or drink.
do_not: Try to move the person's head or neck
Give them any medications unless advised by medical professionals
scenarios.additional_info: Severe head injuries in elderly can be life-threatening. Seek immediate medical attention if symptoms occur.

scenarios.title: Severe Dehydration (Critical)
immediate_steps: Call 911 immediately and begin CPR if unresponsive.
Apply a cold compress or an ice pack wrapped in cloth to reduce body temperature and ease pain.
Administer water orally in small amounts (1-2 teaspoons) every 10-15 minutes until improvement, but be cautious not to overhydrate.
when_to_seek_help: Symptoms worsen within 30 minutes of treatment
do_not: Give them medication without proper medical supervision
Offer hot drinks or heavy food and liquids
scenarios.additional_info: Severe dehydration can be life-threatening. If symptoms persist, seek immediate medical attention.

scenarios.title: Cardiac Arrest - Severe
symptoms: Unresponsive and blue-tinged skin or lips
immediate_steps: Call **911 IMMEDIATELY** (or your local emergency number) and begin CPR.
Start chest compressions at a rate of 100-120 per minute, with continuous defibrillation until emergency medical personnel arrive if available.
do_not: Do not attempt to revive the person on your own; call for emergency assistance immediately.
scenarios.additional_info: CPR should be started immediately if someone is unresponsive and not breathing or has no pulse. If you are not trained in CPR, use a manual defibrillator only if you have been instructed to do so by an emergency medical technician.

scenarios.title: Burn Scald in Elderly
