symptoms: Redness, swelling, and blistering; may also experience dizziness, nausea, or confusion due to decreased circulation
immediate_steps: Cool the burn with cool tap water for 10 minutes; be cautious not to apply ice directly to the skin
Remove any clothing or jewelry near the burned area; avoid tight clothing that may constrict blood flow
Apply a topical antibiotic ointment and cover with non-stick dressing to prevent infection
when_to_seek_help: Infection, blisters that won't heal; seek medical attention if symptoms worsen or last longer than 1 week
Dehydration, fever over 101.5째F (38.6째C), or difficulty breathing
do_not: Break blisters, use home remedies without medical supervision; avoid using harsh soaps or cleansers on the burned area
Apply direct pressure to the burn site; elevate legs if swelling occurs
scenarios.additional_info: Be aware that older adults may be more susceptible to complications from scalds due to decreased circulation and medication side effects

scenarios.title: Deep Cut Wound in Elderly
symptoms: Bleeding, swelling, and bruising; difficulty breathing; rapid heart rate
immediate_steps: Apply gentle pressure to the wound with a clean cloth or bandage; sit comfortably and avoid strenuous activity
Clean the wound with mild soap and lukewarm water; apply an over-the-counter antibiotic ointment, but do not use hydrogen peroxide or iodine
Elevate the injured area above heart level to reduce swelling
when_to_seek_help: Increased pain, difficulty walking, or signs of infection (redness, warmth, or pus)
Severe bleeding that doesn't stop with pressure; shortness of breath; rapid heartbeat
do_not: Cut away clothing to access the wound; do not attempt to walk on the injured area
Use harsh soap, hydrogen peroxide, or iodine; do not apply tight bandages
scenarios.additional_info: Seek medical attention immediately if symptoms worsen or last longer than 3 days. Elderly patients may be more susceptible to complications such as blood clots and deep vein thrombosis.

scenarios.title: Critical Deep Cut Wound
symptoms: Severe bleeding, heavy swelling, bruising, and discoloration
immediate_steps: Apply firm pressure to the wound with a clean cloth or bandage, above the injury. If unable to apply pressure, use a tourniquet if available
Clean the wound with soap and water, then apply an antibiotic ointment. DO NOT clean or dress the wound further without medical guidance
Elevate the injured area above heart level, and move to a safe location
when_to_seek_help: Any signs of shock (dizziness, pale skin, weak pulse) or severe infection (pus, redness, swelling beyond original injury)
Loss of sensation or feeling in the injured area
Signs of circulatory failure (cold, clammy skin, fast heartbeat)
do_not: Cut away clothing to access the wound
Apply any topical treatments without medical guidance
scenarios.additional_info: Call 911 immediately. Seek immediate medical attention if symptoms worsen or last longer than 2 hours.

scenarios.title: Eye Injury (Elderly)
symptoms: Blurred vision, eye pain, or sensitivity to light
immediate_steps: Flush the eye with cool tap water for 5-10 seconds (avoid rubbing the eye)
Apply a sterile bandage or gauze to protect the eye
Seek medical attention immediately
when_to_seek_help: Increased pain, vision loss, double vision, or sensitivity to light that worsens over time
do_not: Use soap on the injured eye (may irritate), ointments without consulting a doctor, or other substances on the injured eye
Rub the eye vigorously as it may cause further damage
scenarios.additional_info: Eye injuries can be serious and may cause permanent damage in elderly patients. Prompt medical attention is crucial to prevent complications.

scenarios.title: Severe Falling Debris Injury
immediate_steps: Call emergency services immediately (911)
Stop movement and move to a safe location
Apply firm pressure to the wound to control bleeding
Elevate the injured area above heart level
Use an ice pack or cold compress wrapped in a cloth to reduce swelling
when_to_seek_help: Severe bleeding that won't stop with pressure
do_not: Disregard injury and attempt to move the person
Apply heat to the wound
Delay calling emergency services for more than a few minutes
scenarios.additional_info: If you are unsure about severity, err on the side of caution. Call 911 regardless.

scenarios.title: Burns from Fire (Elderly)
immediate_steps: Call 911 or your local emergency number
Stop the burning process with cool water, avoid running water
Remove contaminated clothing and jewelry carefully to avoid further injury
Cover the burn area with a sterile dressing, avoid tight bandages
Monitor for return of consciousness, be aware of medication interactions
when_to_seek_help: Unresponsiveness or difficulty responding to verbal commands
do_not: Administer epinephrine without proper training, as it may interact with medications
Use a tourniquet without proper training, as it may cause further injury
Bend or lift, instead use mechanical assistance if needed
scenarios.additional_info: If you are trained in CPR for the elderly, start it immediately

scenarios.title: Frostbite in Elderly Patients (65+)
immediate_steps: Call 911 or your local emergency number immediately
Immerse the affected area in warm water (no hotter than body temperature)
Remove wet clothing and provide dry, warm clothing
Use a topical ointment to promote healing (consult doctor before use)
Monitor for return of sensation and report any concerns
do_not: Administer epinephrine without proper training (especially in elderly)
Use a tourniquet without proper training (may cause more harm)
Disregard medication interactions with frostbite treatment
scenarios.additional_info: Consult doctor before taking any medications or using topical ointments

scenarios.title: Heat Stroke (Critical)
immediate_steps: Call 911 IMMEDIATELY and provide critical information (e.g., victim's age, weight, medical conditions)
Move the victim to a cooler location (shade or air-conditioned space) if possible
Remove excess clothing and wet them with cool tap water (or apply cold compresses) to lower body temperature
Provide cool water to drink, but do not force it down their throat. Use an oral rehydration solution if available
Monitor for return of consciousness closely and be prepared to start CPR if they become unresponsive
do_not: Administer epinephrine without proper training
Use a tourniquet without proper training
Try to cool the victim with ice baths or cold compresses alone
scenarios.additional_info: If you are trained in CPR, start it immediately. If not, begin chest compressions and call for help.

scenarios.title: Broken Wrist in Elderly Patient (65+)
immediate_steps: Stop activity and apply ice pack for 10 minutes, but avoid icing the same area for more than 48 hours to prevent frostbite
Elevate the injured arm above heart level, using a supportive pillow if needed
when_to_seek_help: severe pain that does not improve with rest and ice
difficulty moving the wrist or wrist weakness
numbness or tingling in fingers worsens or is accompanied by loss of sensation
do_not: moving the wrist unnecessarily, as this can exacerbate the injury and increase risk of osteoporotic fracture
using heat on the injury, as this can cause further damage to fragile skin and tissues
scenarios.additional_info: Consider seeking medical attention within 24 hours if symptoms worsen or do not improve, especially if taking blood thinners or having a history of osteoporosis. Elderly patients may also require additional assessment for other potential complications such as infection or nerve damage

scenarios.title: Severe Wrist Fracture
symptoms: Limited mobility and inability to move wrist
immediate_steps: Call 911 immediately and stay on the line with emergency services
Apply a cold compress or ice pack for 15-20 minutes, then switch to warm compresses for 10-15 minutes
Use a sling to immobilize the wrist and elevate above heart level
when_to_seek_help: Any severe pain or difficulty moving the wrist
Pus or open wound at the injury site
do_not: Moving the wrist unless absolutely necessary for medical attention
Using heat on the injury
Removing any splints or immobilization devices
scenarios.additional_info: Seek immediate medical attention if symptoms worsen or do not improve within 24 hours. Disregard for severe pain or swelling can lead to further injury or nerve damage

scenarios.title: Severe Bleeding from Wound in Elderly
immediate_steps: Apply pressure to the wound with a clean cloth
Elevate the injured limb above heart level, but avoid exacerbating dehydration
Call for medical help immediately and sit/lie down if able
do_not: Remove the bandage from the wound, as it may increase bleeding
Apply a tourniquet unless advised by medical professional
Touch the wound with bare hands to avoid infection risk
Lift heavy objects or try to move around excessively
scenarios.additional_info: Monitor vital signs closely and report any worsening symptoms to healthcare provider

scenarios.title: Critical Bleeding from Wound
symptoms: severe bleeding with rapid blood loss
pale skin, cool extremities, and decreased urine output
irregular heart rhythm, shock, or cardiac arrest
immediate_steps: Call 911 immediately and provide location
Apply a tourniquet if available and within reach
Elevate the injured limb above heart level and apply firm pressure to the wound with a clean cloth
when_to_seek_help: Severe blood loss that is not controlled
Decreased breathing rate (less than 10 breaths per minute)
do_not: Remove the bandage from the wound, even if it's stuck to your skin
Touch the wound with bare hands, as this can cause further injury
scenarios.additional_info: Administer CPR if person is unresponsive and not breathing

scenarios.title: Bites and Stings in Elderly
immediate_steps: Wash the wound with soap and water
Apply a cold compress to reduce swelling (avoid direct contact with skin)
Clean and dress the wound, but avoid breaking blisters
do_not: apply heat or tight bandages
ignore numbness or tingling (seek medical attention)
scenarios.additional_info: Consult a doctor if unsure about wound care or symptoms worsen over time

scenarios.title: Life-Threatening Bites and Stings
immediate_steps: Call 911 immediately
Administer epinephrine auto-injector if available
Apply a cold compress to reduce swelling while immobilizing the affected area with a splint
Do not attempt to clean or dress the wound
when_to_seek_help: If you experience difficulty breathing, rapid heartbeat, dizziness, or fainting
do_not: Do not try to remove the stinger or bite from your skin
scenarios.additional_info: Seek medical attention immediately if you experience any of the above symptoms

scenarios.title: Poisoning from Insecticides in Elderly
immediate_steps: Call the poison control hotline (if available)
Provide information about the poison while sitting with the person
Keep the person calm, comfortable, and in a safe position
when_to_seek_help: If symptoms worsen or last longer than 30 minutes
do_not: Give medication unless instructed to do so by medical professionals
Try to induce vomiting unless advised by medical professionals

scenarios.title: Severe Poisoning from Insecticides
symptoms: rapid heartbeat, difficulty breathing, and collapse
immediate_steps: Call 911 immediately (or seek emergency medical services)
Provide information about the poison to emergency responders
Keep the person on their back with their head elevated
do_not: Do not try to give the person anything to eat or drink
scenarios.additional_info: Insecticides can be fatal if ingested, inhaled, or absorbed through the skin

scenarios.title: Severe Burns from Chemicals
immediate_steps: Remove contaminated clothing and jewelry IMMEDIATELY
Flush the affected area with water for 20 minutes; use a saline solution if available
Call emergency services AND call 911 directly. Provide a first aid kit but only as secondary action.
Administer oxygen if available
Perform CPR if cardiac arrest is suspected
do_not: Do not try to neutralize the chemical yourself
Do not apply topical creams or gels without medical supervision
scenarios.additional_info: Chemical burns can be fatal. If in doubt, err on the side of caution and seek immediate medical attention.

scenarios.title: Respiratory Issues from Insecticides in the Elderly
symptoms: coughing (which may produce yellow or green mucus)
immediate_steps: Call the poison control hotline (if available) immediately for guidance
Provide oxygen if necessary, but be cautious not to dislodge any clots
Sit the person up slowly and carefully to help them breathe more easily
when_to_seek_help: If symptoms worsen or do not improve with treatment
If the person shows signs of respiratory failure (e.g., blue discoloration, rapid breathing)
do_not: Do not attempt to give the person any medication without consulting a healthcare professional first
scenarios.additional_info: Elderly individuals may be more susceptible to the effects of insecticide exposure due to age-related declines in lung function and cardiovascular health.

scenarios.title: Respiratory Issues from Insecticides (Severe)
symptoms: difficulty breathing, feeling of choking, chest pain, rapid heartbeat
coughing up blood, bloody sputum, cyanosis (blue-tinged skin)
immediate_steps: Call 911 immediately and provide critical information to the operator
Provide oxygen via non-rebreather mask if available, but prioritize getting the person to the hospital
Keep the person's airway open with their mouth or nose tilted back, sitting upright with legs elevated
Do not give them anything to eat or drink unless instructed to do so by medical professionals
when_to_seek_help: If symptoms worsen or do not improve within 30 minutes
If the person shows signs of seizures, loss of consciousness, or coma
do_not: Do not attempt to treat the person yourself without proper training and equipment
Do not give the person any medication unless instructed to do so by medical professionals
scenarios.additional_info: Insecticides can cause severe respiratory distress, even death. If you suspect exposure or are unsure about what to do, err on the side of caution and call 911.

scenarios.title: Muscle Strains in Elderly
immediate_steps: Apply ice pack to reduce swelling (10-15 minutes, 3 times a day)
Provide rest and immobilization for 2-3 days
Use pain medication as directed by doctor or pharmacist
Consider assistive devices for walking
when_to_seek_help: Severe pain that doesn't improve with medication
Difficulty breathing or shortness of breath
Weakness or numbness in face or extremities
do_not: Bending or twisting to move affected limb
Ignoring pain and continuing activities
Taking unnecessary medications without doctor's guidance
scenarios.additional_info: Elderly may be at risk for osteoporosis; consider calcium and vitamin D supplements.

scenarios.title: Eye Injuries from Chemicals in the Elderly
immediate_steps: Flush the affected eye with water for 10-15 minutes, but do not use soap or any other substance
Provide a first aid kit and sit the person down in a comfortable position
when_to_seek_help: If symptoms worsen or last longer than 30 minutes
If the person experiences severe eye pain, double vision, or difficulty breathing
do_not: Apply any ointments or creams to the affected eye without medical supervision
scenarios.additional_info: Elderly may be more susceptible to chemical injuries due to age-related changes in the eyes. If you suspect an elderly person has been exposed to chemicals, seek immediate medical attention.

scenarios.title: Burns from Electrical Sources in Elderly
immediate_steps: Call emergency services immediately if unable to turn off power source
Remove contaminated clothing and jewelry carefully to avoid further injury
Provide first aid for burns, but be cautious not to dislodge a pacemaker or other implant
when_to_seek_help: If unsure about the severity of the burn
do_not: Do not attempt to move the person unless absolutely necessary
scenarios.additional_info: Elderly individuals may be more susceptible to cardiac complications due to underlying medical conditions.

scenarios.title: Critical Burns from Electrical Sources
immediate_steps: Turn off the power source IMMEDIATELY if possible
Remove contaminated clothing and jewelry RIGHT AWAY
Provide first aid for burns and call 911 RIGHT NOW
Start CPR if the person is unresponsive
when_to_seek_help: Immediately seek medical attention if symptoms worsen or do not improve
Call 911 immediately if the person is experiencing any of the following: difficulty breathing, seizures, unconsciousness
do_not: Do NOT attempt to remove jewelry or clothing if it is stuck to the burn
scenarios.additional_info: Burns from electrical sources can cause severe injuries and even death. If you suspect someone has been electrocuted, call 911 immediately and provide first aid.

scenarios.title: Hypothermia from Drowning in Elderly
immediate_steps: Call 911 or your local emergency number
Remove wet clothing and provide warmth with blankets
Use oxygen if necessary, but be cautious of carbon monoxide risk
do_not: Do not move the person unless they are in immediate danger
Do not give medication without consulting a doctor first

scenarios.title: Hypothermia from Drowning (Critical)
immediate_steps: Call 911 IMMEDIATELY, do not wait for help to arrive
Remove wet clothing and provide warmth immediately, use blankets or a space heater if available
Administer oxygen via mask if symptoms persist, but only if you are trained to do so
do_not: Do not attempt to give the person hot drinks or showers

scenarios.title: Poisoning from Household Cleaning Products in Elderly
immediate_steps: Call the poison control hotline (if available) immediately
Provide information about the product to the caller
Help the person sit down and remain calm while you call for help
Loosen tight clothing around the neck, waist, and arms if necessary
when_to_seek_help: If symptoms worsen or do not improve within 30 minutes of treatment
If the person experiences difficulty breathing, chest pain, or severe vomiting
If the person has a pre-existing medical condition, such as kidney disease or heart failure
do_not: Do not attempt to induce vomiting unless instructed by a healthcare professional
Do not give the person any medications without consulting a healthcare professional first
Do not move the person unless necessary to prevent injury
scenarios.additional_info: Elderly individuals may be more susceptible to poisoning due to decreased kidney function, altered drug metabolism, and potential polypharmacy.

scenarios.title: Allergic Reactions to Medications in Older Adults
immediate_steps: Sit or lie down and call 911 or your local emergency number immediately
Administer epinephrine using an EpiPen (if available) but only if you have prior training
when_to_seek_help: If symptoms worsen or last longer than 30 minutes
do_not: Do not attempt to drive after receiving epinephrine
Avoid giving antihistamines to older adults with kidney disease or liver disease
scenarios.additional_info: Older adults may experience different symptoms due to age-related changes. Seek medical attention promptly if symptoms persist.

scenarios.title: Severe Allergic Reactions to Medications
symptoms: hives covering most of the body
severe itching causing skin cracking and bleeding
immediate_steps: Administer epinephrine using an EpiPen (if available) while calling 911 IMMEDIATELY
Provide antihistamines, antacids, and oxygen if available
when_to_seek_help: When symptoms worsen or do not improve with treatment
do_not: Do not attempt to administer epinephrine without proper training and equipment
Do not give any medication that contains histamine without consulting a doctor first
scenarios.additional_info: Severe allergic reactions can be life-threatening. If you or someone else is experiencing these symptoms, seek immediate medical attention.
scenarios.source: American Academy of Allergy, Asthma & Immunology

scenarios.title: Bleeding from Cuts and Lacerations in Elderly (65+)
immediate_steps: Apply gentle pressure to the wound
Elevate the affected area using a pillow or cushion
Clean and dress the wound with antiseptic wipes and bandages that fit snugly around fragile skin
when_to_seek_help: If bleeding doesn't stop after 10-15 minutes of pressure
If swelling worsens or is accompanied by redness, warmth, or pain
If symptoms of dizziness, lightheadedness, or shortness of breath persist
do_not: Apply tourniquet, as it can cut off circulation and cause further damage
Use harsh soap or hydrogen peroxide on the wound, as they can irritate skin
Bend or lift the affected area, as it can put strain on fragile bones

scenarios.title: Life-Threatening Bleeding from Cuts and Lacerations
immediate_steps: Apply firm pressure to the wound with a clean cloth or gauze for at least 5 minutes
Elevate the affected limb above heart level
Call 911 immediately and provide your location
Administer an antiseptic wipe to the wound, if available
Stay calm and try to remain still until medical help arrives
when_to_seek_help: Immediate attention required; do not delay
Severe bleeding that shows no signs of slowing down
Uncontrolled pain or numbness in extremities
do_not: Do not apply a tourniquet or attempt to stop the bleeding with a hemostatic agent without proper medical training
Do not move the injured person unless they are in a life-threatening position

scenarios.title: Seizures from Head Injuries in Elderly
immediate_steps: Keep the person lying down and turn them onto their side to prevent choking
Loosen tight clothing around the neck
Remove any loose objects or glasses that could cause injury
when_to_seek_help: If the person shows signs of increased intracranial pressure (e.g. headache, confusion)
If the person has a history of seizure disorders or head injuries
do_not: Do not try to restrain the person or give them anything to drink
Do not move the person unless they are in a life-threatening position
scenarios.additional_info: Elderly individuals may have underlying medical conditions that can increase their risk of complications from seizures.

scenarios.title: Head Injuries with Concussion in Elderly
immediate_steps: Monitor vital signs and blood pressure
Provide rest and relaxation, elevate head of bed
Keep the person calm and comfortable, avoid strenuous activities
Call emergency services if symptoms worsen or do not improve
when_to_seek_help: if symptoms worsen or do not improve after 30 minutes
if vomiting lasts more than 2 hours
do_not: administer medication without medical supervision
bend or lift the person, use a bed rail for support instead
drive the person to hospital
allow them to walk or move around if symptoms are present

scenarios.title: Environmental Injuries from Extreme Temperatures (65+)
immediate_steps: Provide warmth and shelter in a well-ventilated area
Remove wet clothing and provide 2+ layers of warm clothing
Monitor for further injury or complications, especially numbness or tingling in extremities
when_to_seek_help: If symptoms worsen, numbness or tingling persists, or confusion or dizziness occurs
do_not: Do not remove wet socks or boots without proper medical supervision
Do not use heating pads or hot water bottles on sensitive skin

scenarios.title: Severe Eye Injury from Flashlight Exposure
symptoms: Severe eye pain, Vision loss, Blurred vision, Double vision, Sensitivity to light
immediate_steps: Call 911 immediately and provide exact location, then proceed with caution. Flush face and eyes with copious amounts of water for at least 20 minutes, until emergency services arrive.
Remove contact lenses if present, but do not attempt to clean them
Apply a cold compress or an ice pack wrapped in a cloth to reduce swelling
when_to_seek_help: Severe eye pain, Vision loss, Blurred vision persist after 20 minutes of flushing and first aid
do_not: Rub eyes vigorously
Touch or blow out the affected eye
Use household cleaners or chemicals to clean the eye
scenarios.additional_info: Seek immediate medical attention if symptoms worsen or do not improve after first aid. Do not delay seeking care.

scenarios.title: Burn from Electrical Appliance (Severe)
symptoms: Difficulty Breathing, Chest Pain, Rapid Heartbeat
immediate_steps: Call 911 IMMEDIATELY and provide location and number of people affected.
Cool with cool water for 10-15 minutes while getting medical help on the way
Remove clothing and jewelry near the burned area, avoiding further irritation
Apply topical antibiotic ointment only if advised to do so by emergency responders
when_to_seek_help: Any sign of infection, Difficulty breathing, Chest pain, Rapid heartbeat
do_not: Use water above 50째F (10째C)
Break blisters or attempt to clean the burn yourself
Apply any ointments or creams without medical supervision
scenarios.additional_info: Seek immediate medical attention from a burn specialist. Do not delay.

scenarios.title: Broken Finger in Elderly
immediate_steps: Apply ice for no more than 15 minutes, 3 times a day
Immobilize the finger with a splint or sling, avoid bending or straightening
Elevate the hand above heart level, avoid heavy lifting or activity
Take over-the-counter pain relievers carefully following dosage instructions
when_to_seek_help: If unable to move the finger
If pain worsens or is severe
do_not: Remove any jewelry or rings on the affected finger, as they can cut skin and increase risk of infection
Try to move the finger excessively, as this can cause further injury
Use NSAIDs without consulting doctor first, especially with other medications
Delay seeking medical attention, especially if symptoms worsen or don't improve

scenarios.title: Severe Finger Injury
symptoms: Swelling and bruising that covers the entire finger
Limited or no mobility in the affected finger
immediate_steps: Call 911 immediately
Immobilize the finger with a rigid splint or sling
Elevate the hand above heart level to reduce swelling
Apply ice packs for 15-20 minutes, 3 times a day
when_to_seek_help: If unable to move the finger
do_not: Remove any jewelry or rings on the affected finger
Apply heat or warm compresses
scenarios.additional_info: This injury may require surgical intervention. Seek immediate medical attention.

scenarios.title: Head Injury in Elderly (65+)
immediate_steps: Remove the person from any further injury
Sit them up gently to prevent choking if they vomit
Loosen tight clothing around their neck, waist, and legs
Monitor their vital signs and keep them calm and comfortable
Get them to a medical facility as soon as possible
when_to_seek_help: If symptoms worsen or do not improve within 24 hours
If they experience difficulty speaking, walking, or swallowing
If they have a history of stroke or head injury
If they are taking medications that may interact with treatment for concussion
do_not: Give them anything to eat or drink without medical supervision
Drive them or perform physical activities until cleared by a doctor
Apply ice packs or cold compresses without consulting a doctor

scenarios.title: Bleeding - External (Elderly)
immediate_steps: Apply firm pressure to the wound for 5-10 minutes
Elevate the injured area above heart level
Clean and dress the wound with sterile gauze
Use a compression dressing if available
Call for medical help immediately
when_to_seek_help: Excessive bleeding that soaks through multiple layers of clothing
Infection, redness, warmth, or pus around the wound
do_not: Remove any clothing that is stuck to the injury, as this can cause further damage
Use harsh soap or hydrogen peroxide on open wounds
Apply a tourniquet unless trained to do so

scenarios.title: Concussion in Elderly (65+)
immediate_steps: Keep the person calm and still in a seated position with support under their neck
Loosen tight clothing around the neck, including collars and ties
Help the person sit comfortably with their head elevated (20-30 degrees)
Provide plenty of rest and monitor for breathing difficulties
when_to_seek_help: Severe symptoms that last for an extended period of time, or if they show signs of worsening (e.g. increased confusion, difficulty speaking)
do_not: Try to revive or perform any strenuous activities, as this can worsen the injury

scenarios.title: Severe Concussion (Critical)
symptoms: Extreme headache with nausea and vomiting
Sudden loss of consciousness or altered mental state
immediate_steps: Call emergency services immediately (911) and provide location
Keep the person's airway clear and turn them onto their side if unconscious
Apply firm and gentle pressure to the back of the head for cervical support
Do not move the person unless they are in a life-threatening position
when_to_seek_help: Any severe symptom or sign, including difficulty breathing, seizures, or weakness
do_not: Try to revive or perform any strenuous activities on your own
Administer medication without medical supervision
scenarios.additional_info: Seek immediate medical attention. Concussions can be life-threatening and may require hospitalization.

scenarios.title: Head, Neck, and Spinal Injury (Elderly)
symptoms: Confusion, disorientation, or altered mental status
immediate_steps: Sit or lie down in a comfortable position to prevent falls
Loosen tight clothing around the neck and chest
Check for any breathing difficulties or swallowing problems
Provide plenty of rest and avoid strenuous activities
when_to_seek_help: Symptoms that worsen over time, or if you experience difficulty speaking or swallowing
Confusion, disorientation, or altered mental status persists
Slurred speech is accompanied by weakness, numbness, or tingling in the face, arm, or leg
do_not: Try to revive or perform any strenuous activities, especially if you have a history of falls or osteoporosis

scenarios.title: Critical Head, Neck, and Spinal Injury
symptoms: Severe, worsening headache with neck stiffness
Loss of consciousness or altered mental state
immediate_steps: Call emergency services immediately (911) and stay on the line
Keep the person's airway clear, if possible, by tilting their head back and lifting their chin
Support the person's neck and spine with a cervical collar or makeshift device
Avoid moving the person except to safely transport them to a medical facility
when_to_seek_help: Any symptom of a potential spinal cord injury, including severe headache, numbness, or weakness
Loss of consciousness or altered mental state lasting more than 30 minutes
do_not: Try to revive or perform any strenuous activities
Move the person except to safely transport them to a medical facility

scenarios.title: Hypothermia (Severe)
symptoms: Slurred speech, drowsiness, and loss of coordination
immediate_steps: Call 911 immediately and provide location information
Remove wet clothing and replace with dry, warm layers
Apply rewarming blankets or a heating pad (set to low)
Use warm compresses on the chest and neck
when_to_seek_help: Hypothermia that lasts for more than 30 minutes in children or adults
Difficulty breathing, rapid heartbeat, or loss of consciousness
do_not: Give any medication without consulting a doctor first
Use ice or cold water to treat hypothermia
Leave the person alone or try to warm them up without proper equipment
scenarios.additional_info: Seek medical attention immediately. Hypothermia can be fatal if left untreated.

scenarios.title: Child Burns - Critical
symptoms: Severe scalding, charring skin and underlying tissue
Painful burning sensation, possible numbness or tingling
Difficulty breathing, rapid heartbeat, pale or cool skin
immediate_steps: Call 911 immediately and provide your location
Remove clothing and jewelry near the burned area while keeping the child calm
Cool the burn with cool tap water for no more than 10 minutes, do not use ice or ice water
Apply a topical antibiotic ointment only if advised by emergency responders or medical professionals
Do not break blisters or scratch the burned skin
when_to_seek_help: Any burn that covers more than 30% of the body surface area
Severe burns that cause difficulty breathing, rapid heartbeat, or dizziness
Burning sensations that do not subside with cooling
do_not: Break blisters or scratch the burned skin under any circumstances
Apply butter, grease, or petroleum jelly to the burn
scenarios.additional_info: Burns can lead to infection, organ damage, and even death if left untreated.

scenarios.title: Senior Fall or Head Injury
immediate_steps: Call emergency services immediately
Keep the person calm and comfortable
Monitor vital signs and keep them upright if possible
do_not: Give medication without consulting a doctor or medical professional
Try to move the person or change their position unless absolutely necessary
scenarios.additional_info: Call for emergency help if symptoms worsen or last longer than expected.

scenarios.title: Child Head Injury (Critical)
immediate_steps: Call 911 immediately and provide your location
Apply a firm but gentle cervical collar to stabilize the neck
Administer CPR if the child is unresponsive or not breathing
when_to_seek_help: Increased intracranial pressure (e.g. bulging anteroinferior fontanelle)
Loss of speech or swallowing function
do_not: Move the child or attempt to remove any objects from their head or neck
Give medication without consulting a doctor
Apply ice packs or cold compresses to the wound
Try to revive the child yourself if they are unresponsive
scenarios.additional_info: Every minute counts in emergency situations. Call 911 for immediate assistance.

scenarios.title: Severe Cut from Glass
symptoms: severe bleeding that won't stop with pressure
numbness or tingling in the face or extremities
immediate_steps: Call 911 immediately and provide your location
Apply firm pressure to the wound with a clean cloth for 10-15 minutes
Clean the cut with soap and water, but avoid applying antibiotic ointment
Do not move or remove any debris from the wound
when_to_seek_help: excessive bleeding that shows no signs of slowing down
signs of infection (increased redness, swelling, or pus)
severe numbness or tingling in the face or extremities
do_not: move the person to a different location until medical help arrives
apply pressure that is too firm or uses an object other than a clean cloth
use any medications without consulting a doctor first
scenarios.additional_info: Seek immediate medical attention for severe cuts. Prompt treatment can help prevent long-term damage and reduce the risk of infection.

scenarios.title: Broken Arm in Traffic Accident (Elderly)
immediate_steps: Stop the bleeding with a clean cloth, then call for help and wait for medical assistance
Avoid moving the arm excessively, as this can worsen the fracture
do_not: apply ice directly to the skin, as this can cause numbness and discomfort in older adults
move the arm excessively, as this can worsen the fracture
try to lift or move the person with the broken arm without proper assistance
scenarios.additional_info: Fractures in elderly patients are more prone to complications due to osteoporosis. Seek medical help immediately for proper immobilization and fracture reduction.

scenarios.title: Severe Fracture of Arm in Traffic Accident
symptoms: numbness or tingling that spreads to other areas
weakness or paralysis in the arm
immediate_steps: Call 911 immediately
Apply a firm, yet not tight, bandage to the affected area to stop bleeding
when_to_seek_help: increased pain that cannot be managed with pain medication
difficulty moving the arm or hand
weakness or paralysis in the arm
do_not: move the arm excessively, as this can cause further injury
apply ice directly to the skin, as this can cause frostbite
remove any clothing or jewelry that is constricting the affected area
scenarios.additional_info: Seek immediate medical help for proper immobilization and fracture reduction. Do not attempt to treat yourself.

scenarios.title: Severe Scald from Hot Water
symptoms: Severe painful burning sensation that can lead to charring of skin and underlying tissues.
Swelling, redness, and blisters that may be accompanied by fever, nausea, and vomiting.
immediate_steps: Call 911 or your local emergency number IMMEDIATELY.
Turn off the source of heat immediately and move away from it to avoid further injury.
Remove clothing around the affected area as quickly and carefully as possible.
Apply a sterile, non-stick dressing over the burn to protect it from further irritation.
when_to_seek_help: Severe burns that require immediate medical attention, including but not limited to:
Burns covering more than 10% of your body surface area
Burns in sensitive areas such as the face, hands, or genitalia
Burns with signs of infection, such as increased redness, swelling, or pus
do_not: Do not attempt to treat the burn yourself. This can lead to further injury and delay medical attention.
Do not immerse the burned area in cold water without consulting a medical professional first.
scenarios.additional_info: Seek immediate medical attention if you experience any of the following: shortness of breath, chest pain, or a fever above 101.5째F (38.6째C).

scenarios.title: Panic Attack (Elderly)
symptoms: Rapid heartbeat, sweating, trembling, confusion or disorientation
immediate_steps: Find a safe place to sit and relax with support, if possible.
Deep breathing exercises can help calm the body and mind. Consider using a walking aid for balance.
do_not: Use stimulants like caffeine or nicotine without consulting your doctor.
Engage in strenuous physical activity
scenarios.additional_info: Medications may be necessary to manage anxiety. Consult your doctor before taking any new medications.

scenarios.title: Insect Bite Allergic Reaction (Elderly)
symptoms: Rash, itching, swelling in small areas
immediate_steps: Apply hydrocortisone cream to the affected area without stinging.
Take a gentle oral antihistamine like diphenhydramine if symptoms worsen.
Rest and elevate legs to reduce swelling.
when_to_seek_help: Increased difficulty breathing, severe swelling of face or throat
do_not: Use ice packs or cold showers without medical supervision due to risk of cardiovascular complications.
Take high-dose pain relievers like acetaminophen or ibuprofen as they may interact with medications.
scenarios.additional_info: Consult doctor if symptoms worsen or don't improve, especially in older adults with pre-existing conditions.

scenarios.title: Elderly Burns from Hot Water
immediate_steps: Remove affected clothing carefully to avoid further injury
Cool with cool tap water for 10-15 minutes, or until pain subsides
Apply topical ointment after consulting doctor
do_not: Try to flush the wound with water
Use ice or cold compresses on exposed skin (may cause further injury)
scenarios.additional_info: Elderly patients may experience delayed symptoms; seek medical attention if any signs of respiratory distress persist.

scenarios.title: Child Burns from Hot Water - Critical
immediate_steps: Remove affected clothing ASAP, call 911 immediately
Cool with cool tap water for 10 minutes, but do not delay calling emergency services
Apply topical ointment, but only if advised by medical professional
when_to_seek_help: Severe pain that worsens over time
do_not: Try to flush the wound with water
Use ice or cold compresses on the burned area
Give any medications without medical supervision
scenarios.additional_info: Do not leave child unattended until medical help arrives. If child is unconscious, not breathing, or has severe burns, start CPR if trained to do so.

scenarios.title: Elderly Fall from Height
symptoms: Weakness or numbness in face, arm, or leg
immediate_steps: Call emergency services and stay on the line
Check for breathing, pulse, and responsiveness
Apply gentle cervical support (if able to move person)
do_not: Move the person unless absolutely necessary
Administer medication without medical guidance
scenarios.additional_info: Perform CPR if cardiac arrest is suspected, but avoid chest compressions in elderly patients with certain conditions.

scenarios.title: Burns from Scalding Water (Severe)
immediate_steps: Call 911 immediately
Stop the burn with cool tap water for 10-15 minutes
Remove clothing near the burned area
Apply a topical antibiotic ointment
Elevate the affected limb above heart level
when_to_seek_help: Decreased sensation in the burned area
do_not: Break blisters or scratch the burn
Use harsh soap or cleansers on the burn
scenarios.additional_info: Seek medical attention immediately, even if symptoms seem minor

scenarios.title: Head Injury from Fall (65+)
immediate_steps: Clear the airway
Stabilize the neck with a cervical collar
Call emergency services immediately and ask for assistance
when_to_seek_help: No improvement after 15 minutes of treatment
do_not: Try to move the person or give medication without consulting a doctor
Assist the person with walking or mobility, as this can exacerbate injury
scenarios.additional_info: Seek medical attention within 1 hour

scenarios.title: Cerebral Concussion from High-Impact Fall
symptoms: Loss of consciousness for more than 30 seconds
Confusion and disorientation with inability to respond to environment
Weakness, numbness, or paralysis in limbs
immediate_steps: Clear the airway and begin CPR if not breathing
when_to_seek_help: No improvement after 5 minutes of treatment
do_not: Try to move the person without stabilizing neck with a cervical collar
Give medication or try to treat without consulting a doctor
Conceal symptoms or delay seeking medical attention
scenarios.additional_info: Call 911 immediately and follow emergency medical services (EMS) instructions. Do not attempt to drive yourself to hospital

scenarios.title: Severe Burned Hand
immediate_steps: Call 911 immediately
Stop burning process
Cool burn with cool water
Remove clothing near burned area
Apply topical antibiotic ointment
Cover with non-stick dressing and secure with sterile bandages
Elevate burned hand above heart level
do_not: Apply butter or oil
Break blisters
Use harsh soap or cleanser
Apply a tourniquet
scenarios.additional_info: Monitor for signs of infection and seek medical attention immediately if symptoms worsen, do not attempt to drive or operate heavy machinery

scenarios.title: Severe Bite from a Wild Animal
symptoms: Swelling and redness that spreads rapidly
immediate_steps: Call 911 immediately
Apply firm pressure to the wound with a clean cloth
Keep victim calm and still until medical help arrives
Do not remove clothing or accessories near the bite area
when_to_seek_help: Uncontrolled bleeding that soaks through the dressing
Signs of sepsis, such as rapid heartbeat or confusion
do_not: Try to suck out the venom
Apply a tourniquet
Give the victim anything to eat or drink
scenarios.additional_info: Monitor vital signs closely and be prepared for potential complications. Do not attempt to treat the wound without proper medical training.

scenarios.title: Severe Respiratory Distress
symptoms: Coughing up blood with frothy sputum
Severe shortness of breath, difficulty speaking
immediate_steps: Call emergency services immediately (911 in USA) - do not attempt to drive yourself to the hospital
Administer oxygen via non-rebreather mask if available and instructions are clear
Lay patient on back with legs elevated 12 inches, head slightly elevated
Keep airway open by tilting head back, supporting neck, and lifting chin
when_to_seek_help: Immediately seek medical attention if symptoms worsen or do not improve with treatment
do_not: Do not try to give the patient oxygen without proper training and equipment
Do not attempt to treat the patient at home unless absolutely necessary
scenarios.additional_info: Continue to monitor vital signs closely and seek immediate medical attention if symptoms worsen or do not improve with treatment. Call emergency services again if breathing becomes labored, chest pain occurs, or consciousness is lost.

scenarios.title: Burned Skin in Elderly (65+)
immediate_steps: Apply topical antibiotic ointment to affected area, but avoid breaking blisters
Cover with non-stick dressing and secure with elastic bandage to prevent dislodging
Keep wound moist with a topical ointment and change dressing daily
Avoid over-bathing or soaking the burned area
when_to_seek_help: Symptoms worsen or do not improve after 3-5 days
Infection signs: increased redness, swelling, pus, fever
do_not: Break blisters with fingers
Apply harsh soap or hydrogen peroxide to burned area
scenarios.additional_info: Monitor for signs of infection and seek medical attention immediately if symptoms worsen or if patient experiences difficulty breathing, chest pain, or fever over 101.5째F (38.6째C)

scenarios.title: Severe Burned Skin
symptoms: Charring of skin and underlying tissues
Difficulty breathing due to inhalation injury
immediate_steps: Call 911 immediately
Remove clothing around the burned area if possible without exposing wound to air
Apply a non-stick dressing or burn blanket and immobilize with a sterile bandage
Administer topical antibiotic ointment only after stabilizing patient
do_not: Do not attempt to remove clothing from the burned area without proper training and equipment
Do not apply water or ice to the burned area unless advised by medical professional
scenarios.additional_info: Seek immediate medical attention at an emergency room. Monitor for signs of shock, infection, and respiratory distress.

scenarios.title: Tetanus Shot Reactions in Elderly Patients
symptoms: Muscle stiffness, especially in older adults may be mistaken for arthritis
Confusion or disorientation due to medication interactions
immediate_steps: Administer over-the-counter pain medication if needed, with caution and under medical supervision
Apply cool compress to affected area, but avoid excessive straining or lifting
Monitor vital signs closely, especially blood pressure and heart rate
when_to_seek_help: Increased muscle stiffness, especially if accompanied by shortness of breath or difficulty breathing
Confusion or disorientation that worsens over time
Dizziness or lightheadedness that persists or is severe
do_not: Administer acetaminophen without consulting a doctor first, as it may interact with other medications
scenarios.additional_info: Continue to monitor vital signs closely and seek medical attention if symptoms worsen or fail to improve with treatment
scenarios.source: American Geriatrics Society Emergency Care Guidelines

scenarios.title: Tetanus Shot Reactions - Critical
symptoms: Severe muscle stiffness that causes difficulty breathing or swallowing
immediate_steps: Call 911 immediately if symptoms occur
Administer oxygen and keep airway clear if possible
Apply ice pack to affected area to reduce swelling
when_to_seek_help: Any of the following symptoms: severe muscle stiffness, high fever, rapid heartbeat, or difficulty speaking
scenarios.additional_info: Continue to monitor vital signs and seek immediate medical attention if symptoms worsen
scenarios.source: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC)

scenarios.title: Severe Burns in the Elderly
immediate_steps: Call emergency services and stay on the line
Move to a safe location away from heat sources
Remove any clothing near the burn area, but do not break blisters
when_to_seek_help: Signs of shock or low blood pressure
Difficulty breathing or shortness of breath
do_not: Use harsh soap or cleansers on elderly skin
Apply a tourniquet or use a tight bandage
Stay in the same location for an extended period

scenarios.title: Environmental Poisoning in Elderly
immediate_steps: Call the poison control center or 911 immediately
Remove contaminated clothing and wash affected area with soap and water, but avoid exacerbating any skin conditions
Provide fresh air, sit upright, and elevate legs if possible
when_to_seek_help: Severe symptoms, worsening symptoms, or symptoms not improving within an hour
do_not: Try to treat symptoms at home without medical guidance, as they may be indicative of underlying conditions
Give medication unless advised by a healthcare professional

scenarios.title: Environmental Poisoning (Severe)
symptoms: Severe nausea and vomiting, leading to dehydration
Dizziness that progresses to loss of consciousness
Severe headache with stiff neck and confusion
Difficulty breathing, coughing up blood or froth
Rapid heartbeat and fall in blood pressure
immediate_steps: Call emergency services immediately via 911
Remove contaminated clothing and wash affected area with soap and water (while on phone)
Provide fresh air by opening windows and using a fan to ventilate the room
Administer first aid for choking if necessary
when_to_seek_help: Severe symptoms that occur within minutes of exposure
Symptoms worsen over time or do not improve with treatment
Difficulty breathing, cardiac arrest, or seizures
do_not: Try to treat symptoms at home without medical guidance
Use household cleaners, chemicals, or medications to treat poisoning

scenarios.title: Severe Cut from Broken Glass
symptoms: swelling and bruising around the wound
immediate_steps: Call emergency services immediately (911) and stay on hold
Apply firm pressure to stop bleeding using a clean cloth or gauze
Immobilize the injured area with a splint if possible
Do not remove the foreign object from the wound
do_not: Apply antibiotic ointment without consulting medical professional
Use harsh soap or cleanser on the wound
Apply a tourniquet unless you're trained to do so
scenarios.additional_info: Wash hands thoroughly, seek medical attention as soon as possible

scenarios.title: Severe Burns from Fire in Elderly (65+)
symptoms: shortness of breath, coughing up blood
immediate_steps: Call 911 or your local emergency number immediately
Remove any clothing or jewelry that is in contact with the burn, but avoid using cold water
when_to_seek_help: Shortness of breath, coughing up blood
do_not: Use soap, ointment, or lotion on the burn
Apply a tourniquet or use constrictive bandages
scenarios.additional_info: Get the burn to a burn center as soon as possible, and consider seeking medical attention for any underlying health conditions
scenarios.source: National Institute on Aging Emergency Care

scenarios.title: Broken Arm in Car Accident (Elderly)
immediate_steps: Immobilize the arm with a splint or sling, but avoid bending at the shoulder
Apply ice to reduce swelling and bruising, for no more than 15 minutes at a time
Monitor for numbness, tingling, or weakness in the arm or hand
when_to_seek_help: if symptoms worsen or do not improve within 24 hours
if there is numbness, tingling, or weakness that persists
do_not: Bend, lift, or move the affected arm, as this can exacerbate the injury and increase risk of complications
Drive or operate heavy machinery until further notice
scenarios.additional_info: Seek medical attention immediately, even if symptoms seem mild. Elderly patients are at higher risk for complications from fractures.
scenarios.source: National Institute on Aging Emergency Care

scenarios.title: Severe Broken Arm in Car Accident
immediate_steps: Call 911 immediately
Immobilize the arm with a splint or sling, but do not attempt to move it
Apply ice to reduce swelling
Elevate the affected arm above heart level
Monitor for numbness or tingling
Do not remove any medical equipment attached to the arm
when_to_seek_help: If symptoms worsen or do not improve within 24 hours
do_not: Bend, lift, or move the affected arm
Apply heat to the area
scenarios.additional_info: Seek immediate medical attention if unable to move arm or hand

scenarios.title: Critical Wild Animal Bite
symptoms: swelling that covers the face and neck
bleeding that is heavy and rapid
immediate_steps: Call 911 or your local emergency number IMMEDIATELY
Perform a CPR if the person is unresponsive and not breathing
Keep the person calm and still until medical help arrives
when_to_seek_help: If symptoms worsen or do not improve with treatment
do_not: Try to suck out the venom or apply a tourniquet
Apply any topical creams or ointments without consulting a doctor first
scenarios.additional_info: Get the person to a hospital immediately if possible

scenarios.title: General Illness (Dehydration) in Elderly
immediate_steps: Offer water or an oral rehydration solution slowly and frequently, as quickly gulping can exacerbate dehydration
Encourage rest and hydration in a cool, quiet space
Monitor for signs of severe dehydration, such as confusion, seizures, or loss of consciousness
when_to_seek_help: if symptoms worsen or do not improve within 2-3 hours
if the person has underlying medical conditions, such as kidney disease or heart failure
do_not: Give the person energy drinks or caffeinated beverages, which can exacerbate dehydration in elderly
Use medications that require careful hydration management, such as diuretics
scenarios.additional_info: Get the person to a hospital immediately if they show signs of severe dehydration or have underlying medical conditions

scenarios.title: General Illness (Dehydration - Severe)
immediate_steps: Call emergency services immediately (911) and explain symptoms
Apply a bandage or tourniquet to limb if bleeding is severe
Administer oral rehydration solution or IV fluids under medical guidance
when_to_seek_help: If showing signs of shock, coma, or severe organ failure
do_not: Give the person energy drinks or caffeinated beverages
Try to treat without immediate medical attention
scenarios.additional_info: Transport to hospital via ambulance if unable to do so yourself

scenarios.title: Severe Wound on Leg
symptoms: swelling that is difficult to move the leg
numbness or tingling in the leg
immediate_steps: Call emergency services immediately and let them know you need a 911 call. Have someone else apply firm pressure with a clean cloth for 10 minutes if possible.
Elevate the injured leg above heart level to reduce swelling, but do not move it excessively as it may worsen bleeding
Clean the wound with sterile bandages and secure them tightly to prevent further injury
when_to_seek_help: Signs of severe infection (pus or discharge)
Difficulty moving the leg due to severe pain or swelling
Loss of sensation in the leg
Severe bleeding that doesn't stop with pressure
do_not: Apply harsh soap, hydrogen peroxide, or other cleansers on the wound
Move the injured leg excessively
Remove any constrictive clothing around the wound
scenarios.additional_info: Seek immediate medical attention if symptoms worsen or do not improve after initial treatment. Monitor for signs of shock (dizziness, pale skin, weak pulse) and report to medical staff upon arrival.
